FIGREF10.text: RESULTS:Dams showed elevated IL-1β blood titers from 3 to 72 h following the GBS inflammatory challenge. At 72 h post-GBS, IL-1β expression was also increased in placentas and fetal blood. Placental histology revealed diffuse polymorphonuclear (PMN) cells infiltrations in the decidua and the labyrinth of placentas 24 h and 48 h after the GBS exposure. Multifocal areas of IL-1β positive PMN and macrophages were observed at 72 h on the fetal face of the placenta and in arterial walls of the umbilical cord vessels after the GBS challenge. Placental levels of metalloproteinase 10 (MMP-10) were increased at 48 h after the GBS exposure. CONCLUSIONS: To our knowledge, this is the first study assessing inflammatory molecular pathways leading to GBS-induced CA. This work helps to understand which molecular pathways could be involved in the occurrence of CA and open the door to new therapeutics avenues, such as cytokine blockade, to protect newborns from the adverse effects of CA.

FIGREF11.text: of CD83 Expression and sCD83 Secretion in the Course of Pregnancy. Katrin RH Packhauser, Damian O Muzzio, Olivia J Heidecke, Anne Tungler, Carolin Weinhold, Marek Zygmunt. Universitätsmedizin Greifswald, Greifswald, Germany. INTRODUCTION: CD83, a highly conserved 40-45 kDa transmembrane molecule and activation marker on dendritic cells, has been postulated to be involved in the modulation of immune response during pregnancy. Its expression on the surface of immune cells is linked to immunosuppressive effects: B cells overexpressing CD83 show a high expression of the anti-inflammatory Interleukin 10 and simultaneously a lower secretion of antibodies. The membrane-bound form of CD83 generates a soluble protein (sCD83), which inhibits the anti-tumor-response of the immune system.

CONCLUSIONS: Apart from the well-established endocrine function of hCG during the pregnancy our results indicate a possible function of hCG in the development of the fetal immune system. Differences in the development of B-and T-cells between male and female newborns could be responsible for their varying susceptibility to infections. Further studies are underway to depict the modulatory role in the modulation of the naive immune system.

FIGREF14.text: Human endometrial adenonocarcinoma HEC-1B cells were incubated in the presence of 10 µM TAM for 0, 24, 48, 72 hours. DPPIV protein expression of was determined at each time by flow cytometry, western blot and immunofluorescence, and gene expression by Real-Time PCR. Treatments with ammonium chloride (0, 6 hours) at 30 mM and with methyl-β-cyclodextrin (0, 2 hours) at 5 mM were also performed.RESULTS: Unstimulated HEC-1B cells expressed DPPIV at the cell surface. TAM treatment induced the clearance of DPPIV form cell surface and its accumulation into the lysosomes, where it colocalized with Lamp1 protein. This phenomenon is progressive and reversible (Figure 1), and can be prevented either by blocking lysosomal function with ammonium chloride or by inhibiting endocytosis with methyl-β-cyclodextrin. *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: TAM induces the clearance of DPPIV from the cell surface by endocytosis and lysosomal degradation. These results provide information about a novel mode of action of TAM in endometrium.

T-261 Conditioned Medium from Human Amniotic Fluid Stem Cell Ameliorated Glutamate-Induced Apoptosis. Marie Fukutake, Daigo Ochiai, Hirotaka Masuda, Youhei Akiba, Toshimitsu Otani, Yoshifumi Kasuga, Tadashi Matsumoto, Kei Miyakoshi, Mamoru Tanaka. Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Shinjyuku-ku, Shinanomachi, Japan. INTRODUCTION: Glutamate-induced apoptosis (G-apoptosis) plays a central role in the pathogenesis of perinatal brain injury. In this study, mesenchymal stem cells derived from human amniotic fluid (hAF-MSC) were established and the effect of conditioned medium (CM) from hAF-MSC on G-apoptosis was determined.METHODS:The study was approved by the institutional review board of our university and informed consent was obtained from all patients. hAF samples were obtained by amniocentesis. CD117 + cells selected by microbeads were characterized by flow cytometry for surface markers of mesenchymal (CD29, CD73, and CD90) and hematopoietic (CD14, CD34, and HLA-DR) stem cells. CD117 + cells were analyzed to confirm their differentiation into osteogenic, adipogenic, and chondrogenic lineages. SH-SY5Y human neuroblastoma cells were treated with excess glutamate in the presence and absence of CM. After 24 hours of treatment, apoptotic cells were quantified using annexin-V immunostaining. RESULTS: CD117 + cells were positive for mesenchymal markers, but negative for hematopoietic markers. The differentiation of CD117 + cells into three lineages was confirmed by Alizarin Red S, Oil Red O and Alcian Blue staining *Figure(s) will be available online. The number of apoptotic cells increased after glutamate treatment; however, CM treatment alleviated this effect. CONCLUSIONS: We established hAF-MSC and CM from hAF-MSC alleviated G-apoptosis.

RESULTS: EM observation demonstrated the adherence and intracellular invasion of UPA to fetal membrane cells. Cell death was not observed under 4 hours of UPA stimulation. Thrombin secretion (pg/ml) was significantly induced by UPA exposure compared to control in amnion epithelial cells (55±11 vs 21±15, P=0.03), amnion mesenchymal cells (48±15 vs 0±0, P=0.048), chorion cells (64±11 vs 11±5, P=0.003), and decidua cells (61±10 vs 0±0, P=0.009). Immunofluorescence observations revealed a typical perinuclear localization of thrombin in amnion epithelial cells. The localization of thrombin in other fetal membrane cells was perinuclear and cytoplasmic. *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: UPA adheres to and invades fetal membrane cells. UPA colonization to these cells induces thrombin generation. These findings provide novel insights into the pathogenicity of UPA and highlight a mechanism by which UPA may induce fetal membrane rupture. FIGREF35.text: Early Stage Endometriosis by Intraperitoneal Inoculation of Uterine Tissue Induces an Acute Sterile Peritonitis with Pelvic Pain in Mice. Janina Boyken, Alexis Laux-Biehlmann, Jens Nagel, Thomas M Zollner, Nicole Schmidt. Bayer Healthcare, Berlin, Germany. INTRODUCTION:Retrograde delivered menstrual debris and cyclic tissue death in endometriotic lesion are clinically relevant pathological mechanisms that occur within the peritoneal cavity and potentially disturb peritoneal homeostasis. The cell death in the tissue is thought to activate the immune system possibly leading to inflammation and pelvic pain observed in women with endometriosis. We have previously shown that intraperitoneal inoculation of uterine tissue causes acute inflammation and pain in mice. As both inflammation and pain are well described features of classic infectious peritonitis model in mice, we further evaluated the underlying inflammatory mechanisms and investigated if the presence of uterine tissue in the peritoneal cavity triggers all hallmarks of a sterile peritonitis. METHODS: Retrograde menstruation was mimicked by inoculation of syngeneic uterine tissue in the peritoneal cavity of BALB/c mice.

TABREF35.text: potential role in EVT invasion. The objective of this research is to investigate further the role of MTA3 in EVT invasion. We hypothesize that MTA3, as part of the NuRD complex, regulates trophoblast invasion directly through invasion genes, MMP2, MMP9 and Snail expression. METHODS: We immunostained for MTA3 protein in term placenta tissue sections (n=8) to verify its expression in trophoblast cells. Lentivirus carrying MTA3 cDNA and shRNA were used to overexpess or knock down MTA3 expression in HTR8SV/neo cells, a model of EVT, and a Matrigel invasion assay was performed. mRNA and protein levels of MMP2, MMP9 and Snail, required for trophoblast invasion, were evaluated via qRT-PCR and Western Blot. MTA3 assembly with NuRD complex was tested by immunoprecipitation from HTR8SV/neo extract with MTA3 antibody, then co-IP-Western-Blot and co-IP-Mass-SPEC were conducted to identify the protein makeup of the complex. RESULTS: MTA3 is expressed in the EVT cells in human term placenta.CONCLUSIONS:In summary, our data show that MTA3 regulates Snail and MMP expression via NuRD complex. The negative regulatory effect of MTA3 on EVT invasion which could be the tribute to the etiology/ pathology of preeclamptic placenta. The T-HESC cell line, representing decidua cells, and first trimester decidua tissues were treated with siRNAs against NODAL after which IGF1 mRNA expression was measured by quantitative RT-PCR and IGF1 secretion in media by Western blot. Recombinant IGF1 was added to SGHPL-5 extravillous trophoblast cells for 72h after which the effects on STOX1 mRNA expression were measured. Secondly, in these cells, STOX1 localization in different protein compartments was studied by Western blot. RESULTS: T-HESC cells treated with NODAL siRNAs showed significant upregulation of IGF1 mRNA, while a clear trend towards increased secretion of IGF1 in media obtained from the cells and decidua tissues was seen. Addition of IGF1 to the media of SGHPL-5 cells upregulated STOX1 mRNA expression, while Western blot on different protein compartments showed that the nuclear concentration of STOX1 protein decreased with the cytoplasmic STOX1 concentration increasing. CONCLUSIONS: In this study we show that downregulated Nodal expression in the first trimester decidua increases IGF1 secretion. In extravillous trophoblasts, this IGF1 increase leads to a shuttling of the STOX1 protein from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. This most likely occurs via the PI3K-Akt pathway which can be activated by IGF1, while STOX1 is known to be regulated by Akt, with phosphorylation causing STOX1 shuttling to the cytoplasm where it is degraded. This also explains the upregulation of STOX1 mRNA; due to activation of the PI3K-Akt pathway, less STOX1 protein is present in the nucleus which is replenished by increasing the STOX1 mRNA production of the cell.University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio, San Antonio, TX, USA; 3 University of Colorado Anschutz Medical campus, Aurora, CO, USA. TABREF36.text: Novel mutations in HUWE1, a chromatin ubiquitin ligase, and MLL2, a histone lysine H3K4 methyltransferase, were detected in 8 and 9 tumors, respectively. CNV analysis identified 12 copy number gains and 12 losses in similar pathways that were altered in the SNV analysis. In addition to loss of STK11, FBXW7, MML2 and MLL3, data revealed frequent deletion of a segment of chromosome 18 encoding SMAD4 and frequent amplification of chromosome segments containing PIK3CA, CASD1, MAST2, FXR1, GNAS, SGC2, DGKI, and MAPK15. INTRODUCTION: To evaluate whether performing antenatal testing on the basis of morbid obesity affects perinatal morbidity and mortality. METHODS: A retrospective case-control study was performed on patients who delivered at the Regional Medical Center from 2007-2013.The historical control group consisted of patients with the diagnosis of morbid obesity that delivered at between 2007 and 2010. The prospective cohort group consisted of patients with the diagnosis of morbid obesity that delivered between 2011 and 2013 and received weekly antenatal testing starting at 32 weeks of gestation in the outpatient setting. Morbid obesity was defined as BMI ≥ 40. The historical control was matched to the prospective cohort based upon patient BMI. Patients who had maternal or fetal comorbidities outside of obesity necessitating antenatal testing were excluded. The cohorts were compared for mode of delivery, fetal outcome, and antepartum comorbidities. Chi-square test and likelihood ratio testing were used to analyze the results.RESULTS:The historical control group consisted of 139 patients with morbid obesity that did not undergo weekly antenatal testing. The prospective cohort group consisted of 139 patients that received weekly antenatal testing. There was no statistically significant difference between the two cohorts in rate of cesarean delivery or preterm delivery. There was no difference in hypertensive disorders, gestational diabetes or other pregnancy-induced conditions between the two cohorts. INTRODUCTION: Urinary tract infection is common in pregnancy and associated with fever and pyelonephritis. Urine is routinely sampled from the mid-stream portion of a voided sample (MSU) and if epithelial cells are seen on microscopy, the sample is disregarded as a contaminated specimen. Outside pregnancy, a catheter specimen urine (CSU) is considered to contain fewer contaminants. No direct comparison between the two methods has been made in pregnancy. At term pregnancy, MSU has more bacterial growth and a higher proportion of urothelial cells with closely associated bacteria when compared to CSU. This suggests that the presence of urothelial cells in MSU may indicate underlying bacteriuria rather than simply contamination. This has implications for the correct interpretation of MSU findings in late pregnancy.

METHODS: This is a retrospective cohort study of women who received a transvaginal ultrasound (US) at an academic medical center in 2014 due to pain or bleeding in the first trimester. Primary outcome was incidence of non-diagnostic US in obese vs. non-obese women (BMI >30kg/m2 vs <30 kg/m2). Inclusion criteria: age >19; vaginal bleeding or pain in the first trimester. Exclusion criteria: prior US documenting IUP, routine/follow-up US. Groups were compared using chi-square, t test and Mann Whitney as applicable. Logistic regression was used for multivariable adjustments.

RESULTS: Fractal dimension score ranged from 1.63-1.81. There was a significant negative correlation between fractal dimension and gestational age at delivery (r=-0.42[-0.65, -0.11], P=0.0083). There was a significant positive correlation between fractal dimension and birthweight percentile (r=0.35 [0.0.15, 0.61], P=0.041). CONCLUSIONS: In SGA pregnancies, increased villous complexity may allow for increased fetal growth and subsequent larger birthweight but decreases with advancing gestation. Future studies of fractal dimension score in SGA and normal pregnancies are needed to determine if fractal dimension can identify placental insufficiency leading to growth restriction.Infection of Placental Hofbauer Cells (HBCs) with Herpes Virus Suppresses Both Response to LPS and Bactericidal Properties:Consequences for Bacterial Infection of the Fetus. Seth Guller, Zhonghua Tang, Vikki M Abrahams, Gil Mor. Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA. INTRODUCTION: The role of a polymicrobial viral-bacterial infection of the placenta in fetal infection remains largely unexplored. Herpes simplex virus is the most common sexually transmitted infection in adult females, and genital herpes infection during pregnancy is linked to fetal mortality. HBCs are placental macrophages located between the syncytium and fetal capillaries, a critical site for the protection against microbes migrating from the mother to the fetus. Our goal was to test whether infection of HBCs with herpes virus alters their ability to respond to bacterial LPS and to restrict bacterial proliferation, requisite functions for preventing transplacental fetal infection. METHODS: HBCs isolated from normal term placenta (n=5) were uninfected or infected for 1 h with murine herpes virus (MHV)-68 (10 5 cfu/ml), fresh media was added, and 24 h later cells were treated with and without 1 ng/ml LPS for 15 min to 24 h. Secretion of IL-1β, TNF-α, and other cytokines was measured by ELISA and multiplex assay. Cytokine mRNA expression was assessed by qPCR. Western blotting was used to examine LPS signaling pathways. Bactericidal properties of HBCs were measured using Td-Tomato labeled E. coli (TL-E. coli, MOI=10), which were incubated with MHV-68-infected and uninfected HBCs for 24 h after which TL-E. coli were localized in HBCs by microscopy. RESULTS: MHV-68 infection of HBCs significantly suppressed the LPSmediated enhancement of IL-1β and TNF-α secretion and up-regulation of IL-1β and TNF-α mRNA from 69% to 98%. LPS-enhanced secretion of IL-6, G-CSF, MIP-1α, MIP-1β, and RANTES, but not GM-CSF, MCP-1, IL-8, and IP-10, was reduced in MHV-68-infected HBCs from 55% to 80%. MHV-68 infection also blocked LPS-dependent down-regulation of IκBα and the phosphorylation of IKK, indicating that MHV-68 infection suppresses LPS-driven NF-κB signaling through an IKK-dependent mechanism. Using TL-E. coli, we observed that the bactericidal properties of HBCs were reduced ~50% in MHV-68-infected HBCs.CONCLUSIONS: Our results indicate that herpes viral infection of HBCs blocks their ability to respond to LPS and inhibits their bactericidal properties. This suggests that a polymicrobial viral-bacterial infection of the placenta may suppress physiological responses of HBCs to bacteria resulting in bacterial proliferation and transplacental infection of the fetus. Angiotensin II (Ang II) was used to stimulate PVSMC contraction.

TABREF157.text: Toll Like Receptor-4(TLR4) Placental Expression Reflects MaternalObesogenic Environment But Does Not Predict Neonatal Adiposity. Xiaohua Yang, 1 Ming Li, 2 Maricela Haghiac, 1 Patricia Glazebrook, 1 Judi Minium, 1 Perrie O'Tierney-Ginn, 1 Patrick M Catalano, 1 Sylvie Hauguel-de Mouzon. 1 1 MetroHealth Medical Center, CWRU, Cleveland, OH, USA; 2 CWRU, Cleveland, OH, USA. INTRODUCTION:Obesity in pregnancy aggravates inflammation and predisposes the fetus to excess adiposity, a risk factor for development of metabolic disorders later in life.The placenta contributes to the inflammatory environment through the activation of TLR4 signaling pathways. The aim of this study was to assess the relationships between placental TLR4 expression and neonatal adiposity. METHODS: Thirty nine healthy women with pre-gravid BMI <25(lean) or ≥30(obese) were recruited at term scheduled C-section(NIH:HD22965). Maternal venous and fetal cord blood were sampled to measure inflammatory and metabolic markers. Placenta tissue and cells were prepared for TLR4 expression by immunohistochemistry, WB and RT-PCR. Results were analyzed with ANOVA, Spearman's Rank Correlation Coefficient (SRCC) and partial SRCC analysis. RESULTS: Neonates from obese women were heavier at birth (3.8±0.4vs.3.0±0.3kg, p<0.001) with a higher percentage of body fat (%BF)(15.9±2.9vs.10.8±2.8, p<0.001). Neonatal %BF was strongly associated with maternal pre-gravid BMI (r=0.52, p<0.001).TLR4, IL6 and IL8 expression was increased 3-fold (p<0.001) in placenta of obese vs. lean women. TLR4 protein was detected on both sides of the placental barrier i.e. in trophoblast cells facing maternal blood and macrovascular endothelial cells lining fetal vasculature. Placental TLR4 expression exhibited positive correlations with maternal pre-gravid BMI, plasma leptin, CRP and placentalweight (PW) (r=0.57, 0.73, 0.54, 0.36, p<0.05) but not with maternal age (MA), gestational age (GA) and gestational weight gain (GWG)(r<0.2, p>0.05). Placental TLR4 was also correlated with neonatal %BF, ponderal index, cord plasma leptin and insulin (r=0.52, 0.48, 0.42, 0.35, p<0.01). However, after adjusting for maternal variables: pre-gravid BMI, HOMA, MA, GA, GWG and PW, the correlation between placental TLR4 and neonatal %BF was no longer significant (r=0.33, p=0.07). CONCLUSIONS: Expression of TLR4 and inflammatory cytokines IL6 and IL8 was increased in placenta of obese vs. lean women. Placental TLR4 strongly correlated with maternal pre-gravid BMI but not with neonatal adiposity. These data suggest that the activation of placental innate immune pathways reflects the pre-pregnancy obesogenic environment but does not directly contribute to fetal fat accretion.Prenatal Maternal Stress Alters Placental Endocrine Functions inSex Dependent Manner. A M Nuzzo, 1,2 E J Camm, 1 A N Sferruzzi-Perri, 1 A Rolfo, 2 T Todros, 2 A Logan, 3 M P Murphy, 3 D A Giussani. 1 1 University of Cambridge, Cambridge, United Kingdom; 2 University of Turin, Turin, Italy; 3 MRC Mitochondrial Biology Unit, Cambridge, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: The placenta responds to adverse environmental conditions, such as maternal glucorticoid over-exposure and dietary manipulation, by adapting its capacity for substrate transfer to maintain appropriate fetal growth and development (Fowden et al. J Neuroendocrinol 20(4):439, 2008).Comparatively little is known about placental adaptations to hypoxia and/or oxidative stress. Here, we determined the effect of maternal chronic hypoxia on placental morphology and established whether maternal treatment with MitoQ protected against hypoxia-induced alterations in placental structure. METHODS: Wistar dams were exposed to normoxia (N, 21% O 2 ) or hypoxia (H, 13% O 2 ) from days 6-20 of pregnancy +/-MitoQ (500µM in drinking water). On day 20, animals were sacrificed and weighed and the placentae were processed for stereology. One placenta per litter per group was used. This model does not affect maternal food intake. RESULTS: Neither hypoxic pregnancy or MitoQ treatment affected fetal growth (N:3.83±0.07 g; H:3.44±0.03 g; HM: 3.59±0.04 g; NM: 3.41±0.03 g). Relative to normoxia, the placental absolute volume and the labyrinthine fetal capillary surface area were significantly increased in hypoxic pregnancy [Fig. 1 A and B, P<0.05]. Maternal MitoQ treatment in hypoxic pregnancy additionally increased the maternal blood space surface area[Fig. 1C, P<0.05]. CONCLUSIONS: The data show that the placenta adapts to chronic hypoxic pregnancy of a moderate level by increasing the fetal capillary surface within the labyrinthine transport zone to maintain fetal growth. Maternal mitochondrial targeted antioxidant therapy during hypoxic pregnancy improves perfusion on the maternal side of the placenta.Trained Memory in Decidual NK Cells During Human Pregnancy. TABREF163.text: Melatonin Protects Human Placental Choriocarcinoma Cells Against Hypoxia/Reoxygenation-Induced Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER)-Stress.PhilippeWong-Yen. INRS, Laval, QC, Canada.   INTRODUCTION: Melatonin and its receptors play a crucial in placental function. This indolamine plays a protective effect against oxidative stress and mitochondrial-mediated apoptosis of the primary villous trophoblast (vTB) induced by hypoxia-reoxygenation (H/R) through maintenance of the equilibrium between pro-and anti-oxidants. Under oxidative stress situations, such as H/R, ER activates a mechanism called unfolded protein response (UPR) by the activation of PERK, ATF6, Ire1α and GRP78. However, whether H/R in the trophoblast cell activates ER-stress and if melatonin can prevent this damage has never been studied. The hypothesis is that melatonin prevents ER-stress induced by H/R in villous trophoblast. The specific objective is to determine the effect of increasing concentrations of melatonin on PERK, ATF6, Ire1α and GRP78 in villous trophoblast under H/R. mM) treatment. ER-stress related proteins, PERK, Ire1α, GRP78, CHOP and ATF4 have been analyzed by western blot. RESULTS: Results show that melatonin induced Ire1α and PERK activation in BeWo cells under H/R compared to normoxia, without induction of downstream protein CHOP which lead to apoptosis. However, GPR78 is induced by melatonin in vTB under H/R suggesting the activation of the autophagy pathways to prevent cell death. CONCLUSIONS: These finding suggested a role of melatonin in ERstress and autophagy that favor the maintenance of homeostasis of the placenta and the well-being of pregnancy. Ren-Wei Su, 1 Michael Strug, 1 Niraj Joshi, 1 Jae-Wook Jeong, 1 Eduardo Miyadahira, 2 Paulo Serafini, 2 Asgerally Fazleabas. 1 1 Michigan State University, Grand Rapids, MI, USA; 2 Faculdade de Medicina da USP, São Paulo, Brazil. TABREF180.text: DNA Methylation Profiling in Endometriosis -LaserCapture Microdissection Enables Targeted Analyses. Eva Simon, 1 Joern Toedling, 1 Juliane Hundt, 2 Maik Obendorf, 1 Ralf Lesche, 1 Kati Hasenbein, 3 Anne Kroker, 3 Thomas M Zollner. 1 1 Bayer HealthCare Pharmaceuticals, Berlin, Germany; 2 Bayer Technology Services GmbH, Leverkusen, Germany; 3 Vivantes Humboldt Hospital, Berlin, Germany. INTRODUCTION:Endometriosis is a benign estrogen dependent inflammatory condition, severely affecting women's quality of life by chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia and subfertility. Even though increasing evidence is indicating the impact of epigenetics in the development of endometriosis, the common use of tissue homogenates or cultured cells might have hampered the detection of distinct pathophysiological alterations so far.In this study we therefore aim to profile DNA methylation patterns in individual endometrial cell populations, separated by laser capture microdissection (LCM) in order to deepen our disease understanding. METHODS: For DNA methylation profiling, eutopic and ectopic endometrial specimens from patients with endometriosis as well as normal endometrium from healthy control donors were provided by the Vivantes Humboldt Hospital Berlin. The separation of epithelial and stromal endometrial cells was performed by LCM on 10 µm thick fresh frozen tissue sections. After DNA isolation and fragmentation with the restriction endonuclease MspI, bisulfite-converted libraries were produced using the NuGEN Ovation® Ultralow Methyl-Seq Library System. Potential differences in DNA methylation were subsequently examined by reduced representation bisulfite sequencing (RRBS) on the Illumina HiSeq instrument.

TABREF181.text: Lesion Specific KLF10 Levels Determine Cyst Development andDisease Progression in Endometriosis. Chandra C Shenoy, Abigail A Delaney, Ye Zheng, Zaraq Khan, Gaurang S Daftary. Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA. INTRODUCTION: Endometriosis affects 10% of reproductive aged women. Loss of KLF11 signaling causes advanced endometriotic progression and fibrosis. We identified a novel role for KLF10, a KLF11 paralog, in human endometriosis. Whereas loss of KLF11 activates Collagen1 and scarring, loss of KLF10 results in dysregulation of distinct inflammatory pathways and cystic lesions. Despite 80% homology and similar epigenetic cofactor binding domains, loss KLF10 and 11 result in two common but highly divergent disease phenotypes and offer a robust model for molecular investigation of this heterogenous disease. METHODS: Endometriosis was surgically induced in 10wk old wt or Klf10-/-mice by suturing 0.5 mm everted uterine segments to parietal peritoneum. Klf10-/-uterine segments were allografted into wt mice and v.v. Disease progression was assessed by morphometry, PCR and IHC. PCR Arrays and confirmatory gene expression studies were performed in Ishikawa cells transfected with KLF10, KLF10siRNA or controls by ChIP, PCR and WB. CD40/CD154 expression was assessed by IHC in allografted murine and human disease lesions. RESULTS: In contrast to lesion regression in wild type, Klf10-/developed cystic lesions with minimal fibrosis. Like autologously implanted Klf10-/-lesions, when Klf10-/-lesions were allografted into wt animals, the lesions were cystic. In contrast, wt lesions regressed in Klf10-/-animals. Lesion specific loss of Klf10 determined inflammation and cystic progression, which significantly was also not accompanied by fibrosis in contrast with Klf11. Whereas KLF10siRNA increased CD40 and CD154 mRNA and protein levels, both were repressed by KLF10 in Ishikawa cells. Congruently, CD154 expression was increased in Klf10-/-but not wt lesions. In humans diminished KLF10 in lesions was also associated with increased CD154 compared to corresponding ectopic endometrium. CONCLUSIONS: Lesion specific dysregulated CD40/CD154 mediated inflammation from loss of KLF10 results in endometriotic cyst formation. Despite significant inflammatory infiltrate there was minimal scarring in contrast with loss of Klf11. Endometriotic cyst and fibrosis are thus likely discrete disease progression phenotypes contributing to heterogeneity. Human disease specific genes KLF10 and KLF11 recruit epigenetic mechanisms to regulate distinct target genes. Our models offer new insight into the role of inflammation and fibrosis in chronic disease with novel translational potential.Mast Cells and Chymase: Are They Partners in Crime inPelvic Pain and Endometriosis? Bianca De Leo, 1-2 Olympia Kelepouri, 1 Frances Collins, 1 Hilary OD Critchley, 2 Andrew W Horne, 2 Philippa TK Saunders. 1 1 University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; 2 University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION:Endometriosis is a chronic, estrogen-dependent inflammatory disease. Symptoms include chronic pelvic pain linked to an aberrant inflammatory state. Immune cells may communicate with neurons to alter pain sensitivity and trigger the transition from acute to chronic pain. Mast cells (MCs) are emerging as key players in physiological and pathological pain pathways. Degranulation of MCs results in release of inflammatory molecules including the MC-specific proteases, tryptase and chymase. MC mediators can sensitize neurons and the nerves in turn release neuropeptides such as histamine that can activate MCs, resulting in a vicious cycle.

TABREF183.text: Distant Relative Pair Analysis Identifies a DNA Repair Gene POLN Associated with Familial Endometriosis. Rakesh Chetter, Hans M Albertsen, Kenneth Ward. Juneau Biosciences, Salt Lake City, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION:Genome wide association studies (GWAS) have implicated and replicated several single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) associated with endometriosis. However, GWAS studies focus on SNPs with minor allele frequencies >3%, and for many diseases the phenotypic variance explained by GWAS are modest. SNPs rare in the general population often account for missing heritability. In this study, we sequenced the exomes of 206 affected women who were distantly related pairs (meiosis 6 to 7 apart) to detect rare variants in genes likely to predispose women to endometriosis. METHODS: Paired-end WGS was performed on 206 affected women using Ion Proton Platform (Thermo Fisher). Variant analysis was performed using Ion Torrent Variant caller and validated using the best practices workflow recommended by Genome-Analysis-Tool-Kit (Broad Institute). Prediction of protein function was evaluated using seven different algorithms (Polyphen 2, sift, Mutation Accessor, Mutation Taster, FATHMM,LRT, MetaLR). We examined damaging rare variants (ExAc MAF <0.03, and predicted to be damaging in at least 1 prediction algorithm). RESULTS: WGS was accomplished with a 100-fold mean coverage. We identified ~17,000 exome variants per individual and 2,811 rare exonic variants shared at least by a single relative pair. 227 rare variants were predicted to be damaging. 20 variants were shared by at least 5 distant relative affected pairs. We looked for association of these 20 variants in exome sequencing database of 860 unrelated endometriosis subjects. The genes showing association p<0.05 are shown inTable 1. Two other damaging missense variants in POLN (p.R485Q and p.R406G) showed association with endometriosis. CONCLUSIONS: Through distant relative pair analysis and exome sequencing, we have identified POLN as an endometriosis predisposition gene. POLN is the first DNA repair gene associated with endometriosis. POLN is expressed in endometrium and is implicated in prostate and ovarian cancer, but it does not have a known role in endometriosis.Impact of Psychological Stress on Pain Perception in an AnimalModel of Endometriosis. Siomara Hernandez, 1 Myrella L Cruz, 1 Inevy Seguinot, 1 Mayra I Gonzalez, 2 Abdon Lopez, 2 Annelyn Torres-Reveron, 1 Caroline B Appleyard. 1 1 Ponce Health Sciences University, Ponce, Puerto Rico; 2 University of Puerto Rico in Ponce, Ponce, Puerto Rico. INTRODUCTION: Symptoms of pain and infertility in endometriosis patients are considered significant sources of stress.We have recently demonstrated that stress can worsen the condition in a rat model of endometriosis, however the impact of stress on the sensitivity to pain in this condition has not been investigated. Our aim was to determine the effects of a psychological stress protocol on pain thresholds. METHODS: Endometriosis was induced in female rats by suturing uterine horn tissue next to the intestinal mesentery. Sham rats had sutures only. The stress protocol consisted of placing the rat on a platform (11cm x 10cm) in a plastic container (40.6cm x 40.6cm) with 25°C water up to 1 cm below the platform for 1 hour for 7 consecutive days. Fecal pellets (FPC) and corticosterone (CORT) levels were measured. Changes in pain perception were assessed using the hot plate test for hyperalgesia and Von Frey test for allodynia. Mu opioid receptor (MOR), neurokinin-1 receptor (NK-1R), and substance P (Sub P) expression in the spinal cord was measured by immunohistochemistry. At time of sacrifice tissues were collected and vesicles measured.RESULTS:The endo stress (ES) group had higher anxiety levels (FPC and CORT) than endo no stress (ENS) (p<0.01) and sham no stress (SNS) (p<0.01). ES rats had higher inflammation when compared to the SNS (colonic damage: p<0.001) and ENS (colonic damage: p<0.05; mast cells in vesicles: p<0.01). Vesicles in ES animals were larger and more severe than in ENS. Both endo groups developed hyperalgesia reaching significance in the ES (p<0.05), but stress reversed the allodynic effect caused by endo (p<0.001). MOR expression was significantly reduced in ENS versus SNS (p<0.05), and stress did not significantly alter this. No effects were found between groups for NK-1R and Sub P expression. CONCLUSIONS: Our findings parallel our previous studies showing that animals subjected to stress develop more severe symptoms. Interestingly stress seems to have beneficial effects on allodynia which could be a consequence of the stress induced analgesia phenomenon. Further studies are needed to understand physiologically how pain perception is altered in this disease and which pathways are involved.Supported in part by R25GM096955 & R25GM082406 Endometrial Gene Expression Analysis of Genes Found to Be Associated with Endometriosis by GWAS. Luca Pagliardini, 1 Ana Maria Sanchez, 1 Alessio Paffoni, 2 Edgardo Somigliana, 2 Umberto Leone Roberti Maggiore, 3 Simone Ferrero, 3 Massimo Candiani, 1 Paola Vigano'. 1 1 IRCCS San Raffaele Scientific Institute, Milan, Italy; 2 Fondazione Cà Granda, Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico, Milan, Italy; 3 Ospedale San Martino, Università degli Studi, Genova, Italy. INTRODUCTION: A series of genome wide association study (GWAS)

TABREF184.text: Production in Endometriosis: The Roles of NR5A1 and GATA6. Lia Bernardi, Christia Sison, Serdar Bulun, Matthew Dyson. Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA. INTRODUCTION: NR5A1 and GATA6 regulate steroid biosynthesis in steroidogenic tissues.We have previously demonstrated that both of these transcription factors are expressed in endometriotic tissue and drive steroidogenic gene expression in certain cell types. As the pathoprogression of endometriosis ultimately depends on estradiol (E2), we hypothesize that NR5A1 and GATA6 also drive E2 production seen in endometriosis. To test this, NR5A1 and GATA6 were silenced in endometriotic stromal fibroblasts (OSIS) and transduced into normal endometrial stromal cells (NoEM), human foreskin fibroblast cells (BJ), or mouse embryonic fibroblasts (NIH/3T3). METHODS: OSIS were obtained from endometriotic cysts and NoEM were acquired from the endometrium of women without endometriosis. BJ and NIH/3T3 cells were obtained from ATCC. NR5A1 and GATA6 were depleted in OSIS by transfecting gene-specific siRNAs. Overexpression in NoEM, BJ, and NIH/3T3 was accomplished by transducing adenoviruses bearing species-specific, CMV-driven NR5A1 and GATA6. Enzyme immunoassays were performed to assess E2 production. Steroidogenic gene expression was evaluated in NIH/3T3 using qPCR and immunoblotting. RESULTS: Concordant with reduced steroidogenic gene expression, E2 production in OSIS decreased from 59.7 pg/mL in controls to 41.7 pg/ mL with NR5A1 silencing (p=0.04). E2 synthesis was further suppressed to 23.2 pg/mL when both NR5A1 and GATA6 were silenced (p=0.005). NR5A1 expression in NoEM generated a nonsignificant increase in E2 production (42.9 pg/mL versus baseline of 17.5 pg/mL). Combined expression of NR5A1 and GATA6 significantly increased E2 synthesis to 260.6 ng/mL (p=0.003). Although steroidogenic genes were induced in BJ cells in response to NR5A1 and GATA6, there was no detectable E2 synthesis. In NIH/3T3, NR5A1 and GATA6 elicited little change in steroidogenic gene expression. CONCLUSIONS: NR5A1 and GATA6 contribute toward E2 synthesis in endometriosis. E2 production was dependent upon both transcription factors, as depletion compromised steroidogenesis in OSIS. This observation was complemented in NoEM, where NR5A1 and GATA6 worked synergistically to produce the highest levels of E2. In contrast, NR5A1 and GATA6 did not drive E2 synthesis in BJ cells, despite detectable levels of the steroidogenic enzymes. NIH/3T3 cells appeared refractory to developing any steroidogenic potential. Studies addressing the differentiation cues inducing NR5A1 and GATA6 will provide insight into novel treatments for the disease.Physical & Mental Health Components of Health Related Quality of Life (HRQL) and Health State Utilities (HSU) for Uterine Fibroids (UF) Patients in the United States (US). Ahmed M Soliman, 1 Karin Coyne, 2 Mary Kay Margolis, 2 Jane Castelli-Haley, 1 Michael Snabes, 3 Craig Winkel. 4 1 AbbVie Inc., Chicago, IL, USA; 2 Evidera Inc., Bethesda, MD, USA; 3 AbbVie Inc., Chicago, IL, USA; 4 Georgetown University, Washington, DC, USA. INTRODUCTION: UF is associated with significant impact on HRQL.This analysis assessed the HRQL (physical and mental health) and health state utilities (HSU) among UF patients in the US. METHODS: An online survey was conducted among US women aged 18-54. Women who reported UF diagnosis or UF-related symptoms in prevalence screening completed a main survey which assessed multiple aspects of HRQL; SF-12 ® was used to compute physical and mental component scores (PCS & MCS; national average score is 50) and EQ-5D-5L ® was used to derive HSU (range:0-1). Analysis excluded women who had hysterectomy. ANOVA was used to examine the impact of UF self-reported severity and UF-related symptoms (heavy menstrual bleeding, excessive or irregular bleeding, passage of clots, pelvic pressure & bloating) co-occurrence on HRQL and HSU. RESULTS: A total of 59,411 women completed the prevalence screener; 5,879 completed the main survey. SF-12 analysis sample included 1,397 UF women. Mean age was 42.8 years. Mean PCS and MCS scores were 49.7 and 43.6 respectively . Women reporting their overall UF symptoms as severe had significantly lower PCS and MCS scores compared to women reporting moderate or mild symptoms (PCS: 41.1, 48.7 and 51.7; MCS: 36.7, 40.9 and 46.2; respectively all p<0.01). PCS and MCS scores decreased as the number of co-occurring UF-related symptoms increased . HSU analysis included 1,244 women with UF. Mean HSU were 0.81. Women with overall self-reported severe UF symptoms had significantly lower estimated HSU compared to women reporting moderate or mild UF symptoms (0.65, 0.79 and 0.85, p<0.01). HSU among women with UF deteriorated as the number of UF-related symptoms increased. CONCLUSIONS: UF are associated with significant impairment in HRQL and HSU that increase with increasing disease severity and symptoms co-occurrence. Symptom improvement could result in improving overall HRQL of women with UF.Therapeutic Use of Ulipristal to Inhibit Leiomyoma Growth Inhibits Smooth Muscle Contractile Protein Expression in Surgical Samples.William H Catherino, 1,2 Jeris Cox, 1,2 Minnie Malik, 1 Joy Britten, 1 Lynnette Nieman. 2 1 Uniformed Services University, Bethesda, MD, USA; 2 National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, NIH, Bethesda, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: Uterine leiomyomas are highly prevalent and symptomatic, resulting in substantial maternal and fetal morbidity. Ulipristal acetate treatment, in clinical trials, results in decreased leiomyoma size and symptoms. However, the mechanism of this compound remains unclear. We have obtained hysterectomy specimens from a clinical trial after treatment with ulipristal or placebo for 12 weeks, and have demonstrated alterations in extracellular matrix. We hypothesize that ulipristal alters excessive and aberrant intracellular, contractile smooth muscle proteins. METHODS: Genome-wide quantitative screening via RNAseq, followed by confirmatory qRT-PCR. Additional confirmatory tests were performed using human immortalized leiomyoma cells in vitro.

Marcus Schultze-Mosgau, 1 Joachim Hochel, 1 Olaf Prien, 2 Torsten Zimmermann, 3 Ashley Brooks, 4 Antje Rottmann. 2 1 Bayer Pharma AG, Berlin, Germany; 2 Bayer Pharma AG, Berlin, Germany; 3 Bayer Pharma AG, Berlin, Germany; 4 Clinical Research Unit, Leeds, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: Vilaprisan (BAY1002670)is a selective progesterone receptor modulator that markedly reduced the growth of human leiomyoma tissue in a preclinical model of uterine fibroids. The objectives of this phase 1 study were to investigate the metabolism, excretion pattern and mass balance of vilaprisan in women. Safety and tolerability were also assessed.

TABREF186.text: Do Steroid Hormones Regulate a Kinase Anchoring Protein 13, AKAP13, Expression in Fibroid Cells? Farah S Chuong, 1 Chantel I Washington, 1 Paul H Driggers, 1 Minnie Malik, 2 James H Segars. 1 1 Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD, USA; 2 Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, Bethesda, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: Sex steroid hormones, estrogen (E) and progesterone (P), play a critical role in regulating growth and development of uterine fibroids. Fibroids have an altered extracellular matrix, which can cause increased mechanical stress leading to activation of Rho-dependent signaling and cytoskeletal rearrangement. We have previously shown that AKAP13, a scaffolding protein that activates Rho-dependent signaling, is differentially expressed in fibroid cells versus myometrial cell controls. AKAP13 binds specifically to estrogen receptors (ERα and ERβ) and progesterone receptor B (PR-B) in vitro and augments both PR and ERdependent reporter activity in transfected cells. Given this interaction, we evaluated whether AKAP13 gene expression in fibroid tissue is subject to regulation by ovarian steroid hormones. METHODS: Immortalized leiomyoma cells were treated with E or P for 24 hours. RNA was then isolated and used as a template for generation of complementary DNA (cDNA). Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reactions (qRT-PCR) were performed. All values of the target genes were normalized to the expression of the reference genes glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) and 18S ribosomal RNAs. The immortalized leiomyoma cells were transfected with AKAP13 expression vector and analyzed for a change in PR-B message. RESULTS: We observed a significant increase in AKAP13 gene expression with the 24-hours of E exposure (p<0.05) that was not observed after P exposure. Through AKAP13 transfection we were unable to detect a difference in PR-B message. CONCLUSIONS: These data suggest that E induces AKAP13 in a feedforward mechanism affecting E action. The increased P responsive gene activity previously noted does not appear to be caused by increased PR-B message in the presence AKAP13. AKAP13's involvement in both Rho signaling and steroid hormone response makes it a plausible integrator of mechanical stress and hormonal signaling. We postulate that the increased expression of AKAP13 noted in fibroid cells results from both an altered state of mechanical homeostasis as well as hormonal regulation.Vitamin D Deficiency Induces an Overactive Bladder SyndromePhenotype in a Novel Murine Model. Mohamed Abdelaziz, 1 Noura Eziba, 1 Paul O'Connor, 1 Nahed Ismail, 2 Michael Diamond, 1 Ayman Al-Hendy. 1 1 Georgia Regents University, Augusta, GA, USA; 2 University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Overactive bladder syndrome (OBS) is a common health problem. This syndrome shares epidemiological and pathophysiological features with preterm birth. Our recently published work suggested that vitamin D deficiency is a risk factor for preterm birth(Thota et. al., 2013). Recent studies have documented the expression of vitamin D receptors in human bladder. We hypothesize that vitamin D deficiency is a risk factor for OBS, leading to a heightened inflammatory microenvironment in the bladder wall leading to hyper-excitability of detrusor muscle cells. METHODS: Weight matched 4-6 wk-old C57BL/6 female mice were either raised on normal diet (n = 10) or vitamin D-deficient diet (n = 10) for 8 weeks. Then mice undergone cystometry & the following parameters recorded: Filling pressure, threshold pressure, presence of non-voiding bladder contractions (NVBC) & bladder capacity. Then animals were euthanized. Blood was collected at time of euthanasia. Bladder samples undergone H&E and Immunohistochemistry for proliferation markers (Ki67, PCNA & TGF beta), inflammatory cell markers (CD69, CD3, FOXP3 & CD11b), and contractility related markers (Connexin 43, COX 2 & NF-Kb). Statistical analysis done using Student's T test. RESULTS: We confirmed hypovitaminosis D status by measuring serum 25-OH vitamin D (23±1.78 ng/mL in vitamin D deficient group vs 62±2.63 ng/mL in control group, P=0.01). In deficient group versus control, we observed significant increase in filling pressure (5.8±0.7 vs 1.6±0.8 cm H 2 O, P= 0.03) as well as significant decrease in bladder capacity (153±28 vs 266±22 microL, P=0.01). We also identified presence of premature NVBC in deficient group which was totally absent in control group. H&E shows significant increase in thickness of detrusor muscle in deficient group by 32±3.73% (P=0.02). IHC showed significant increase in expression of proliferation markers 'PCNA, Ki-67 & TGF beta', inflammatory markers (CD69, CD3, FOXP3 & CD11b) and contractility related markers (Connexin 43, COX 2 & NF-Kb) in deficient group (P<0.05). CONCLUSIONS: Our results suggest that vitamin D deficiency was associated with decreased bladder compliance, development of detrusor overactivity and increased detrusor proliferation. Vitamin D deficiency might be a novel OBS risk factor. Vitamin D and its analogues could present a new family for possible treatment of OBS.Low Impact of Vaginal or Buccal Misoprostol on Mucosal and Systemic Immune Activation and the CervicovaginalMicrobiome. Spyros A Kalams, 1 Lisa M Rogers, 1 Rita M Smith, 1 Louise Barnett, 1 Katie Crumbo, 1 Shonda Sumner, 1 Naomi Prashad, 1 Kyle Rybczyk, 1 Ginger L Milne, 1 Scot E Dowd, 2 Erica Chong, 3 Beverly Winikoff, 3 David M Aronoff. 1 1 Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, USA; 2 MR DNA (Molecular Research), Shallowater, TX, USA; 3 Gynuity Health Projects, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION:Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin (PG) E 1 analogue. It is used to prevent post-partum hemorrhage, induce labor in term pregnancies, and terminate pregnancies. Misoprostol has immunomodulatory effects. It is typically administered orally, buccally, or vaginally. Vaginal misoprostol has garnered controversy because of concerns that the drug increases the susceptibility of women to infections of the reproductive tract following its use. We sought to test the null hypothesis that single-dose misoprostol alters neither mucosal nor systemic immune responses, regardless of the route of administration METHODS: Prospective, cross-over, pilot study of 15 healthy, reproductive age women. Women received 800 ug of misoprostol either via buccal or vaginal administration and were crossed over one month later to receive the drug via the other route. Cervicovaginal lavage (CVL) samples, cervical cytobrush samples, cervicovaginal swabs, urine, and blood were obtained immediately prior to drug administration and 24 hours later. Parameters assessed included urine and cervicovaginal misoprostol levels, whole blood cytokine responses (by ELISA) to immune stimulation, peripheral blood and cervical lymphocyte phenotyping by flow cytometry, cervicovaginal antimicrobial peptide measurement by ELISA, and cervicovaginal microbial ecology assessment by 16S rRNA sequencing. RESULTS: Misoprostol was well tolerated and cleared from subjects within 1 day of administration. Neither buccal nor vaginal misoprostol significantly altered the local or systemic innate or adaptive immune responses measured in this study. Misoprostol did not appear to alter the vaginal microbiome. CONCLUSIONS: These results do not identify major immunomodulatory roles for buccal or vaginal single-dose misoprostol in healthy, reproductive age women. This study was supported by a grant to Gynuity Health Projects from an anonymous donor.Lactobacillus Crispatus Protects Vaginal Epithelial Cells fromLeptotrichia Amnionii-Induced Damage. Caroline Mitchell, Nidhi Gaur, Anuj Kalsy. Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Leptotrichia amnionii (LA) is a gram negative, anaerobic species associated with increased preterm birth, stillbirth, and neonatal meningitis. Lactobacillus species have been associated with decreased rates of these complications. METHODS: Immortalized human vaginal epithelial cells (VK2) were cultured anaerobically with live or heat-killed (HK) Lactobacillus crispatus (LC) or LA alone or in combination for 24 hours. VK2 and bacterial numbers and viability were evaluated at 24 hours. Bacterial adherence was measured by plating VK2 cell suspension on appropriate agar after PBS wash. ELISA for IL6 and IL8 was performed on culture supernatant. Results were compared between treatment conditions using ANOVA with Dunnett's multiple comparison test. RESULTS: After culture with live LA VK2 cell numbers were significantly reduced compared to culture with no bacteria or with LC, though 95% of remaining cells were viable. *Figure(s) will be available online. When live LC was combined with LA this cell loss was attenuated. With HK bacteria, these effects were not seen. No differences in number of LA were seen whether cultured alone or with LC (4.8 x 10 6 vs. 4.2 x 10 6 cfu; p = 0.95) Levels of IL8 were significantly elevated after co-culture with live or HK LA *Figure(s) will be available online. but this was attenuated by co-culture with live or HK LC. A similar trend was seen for IL6 (data not shown). Co-culture with LC reduced the number of adherent LA by 41 ± 3% (p = 0.02). CONCLUSIONS: Live LC inhibits vaginal epithelial cells loss due to LA and attenuates the epithelial immune response. This may be via competitive binding to the cell surface, but is not due to direct killing of LA.The S100A8 Concentration in Sera Prior to Initiation of an In Vitro Fertilization (IVF) Cycle Predicts Subsequent Outcome. INTRODUCTION: The autoimmune disorder Multiple Sclerosis (MS) ameliorates during pregnancy. The mechanisms for this are unclear, but some have hypothesized that maternal-fetal interaction may play a role.During normal pregnancy, bidirectional transplacental exchange of cells and subcellular material occurs between mother and fetus, establishing microchimerism (Mc). We sought to evaluate circulating fetal Mc (FMc) in pregnancies complicated by MS, evaluating overall whole blood (WB) and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC). METHODS: Maternal blood samples (n=40) were collected longitudinally from patients (n=8) with MS and confirmed full-term delivery (prepregnancy, 1 st , 2 nd , and 3 rd trimester, delivery, and postpartum). Cord blood was collected at delivery, or if not available, offspring buccal swabs were obtained. Maternal DNA was extracted from WB and Ficollpurified PBMC. Maternal and fetal genotyping was conducted, and FMc was quantified with quantitative polymerase chain reaction assays targeting fetal-specific nonshared polymorphisms. Prevalence of FMc was compared in WB and PBMC. RESULTS: Overall detection of FMc was higher in WB than in PBMC (43% vs 9%, p=0.003) and this relationship persisted as gestation progressed. Although a limited sample size, our analysis suggests a possible reversal of this relationship in the postpartum period where FMc was more readily detectable in PBMC than WB (20% vs 0%).CONCLUSIONS:Our data demonstrate that in pregnancies complicated by MS, FMc was commonly detectable and found more often in WB compared to PBMC. This difference may reflect cell-free FMc or FMc in cells other than PBMC, such as granulocytes. Further studies are warranted to determine the phenotype of FMc, to evaluate whether detection correlates with MS amelioration in pregnancy, and to delineate any potential mechanistic relationship.Reconstruction of the Human EndometriumUsing Decellularized Uterine Tissues. TABREF188.text: Regulation of Oocyte DNA Methylation: Can Insulin and Its Terminal Enzyme Glycogen Synthase Kinase 3 (GSK3) Be Involved? MichaelBalistreri, Gary Smith. University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA. INTRODUCTION: 1. Characterize the expression of methylation regulatory enzymes, DNA methyl transferases (DNMTs) and teneleven translocation (TETs) enzymes, in murine oocytes during growth, acquisition of meiotic competence, and in response to exogenous gonadotropins. 2. Determine if insulin's terminal enzyme, glycogen synthase kinase 3 (GSK3), regulates DNMTs/TETSs expression. METHODS: Growing meiotic incompetent and fully grown meiotic competent murine germinal vesicle intact oocytes were collected with and without ovarian stimulation with pregnant mare serum gonadotropins (PMSG) and expression levels of 5 DNMTs and 3 TET's were determined by Q-PCR. Two murine embryonic stem cell (mESC) lines were treated with either control solutions containing i) phosphate buffer saline (PBS), ii) Leukemia Inhibiting Factor (LIF), iii) DMSO (vehicle control) or the GSK3 inhibitors iv) Lithium chloride (LiCl), or v) Alsterpaullone (Alster). LiCl and Alster simulate hyperinsulinemia which results in GSK3 inhibition. Cells were collected after 15 days and Q-PCR was performed to measure the quantity of mRNA. ANOVA and pairwise comparisons by unpaired Student t-test were used in the analysis. RESULTS: All DNMT transcripts (1o, 1s, 3a, 3b, 3l) and all TET mRNAs (1, 2, 3) analyzed were expressed in murine oocytes. During oocyte growth and acquisition of meiotic competence DNMT1o & 1s expression increased while DNMT3a & 3l remained constant and DNMT3b was significantly reduced. As oocyte gained meiotic competence TET1 expression significantly decreased, while TET2 & 3 expression remained constant. In fully grown meiotic competent oocytes, pretreatment with gonadotropin, caused a significant increase in DNMT1s, no change in DNMT1o & 3a, and a significant reduction in DNMT3b & 3l. In the same oocyte group, pretreatment with PMSG had no effect on TET1 & 2 expression, whereas it induced a significant decrease in TET3 expression. Treatment of mESCs for 15 days with inhibitors of GSK3 (LiCl & Alster) had no influence on expression of DNMT3a, 3b, 3l, or 1s. In the same study, GSK3 inhibitors had no effect on TET1, 2, or 3 expression. CONCLUSIONS: DNA methylation enzymes are present in murine oocytes, change in expression during oocyte growth/acquisition of meiotic competence, and can be influenced by exogenous gonadotropins. Future experiments will address the role of prolonged elevated insulin, oocyte GSK3, and regulation of enzymes that regulate DNA methylation, epigenetics and imprinting.Obese Women Experience Impaired Endometrial ReceptivityIn Vitro Compared to Lean Women. Maureen MB Schulte, Jui-He Tsai, Kelle H Moley. Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, MO, USA. INTRODUCTION:Defective endometrial receptivity can lead to infertility and miscarriage. Obese women (BMI ≥ 30) are three times more likely to suffer infertility than women with a normal BMI. The objective of this study was to investigate the difference in endometrial receptivity between normo-ovulatory lean and obese women. METHODS: Normo-ovulatory women with regular menses and proven fertility were consented. They underwent an endometrial biopsy, patients with BMI ≥ 30 were considered obese and BMI ≤ 25 were considered lean. Endometrial decidualization was induced by exposing endometrial stromal cells to 1mM medroxyprogesterone acetate and 0.5 mM cAMP for nine days. The mRNA expression levels of known markers of endometrial decidualization; prolactin and IGFBP1, were measured by quantitative RT-PCR. The fold change in gene expression between non-decidualized and decidualized samples was calculated. Students T-test was used for statistical analysis to stratify endometrial decidualization by BMI. RESULTS: The fold change in gene expression of markers of endometrial decidualization prolactin and IGFBP1 exhibit a statistically significant decrease in obese patients as compared to lean. Recent studies suggest that endometrial disturbances in PCOS patients are distinct from those in obese women. Here, we are presenting data that confirms that obesity alone perturbs endometrial receptivity.CONCLUSIONS:By controlling the in vitro hormonal environment and measuring markers of endometrial decidualization we found that obese women have endometrial stromal cells that have reduced ability to undergo normal decidualization.Cigarette Smoking AffectsUterine Receptivity. Gulcin Sahin Ersoy, 1 Yuping Zhou, 1 Hamdi A Inan, 2 Cuneyt E Taner, 2 Hugh S Taylor. 1 1 Yale University School of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA; 2 Tepecik Education and Research Hospital, Izmir, Turkey. INTRODUCTION: Smoking is known to have negative reproductive consequences. Smokers undergoing IVF cycles have a lower implantation rate than non-smokers after adjusting for embryos quality. This suggests that altered uterine receptiveness may be a factor in infertile smoker women.

TABREF189.text: Cell-Derived Factor-1 Expression by Endometrial StromalCells In Vitro Increases with Incubation Time. Emily C Holden, Banafsheh N Kashani, Andrea Wojtczuk, Sara Morelli, Laura T Goldsmith. Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Newark, NJ, USA. INTRODUCTION: Stromal Cell-Derived Factor-1 (SDF-1/CXCL12) is an important angiogenic, proliferative and chemotactic factor produced by human endometrial stromal cells. Prior studies have shown inconsistent expression patterns in endometrial tissue during the menstrual cycle. Thus, understanding of the regulation of endometrial CXCL12 expression requires reproducible in vitro studies. Several laboratories have reported that levels of CXCL12 in medium from cultured endometrial stromal cells are undetectable. However, these studies have generally used relatively short incubation time periods. Our prior data suggest that CXCL12 levels from cultured endometrial cells are fairly abundant after extended culture time periods. We tested the hypothesis that endometrial stromal CXCL12 expression increases with time of incubation, independent of cell differentiation. METHODS: A well characterized line of immortalized human endometrial stromal cells was used. In each experiment, replicate wells of cells, plated at 1 x 10 5 cells per well in 24 well tissue culture plates, were incubated in phenol red-free medium supplemented with stripped serum, for various time periods up to 16 days. At the end of each incubation time period, cell morphology was assessed under phase contrast microscopy, cell numbers in each well were determined and CXCL12 levels in conditioned medium from each well were measured using a human CXCL12 specific ELISA. Medium levels of CXCL12 at each time point are expressed normalized to cell number. Increased production of endometrial stromal CXCL12 during extended duration of culture is independent of cell differentiation and associated with increased cell proliferation. These findings suggest autocrine regulation of endometrial stromal CXCL12 expression.Does Insulin Resistance Correlate with Changes in the EndometrialTranscriptome by the Endometrial Receptivity Array? TABREF195.text: and Turner Syndrome -SNP Array Analysis of Three Women with 45,X and Preserved Fertility. Nicole K Banks, 1, 2 Paul S Kruszka, 1 Frank X Donovan, 1 Yonit A Addissie, 1 Ariel F Martinez, 1 Rachel Hart, 1 Alan H DeCherney, 2 James H Segars, 3 Carolyn Bondy, 2 Maximilian Muenke. 1 1 NIH, Bethesda, MD, USA; 2 NIH, Bethesda, MD, USA; 3 Johns Hopkins, Baltimore, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION:Turner syndrome (TS) is due to partial or complete loss of the second sex chromosome and affects 1 in 2500 live-born females. Half of TS females have a 45,X karyotype, while the remainder demonstrate mosaicism or structural abnormalities of the second sex chromosome. In TS, normal ovarian development occurs in the fetus, but accelerated follicular atresia leads to gonadal dysgenesis and infertility. Our objective is to analyze single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) arrays for three apparently non-mosaic fertile TS females to determine if low level mosaicism or copy number variations (CNV) may contribute to preserved fertility. METHODS: Five women were identified as non-mosaic TS with 200 cell peripheral blood karyotype with spontaneous pregnancy through the National Institutes of Health. Three underwent OmniExpressExome_ v1.2-A SNP Array and analysis with CNVPartition v3.2 (Illumina) and Nexus Copy Number v.7.5 (Biodiscovery) to evaluate for low-level mosaicism or microdeletions/duplications that may explain preserved fertility. RESULTS: No occult mosaicism was detected on Log R ratio or B allele plot. In total, 32 deletions and 14 duplications were found. There were no CNVs involving genes known to cause premature ovarian insufficiency (catalogued in the Clinical Genomic Database, http://research.nhgri.nih. gov/CGD/). One 56-kilobase deletion was detected on the X chromosome, involving the intronic portion of DMD. No other sex chromosome CNVs were seen. CONCLUSIONS: Mosaicism in peripheral blood was not detected in this small case series of women with monosomy X and preserved fertility. Additionally, microduplication of the X chromosome was not present. CNVs detected were not disease causing and unlikely to contribute to fertility protection. The presence of mosaicism in other tissues, such as the ovaries, cannot be excluded.

We hypothesize that hepatic liver disease manifested by elevated bile acids will have abnormally elevated fetal left ventricular Tei indices. TABREF383.text: Random-Start In Vitro Fertilization Protocols Have EquivalentOutcomes to Cycle-Specific Protocols, But May Not Shorten Time to Cancer Treatment. Molly B Moravek, 1 Angela K Lawson, 2 Rafael Confino, 2 Kristin N Smith, 2 Ralph R Kazer, 2 Susan C Klock, 2 Mary Ellen Pavone. 2 1 University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; 2 Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA. INTRODUCTION: Initiating in vitro fertilization (IVF) cycles in fertility preservation (FP) patients regardless of menstrual cycle phase, a "randomstart" (RS) protocol, has been proposed in order to decrease the time to cancer treatment, but has not been thoroughly studied. We hypothesized that RS protocols would have the same cycle outcome as conventional, cycle-specific (CS) protocols, and would decrease the time from fertility preservation consultation to initiation of cancer treatment. METHODS: A retrospective chart review was performed on all patients undergoing IVF for FP at Northwestern University from 2006-2012. Outcomes from RS protocols compared to CS protocols, including days of stimulation, peak estradiol levels, total oocytes retrieved, mature oocytes, and days between fertility preservation referral and beginning cancer treatment (surgery or chemotherapy), were analyzed using student's t-test. RESULTS: A total of 95 FP patients were included, with 14 in the RS group and 81 in CS group. Mean age was 31 years in both groups. RS protocols resulted in significantly higher peak estradiol levels than in CS protocols (1744 vs 1434 pcg/mL, p<0.01), but there was no significant difference in number of oocytes retrieved (13 vs 12), mature oocytes (11 vs 9), or days of stimulation (11 days in both groups). There was also no difference in the number of days from initial patient consultation to commencement of cancer treatment (44 vs 45 days). CONCLUSIONS: RS cycles result in similar oocyte yield as CS cycles in FP patients, and it is unnecessary to await menses to initiate stimulation. Interestingly, RS protocols may not significantly shorten the time from fertility preservation referral to initiation of cancer treatment, as previously proposed, suggesting there may be other factors resulting in delay.A Highly Specific Molecular Bioimaging Approach for Diagnosis of Human Uterine Leiomyosarcoma. Mostafa K Khater, 1 Shahinaz M Shalaby, 1,2 Ayman A Al-Hendy. 1 1 Georgia Regents University, Augusta, GA, USA; 2 Tanta Medical School, Tanta, Egypt. INTRODUCTION: Uterine Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) is a highly aggressive malignant tumor developing in the uterine smooth muscle. LMS is associated with poor prognosis with 5-year overall survival rates (2-9%).FDA recently estimated that 1:352 women undergoing a surgery for benign leiomyomas may have unsuspected sarcoma. Leiomyosarcoma can't be pre-operatively diagnosed with sufficient certainty & accuracy. No LMS specific imaging characteristics are available, nor reliable biomarkers. The FDA discouraged the use of power morcellation for hysterectomy & myomectomy in women with a uterine mass,for the potential risk of disseminatiing occult uterine cancers;highlighting the need for better diagnostics for LMS.

TABREF384.text: Induces a Genotype Switch in Key Antioxidant Enzymes: A Potential Mechanism of Chemoresistance in EpithelialOvarian Cancer Cells. Nicole M Fletcher, 1 Jimmy Belotte, 1 Mohammed G Saed, 1 Mohammed S Abusamaan, 1 Michael P Diamond, 2 Ghassan M Saed. 1 1 Wayne State Univeristy, Detroit, MI, USA; 2 Georgia Regents University, Augusta, GA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Despite significant advances in surgery, radiation therapy, and anticancer treatment, chemotherapy resistance remains a major obstacle to improving ovarian cancer patient outcome. The genetic component of ovarian cancer risk may be attributed to single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) that result in point mutations in the gene, and altered protein function. We hypothesized that treatment of epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) cells with clinically approved chemotherapeutic drugs could induce a genotype switch in key antioxidant enzymes altering their activity. METHODS: DNA from human EOC cell lines (MDAH-2774 and SKOV-3) and their cisplatin or taxotere chemoresistant counterparts was evaluated by TaqMan® SNP Genotype analysis for SNPs rs1001179 (catalase (CAT)), rs1002149 (glutathione reductase (GSR)), rs3448 (glutathione peroxidase (GPX1)), and rs4880 (superoxide dismutase (MnSOD)) utilizing the QuantStudio 12K Flex Real-Time PCR System. Corresponding enzymatic activity and mRNA levels were determined utilizing both ELISAs and real-time RT-PCR. Data were analyzed using SPSS 15.0 for Windows with independent sample t-tests for sensitive EOC cells as compared to their chemoresistant counterparts. Statistical significance of p<0.05 is considered significant for all analyses. RESULTS: There was no SNP for CAT, GSR, or MnSOD in either chemosensitive EOC cell line. Interestingly, the GPX1 SNP was present in both chemosensitive EOC cell lines. Upon the acquisition of chemoresistance to taxotere or cisplatin, there was a SNP in MnSOD in both cell lines. Additionally, the GPX1 SNP present in sensitive EOC cells was switched to the normal GPX1 genotype in chemoresistant EOC cells. There was no SNP present in either GSR or CAT in both chemoresistant EOC cell lines. The mRNA levels of GPX1 and CAT were significantly increased while GSR and SOD3 were significantly decreased in chemoresistant as compared to chemosensitive EOC cells (p<0.05). The activity of GPX, GSR and SOD were significantly decreased while the activity of CAT was significantly increased in chemoresistant as compared to chemosensitive EOC cells (p<0.05). CONCLUSIONS: Exposure of EOC cells to chemotherapy leads to a genotype switch in key antioxidant enzymes, which may serve as a mechanism of chemoresistance in ovarian cancer.MicroRNA let-7c Contributes to Acquired Resistance to Paclitaxel inEndometrial Serous Carcinoma. Izumi Sato, 1 Yoh Watanabe, 1 Fumihiko Suzuki, 1 Satoru Nagase, 2 Nobuo Yaegashi. 1 1 Tohoku University Hospital, Sendai, Japan; 2 Yamagata University Hospital, Yamagata, Japan. INTRODUCTION: Endometrial serous carcinoma (ESC) is a rare phenotype of endometrial carcinoma known for the poorest prognosis in gynecological cancers. One of the reasons of miserable clinical course of ESC is acquired chemo-resistance, because there are few choices of chemo-agent. Thus, the objective of this study is to investigate mechanisms of paclitaxel resistance from the aspect of microRNA (miRNA). METHODS: ESC cell line USPC1 and paclitaxel (PTX) resistant cell line (USPC1/PTX-R) derived in our laboratory were used. Expression of let-7c was examined by qRT-PCR in drug resistant cells and compared with their parental cell. Alteration of drug-resistance was analyzed after let-7c precursor transfection. Moreover we searched for the possible target of let-7c including HMGA2, Bcl-xl and other candidate.RESULTS:The expression of let-7c was decreased in USPC1/PTX-R. After let-7c precursor transfection to USPC1/PTX-R, the decreased resistance for PTX was observed compared with negative control. CONCLUSIONS: Let-7c contributes acquired resistance to PTX in ESC.Transferrin in Follicular FluidCan Facilitate DNA Double-Strand Breaks to Fallopian Tube Epithelium: Possible Involvement of Transferrin in the Carcinogenesis of High-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer. DNA double-strand breaks (DNA-DSBs) is considered to be involved in the carcinogenic change at FTE. Iron ion is known to catalyzes a Fenton reaction resulting in inducing oxidative stress. Focusing on the transferrin as an iron ion transporter, we have reported that transferrin-transferrin receptor 1 axis facilitated DNA-DSBs to the cells in vitro at the previous meeting. Further,

TABREF386.text: Valproic Acid and Human Amniotic Fluid Derived Cells: A Model for Mechanistic Studies. Margaret Dziadosz, Michael Chan, RossBasch, Bruce K Young. New York University Langone Medical Center, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: Human amniotic fluid contains a heterogeneous population of cells that carry surface markers and transcription factors resembling embryonic cells and can induce to all germ layers. We investigated effects of valproic acid (VPA), a known teratogen, on amniotic fluid cells (AFC) in culture. METHODS: Amniotic fluid was collected between 16-23 wks by amniocentesis from 3 individuals. Two groups were studied: 1)control grown in DeCoppi medium and 2)treatment group supplemented with VPA. AFC were characterized by morphology, multiplication and FACS for expression of embryonic markers CD-90, TRA-1-60, and SSEA4. AFC were grown as 3D spheroids with/without VPA for differentiation capacity to osteogenic, chondrogenic and neural lineage and analyzed by immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence. RNA was extracted (RNeasy MiniRNA Kit Quiagen,CA), PCR was performed and compared with differential gene expression using Affymetrix probes, DAVID and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA). RESULTS: VPA addition in vitro did not affect cell morphology but slowed proliferation. VPA treated samples displayed significant increase in apoptosis with increased TRA-1-60 and SSEA-4 and decreased CD-90 compared to untreated controls. Differentiation varied among VPA exposed samples, with overall inhibition of neural lineage measured by expression of Nestin, Tubulin, and GFAP. IPA was consistent with downregulation of neural development pathways in VPA treated samples with significant variation in gene expression from controls. VPA treatment caused upregulation of cell cycle and apoptosis pathways and downregulation of cell membrane pathways related to neural differentiation. There was variable upregulation of bone and cartilage differentiation with VPA exposure. CONCLUSIONS: Valproic acid exhibits selective effects on AFC in vitro. Inhibition of neural lineage and preservation of osteogenic and chondrocyte lines resembles in vivo effects of VPA exposure such as neonatal frontal bossing and neural tube defects. This AFC model may serve as a surrogate for study of mechanisms for deleterious effects that medications may have on the developing human fetus. *Figure(s) will be available online.Egg from Ovarian-Derived Stem Cells Develops into Embryo AfterIntracytoplasmic Sperm Injection. Solji Park, Jaclyn Yu, Kaitlin Marquis, Alan H DeCherney, Erin F Wolff. NIH, Bethesda, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: Historically, germ cell development was believed to occur only during fetal development. Once the maximum number of oocytes is reached in the fetal stage, this number decreases until depletion at menopause. This is in contrast to men who possess germ line stem cells that create sperm throughout their lives.However, recently several labs have shown the existence of cells in the ovarian cortex capable of mitosis and meiosis in mouse, rat, and human models. Our lab has shown that these ovarian-derived stem cells (OSCs) are also present in a non-human primates (NHP).METHODS:The objective of this study is to test fertilization potential of oocytes derived from OSCs transplantation in non-human primates. To obtain OSC, the ovarian cortex was digested with collagenase and DNase followed by FACS with the DDX4 antibody. The cells were expanded in culture, transfected with a GFP lentivirus, and transplanted into the remaining ovary of the monkey. Following transplantation, gonadotropins are used for ovarian hyperstimulation to isolate oocytes. Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) was performed with collected MII oocytes and fertilization and embryo development potential assessed. Resultant embryos were analyzed by PCR and nested-PCR to identify lentiviral labeling indicating OSC derivation. RESULTS: OSCs were autologous or allo-transplanted into four monkeys. Each monkey received 1.28-2.1 million cells that were GFP+ via a 27 gauge tuberculin syringe. One out of 11 oocytes obtained by follicular aspiration were confirmed OSCs origin, whereas 32 out of 71 from microdissection. Following ICSI, a mature oocyte originating from OSCs developed into 64-cells stage embryo. OSC derivation was confirmed with nested PCR for the GFP. CONCLUSIONS: Orthotopic OSC transplantation in healthy non-human primates results in mature oocyte formation which can be fertilized and develop to the early blastocyst stage. This is the first fertilized embryo derived from stem cells to achieve fertilization in primates. However, most OSC derived oocytes appear to arrest in the ovarian tissue after transplantation. Further studies are needed to elucidate the determinants and timeline of follicular development of OSC derived oocytes after orthotopic transplantation.Co-Culture of Endometrium-Derived Stem Cells with Murine NeonatalCardiomyocytes to Support Differentiation into Cardiomyocyte-Like Cells In Vitro. Demetra H Hufnagel, Levent Mutlu, Hugh S Taylor. Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are the leading cause of death globally. CVDs result in permanent damage to cardiomyocytes, which ultimately may lead to loss of heart function. Human clinical trials for CVD treatment have shown that injection of mesenchymal stem cells can improve cardiac function. Endometriumderived stem cells (EDSCs) may provide a new and less invasive source of cardiomyocyte-like cells. METHODS: Hearts from neonatal dsRed mice were digested to single cell suspensions before being plated on gelatin-coated 6-well plates.
