TABREF388.text: Trophoblast Differentiation Defects Using Human Pluripotent Stem Cells. Mariko Horii, 1 Yingchun Li, 1 Karen Sabatini, 2 Louise C Laurent, 2 Ying Liu, 3 Mana Parast. 1 1 University of California San Diego, La Jolla, CA, USA; 2 University of California San Diego, La Jolla, CA, USA; 3 The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, TX, USA. INTRODUCTION: Human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) can differentiate into trophoblast using BMP4.

TABREF389.text: : During the 1st step of BMP4-induced differentiation, T21-hPSCs show delayed expression of CTB marker (EGFR), with delayed loss of pluripotency marker POU5F1/OCT4 and longer retention of CTB marker CDX2. During the 2nd step, these cells show lower fusion index and higher hCG secretion in T21-hPSC-derived trophoblast. Furthermore, Activin A treatment rescued the fusion defect in T21-hPSC-derived CTB, without changing hCG secretion. CONCLUSIONS: We have shown that, similar to primary T21 trophoblast, T21-hPSC-derived trophoblast have cell fusion defects which can rescue by exogenous Activin A. Our results confirm that BMP4-treated hPSC can be used to model trophoblast differentiation defect. Our goal is to generate iPSCs from placental cells from both normal and complicated pregnancies to establish in vitro models of placental disorders.Umbilical Cord Blood Mesenchymal Stem Cells Therapy Restores Ovarian Functions in a Preclinical Model of Chemotherapy InducedPremature Ovarian Failure. Sara A Mohamed, 1,2 Shahinaz M Shalaby, 1,3 Soumia Brakta, 1 Lelyand Elam, 1 Mohamed Elakany, 2 Ayman Alhendy. 1 1 Georgia Regents University, Augusta,GA, USA; 2 Mansoura Medical  School, Mansoura, Egypt; 3 Tanta medical school, Tanta, Egypt.   INTRODUCTION: This work is to determine efficacy of Umbilical cord blood mesenchymal stem cells (UCMSCs) in restorative functioning of chemotherapy-damaged ovaries in mice which will serve as a prelude to assess utility of preserving fertility with adult stem cells among cancer survivors for treatment of patients with idiopathic premature ovarian failure. METHODS: Acclimatized 4-6 weeks old female C57BL/6 mice (N=6/group) were randomly assigned to vehicle treated control group (group1), sham chemotherapy group (group2), or cell therapy group (group3). Group 2 & 3 received single intraperitoneal injection of 70 mg/ kg Cyclophosamide and 12 mg/kg Busulfan to induce ovarian failure. Seven days post injection, mice in groups 1 and 2 were subjected to bilateral intra-ovarian injection of 10 ul phosphate buffered saline through abdominal laparotomy. Group 3 received 10 ul of UCMSCs suspension (5X10 5 cells) in each ovary . RESULTS: Post UCMSC implantation, group3 showed detectable estroidogeneic changes in vaginal smears as early as 1 week . Significant increases in total body weight as well as ovaries and other estrogendependent organs (uterus & liver) were observed in group 3 (P<0.05) as early as 2 weeks post cell implantation . Hemotoxylin and Eosin evaluation of the ovaries demonstrated significant increases in total number of follicles in group3 as compared to group 2 (P<0.05) after 2 weeks post cell implantation (1 st time point). Group 3 demonstrated a serum hormonal profile of restored ovarian function compared to group 2: group 3 FSH serum levels showed significant decrease of 40 % ± 5 (P <0.05) compared to group 2, AMH serum levels increased by 50 %± 2 (P<0.05) in group 3 versus group 2. Immunohistochemistry analysis demonstrated higher expression of AMH, FSHR, Inhibinα and Inhibinβ in growing follicles in group 3 versus group 2. Breeding experiments to evaluate effect of this treatment on fertility is ongoing in our laboratory. CONCLUSIONS: Our study shows that intra-ovarian injected UCMSCs were able to restore ovarian hormone production, reactivate folliculogenesis in chemotherapy-damaged ovaries in this preclinical model. This approach carries high promise to women with chemotherapyinduced, and potentially other types of, premature ovarian failure.Fertile Lifespan Characteristics and All-Cause and Cause-SpecificMortality: A Study of Postmenopausal Women from the Rotterdam Study. Loes Jaspers, 1 Nicole Erler, 1,2 Albert Hofman, 1 Joop SE Laven, 3 Maryam Kavousi, 1 Oscar H Franco. 1 1 Erasmus University Medical Centre, Rotterdam, Netherlands; 2 Erasmus University Medical Centre, Rotterdam, Netherlands; 3 Erasmus University Medical Centre, Rotterdam, Netherlands.INTRODUCTION: Considering demographic changes in reproductive choices and their relevance for longevity, we characterized the relation between established and novel characteristics of the fertile life with allcause and cause-specific mortality (ACM and CSM). METHODS: Analyses included 4076 women (mean age 69.1 years) from the population-based Rotterdam Study. Using cox models, the effect of women's fertile lifespan (age at menopause -menarche), number of children, maternal age at first and last child, maternal lifespan (maternal age at first -last child), and post-maternal fertile lifespan (age of menopause -age at last child) on ACM and CSM were assessed. The potential (non)-linearity of the effect was evaluated with p-splines, and the interaction of these variables with age and number of children was tested.RESULTS: 2754 women died during 14.8 years of follow-up. Each 1 year increase in age at first and last birth was linearly associated with a significantly lower hazard of dying of any cause in age and time since menopause adjusted models [hazard ratio HR, (95% confidence interval CI): 0.99 (0.98-1.00), for both variables], whereas a 1 year longer maternal, fertile, and post-maternal fertile lifespan was significantly associated with higher hazards or dying of any cause [HR (95%CI): 1.01 (1.00-1.02), 1.02 (1.00-1.04), 1.01 (1.00-1.02), respectively]. None except fertile lifespan remained significant in fully adjusted models. Furthermore, we found that women bearing 1 child and bearing it >35 years had a lower hazard of dying [HR (95% CI): 0.61 (0.46-0.82)] compared to women bearing at ≤34 years, whereas no effects were found in women bearing > 1 child. This association might be explained by the higher socio-economic status of these women. Findings differed with regard to direction, size and significance when stratifying for CVD and cancer mortality. CONCLUSIONS: Overall, we found associations between fertile lifespan characteristics and mortality. To broaden our understanding of the effect of changing fertility patterns on mortality, more research is needed in contemporary cohorts with larger sample sizes and more extreme ages of birth.Maternal Morbidity Associated with Postpartum Hemorrhage After Vaginal Delivery at Low, Moderate, and High Volume Hospitals.Alexander M Friedman, Cande V Ananth, Audrey A Merriam, Zainab Siddiq, Mary E D'Alton, Jason D Wright. Columbia University, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: The purpose of this study was to determine risk for postpartum hemorrhage and associated major morbidity for women undergoing vaginal delivery in hospitals with different obstetrical volumes. METHODS: Women who experienced postpartum hemorrhage following vaginal delivery from 2006 to 2012 were identified in a large administrative database (Premier). Hospitals were characterized based on annualized volume: low (<1,000 deliveries per year), moderate (1,000-<2,000), and high volume (≥2000). The incidence of postpartum hemorrhage was calculated for each hospital volume category. Risk for severe maternal morbidity and/or death associated with postpartum hemorrhage was determined. RESULTS: Of 4,067,694 women who had a vaginal delivery, 103,474 women (2.54%) experienced hemorrhage. At low volume hospitals, the rate of hemorrhage was 2.47% compared to 2.58% and 2.55% at moderate and high volume hospitals. Rates of severe morbidity are presented in the table in terms of incidence per 1,000 cases of hemorrhage. Disseminated intravascular coagulation was the most common form of severe morbidity, occurring in 6.2%, 7.3%, and 8.4% of cases of hemorrhage at low, moderate, and high volume hospitals respectively. Other commonly encountered morbidity included acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and shock. CONCLUSIONS: Hemorrhage after vaginal delivery is relatively common obstetric complication that occurs with similar frequency across obstetrical centers. Given the morbidity associated with postpartum hemorrhage, and that it occurs with similar frequency even at low volume hospitals, all centers providing care should be prepared to manage this complication. *Figure(s) will be available online.Sustainable Cervical Cancer Prevention Clinics Using the World Health Organization "See and Treat" Method: A Five CountryExperience. Stephen A Morris, 1 Jacquelyn T Dang, 1 Jennifer Lang, 1 Patricia Gordon, 1 Caroline C Nitschmann. 1,2 1 Cure Cervical Cancer, Los Angeles, CA, USA; 2 Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA. INTRODUCTION: Cervical cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths among women worldwide.CureCervicalCancer (CCC), a 501(c) (3) nonprofit organization, is dedicated to cervical cancer prevention in resource poor nations. Clinics are sustained by utilizing local recourses and training native healthcare providers in the 'See and Treat' method as described by the World Health Organization (WHO). We sought to describe our experience of five international clinics. METHODS: Patients screened and treated for precancerous lesions at sustainable CCC clinics were retrospectively identified from March 2013 to August 2015. Clinic locations included Vietnam, Haiti, Kenya, Ethiopia, and Guatemala for a total of 46 clinics in all five countries. Per the WHO method, patients were screened by visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA). If patients screened positive they were offered treatment with cryotherapy by carbon dioxide (CO2) or nitrous oxide (N2O). Local healthcare provider training was offered to doctors, midwives, and nurses. Intensive education was presented in the native language in both visual and written forms in addition to hands on training. Continued education and support was provided for each clinic in exchange for ongoing screening and creation of reliable patient registries. RESULTS: A total of 34,759 patients were screened in the five countries identified. There were 4,010 (11.5%) patients found to be VIA positive, of which 2,994 (8.6%) received cryotherapy treatment. Of the patients who screened VIA positive, there were 1,016 patients (2.9%) that did not receive cryotherapy treatment because of refusal or equipment failure. As a result of local training, a total of 256 healthcare providers were considered proficient in "See and Treat". CCC maintains constant communication with the clinics. Data from ongoing screening is reported electronically on a monthly basis and includes the number of women screened with VIA, how many test positive or negative, and the number of women that received cryotherapy. CONCLUSIONS: Immediate 'See and Treat' is a feasible approach to the early detection and treatment of precancerous cervical lesions in different developing countries. The unique CCC organizational model demonstrates it is possible to maintain sustainable clinics in through ongoing education and support.Twin Pregnancy in theSetting of Advanced Maternal Age: Risk of Prematurity, Neonatal Morbidity, and Stillbirth. Amelia A McLennan, Cande V Ananth, Jason D Wright, Zainab Siddiq, Mary E D'Alton, Alexander M Friedman. Columbia University, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION:The objective of this study was to evaluate risk of preterm delivery, neonatal morbidity, and stillbirth in twin pregnancies in the setting of advanced maternal age. METHODS: This population-based study of U.S. natality records from 2005-2013 evaluated neonatal outcomes for twin pregnancies based on maternal age. Women delivering at age 18-34, 35 to 39, and >39 were compared. Only twin pregnancies that resulted in a live birth at > 24 weeks gestation or a stillbirth at ≥20 weeks were included. For each maternal age category, risk was determined for the following conditions: assisted ventilation for >6 hours, NICU admission, antibiotic administration for suspected neonatal sepsis, surfactant use, neonatal seizures or serious neurologic dysfunction, Apgar score <7 at 5 minutes, and stillbirth. RESULTS: Of 785,888 live twin births, 601,710 were to women age 18-34, 137,602 were to women age 35-39, and 46,576 were to women 40 or older. 8855 stillbirths were included in the analysis. Risk for stillbirth was significantly lower for both groups of older mothers compared to mothers age 18-34, as was risk for preterm birth at age <32 weeks gestation

TABREF390.text: p<0.001). Mothers of newborns who received a well visit in the first week were 31% less likely to miss their own postpartum visit (RR: 0.69 (95% CI: 0.64-0.75). CONCLUSIONS: Sociodemographic factors, newborn health issues, and noncompliance with other medical care emerged as main themes associated with postpartum visit noncompliance. Women with high-risk of failing to attend a postpartum checkup can be targeted for interventions to increase compliance or obtain postpartum care in other settings.Advanced Maternal Age with Twin Pregnancy: Mode of Delivery and Risk for Gestational Diabetes and Gestational Hypertension/ Preeclampsia. Amelia A McLennan, Cande V Ananth, Jason D Wright, Zainab Siddiq, Mary E D'Alton, Alexander M Friedman. Columbia University, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: The objective of this study was to evaluate mode of delivery and risk for obstetric conditions such as gestational diabetes and gestational hypertension/preeclampsia for twin pregnancies based on maternal age. METHODS: This population-based study of U.S. natality records from 2005-2013 evaluated maternal outcomes for twin pregnancies in women by maternal age. Women aged 18-34, 35 to 39, and >39 were compared where delivery occurred after 24 weeks gestation. Only twin pregnancies that delivered at ≥ 24 weeks gestation were included. For each maternal age category, risk was determined for gestational diabetes and gestational hypertension/preeclampsia. Mode of delivery was also determined. RESULTS: 785,888 twin births were included in the analysis: 601,710 to women age 18-34, 137,602 in women age 35-39, and 46,576 to women over 40. Risk of gestational hypertension was significantly higher only in mothers over 40 (RR 1.45, 95%CI 1.42-1.49) compared to women age 18-34. Risk of gestational diabetes was increased among both 34-39year-olds (RR 1.58, 95%CI 1.55-1.62) and age greater than 39 (RR 1.83, 95%CI 1.78-1.88). Women with twin pregnancies over age 39 were most likely to undergo cesarean delivery (84.5%) compared with those age 18-34 (74%) and 34-39 (79%) (p<.0001). There were fewer vacuum-assisted vaginal deliveries in both groups over 35, and no difference between the groups in rates of forceps-assisted vaginal delivery CONCLUSIONS: Twin pregnancies in women over age 35 are associated with higher rates of gestational hypertension/preeclampsia, gestational diabetes, and cesarean section compared to women age 18-34, and are the highest in women over age 40. *Figure(s) will be available online.Association Between Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) and Preterm Birth: A Case-Control Study inChongqing, China. Barbara SE Verstraeten, 1,2 Ping Xu, 3 Kelly Ma, 4 Xing Cheng Qi, 3 Hongbo Qi, 3 David M Olson. 1,5 1 U of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; 2 Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium; 3 Chongqing Medical University, Chonqing, China; 4 U of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; 5 U of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada. INTRODUCTION: Preterm birth(PTB)is the leading cause of neonatal mortality and morbidity. One of the possible contributors to PTB is chronic maternal stress. We previously conducted a case-control study in Edmonton, AB, Canada, using the Wellbeing and Pregnancy Questionnaire. We showed that adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) in a mother's life are associated with increasing PTB risk. We report on a similar study performed in Chongqing, China in order to evaluate the questionnaire's effectiveness in a different population. METHODS: Subjects were recruited at hospitals in the Chongqing area. Cases were mothers with a spontaneous singleton PTB (<37w) without preterm premature rupture of membranes. Controls included mothers with an uncomplicated singleton birth >38 weeks and without a history of PTB. Sociodemographic and medical data were collected. The Wellbeing and Pregnancy Questionnaire, evaluating chronic life-long stressors was administered postpartum. A combined childhood and adult abuse score was calculated from the ACE score and the Abuse Assessment Screen (ASS). 20 cases and 75 controls were included. Uni-and multivariate logistic regression were performed, p<0.05. Odds ratios for spontaneous PTB and 95% CIs are reported. RESULTS: Maternal age and educational status differed significantly between cases and controls. Cases were younger (OR 0.874; 95% CI 0.78-0.99), had a lower level of education (p<0.001) and annual income (p<0.001). The ACE score and ASS were significantly associated with sPTB in univariate analyses (OR 2.00, 95% CI 1.08-3.71; OR 13.06, 95% CI 1.28-133.38) as was the combined childhood and adult abuse score (OR 5.89, 95% CI 1.92-18.01), but not in multivariate. History of ≥1 ACE was also linked with sPTB (OR 6.00, 95%CI 1.95-18.44). CONCLUSIONS: This case-control study in Chongqing showed similar results to our larger study in Edmonton with small differences in sociodemographic variables between the study populations. Even in this small Chinese cohort, the ACE score, ASS and childhood and adult abuse score were associated with sPTB, suggesting that the association between ACEs and sPTB might be common between ethnic groups, and that this questionnaire may be part of a predictive algorithm for sPTB.Factors Associated with Gastroschisis in the UnitedStates, 2005-2013. Alexander M Friedman, Cande V Ananth, Zainab Siddiq, Mary E D'Alton, Jason D Wright. Columbia University, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: The objective of this study evaluating live births in the United States from 2005 to 2013 was to provide up-to-date epidemiology on risk factors associated with gastroschisis. METHODS: This population-based study of US natality records from 2005-2013 evaluated pregnancies complicated by gastroschisis.The primary outcome was the presence or absence of gastroschisis. Obstetrical, medical, and demographic characteristics were evaluated. Multivariable log-linear regression models were developed to determine factors associated with the anomaly. RESULTS: 7,683 pregnancies with gastroschisis and 24,829,094 pregnancies without the anomaly were included. The overall incidence was 3.1 cases per 10,000 pregnancies and ranged from 2.9 to 3.2 during the study period. 74.0% of cases were diagnosed in women younger than 25. The risk ratio (RR) in the adjusted model for age <20 was 3.46 (95% confidence interval [CI] 3.19-3.75). Other factors included smoking (RR 1.61, 95% CI 1.51-1.72), being unmarried (RR 1.67, 95% CI 1.57-1.77), and high school graduation as highest educational attainment (RR 1.40, 95% CI 1.23-1.59). Factors associated with lower risk for gastroschisis included African American race (RR 0.44, 95% CI 0.41-0.48), chronic hypertension (RR 0.61, 95% CI 0.44-0.84), and body mass index (BMI): Compared to normal weight women, the RR for overweight women was 0.70 (95%CI 0.65-0.77); for obesity with BMI 30.0-34.9 the RR was 0.49 (95% CI 0.43-0.56); for obesity with BMI ≥40 the RR was 0.26 (95% CI 0.19-0.36). CONCLUSIONS: The magnitude of reduced risk with obesity suggests a potential metabolic etiology for gastroschisis. Given the morbidity associated with gastroschisis and that the etiology is unknown, further research into the protective role of obesity is warranted. While several reports have suggested increasing prevalence of gastroschisis, our results did not demonstrate this temporal trend.Stillbirth and Neonatal Adverse Outcomes in PregnanciesComplicated by Chronic Hypertension. Alexander M Friedman, Cynthia Gyamfi-Bannerman, Jason D Wright, Zainab Siddiq, Mary E D'Alton, Cande V Ananth. Columbia University, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: The objective of this study was to evaluate the risk for stillbirth and adverse neonatal outcomes in pregnancies complicated by chronic hypertension at or nearing term. METHODS: This population-based study of U.S. natality records from 2005-2013 evaluated neonatal outcomes and cumulative risk for stillbirth for pregnancies complicated by chronic hypertension delivering at ≥36 weeks gestational age. Only singleton, non-anomalous pregnancies without diabetes and/or preeclampsia/gestational hypertension were included. For delivery at each week of gestation, risk was determined for a composite adverse neonatal outcome that included the following conditions: assisted ventilation for >6 hours, NICU admission, antibiotic administration for suspected neonatal sepsis, surfactant use, neonatal seizures or serious neurologic dysfunction, and/or Apgar score <7 at 5 minutes. Multivariable log-linear regression models were developed to create an adjusted model for the composite neonatal outcome. Cumulative risk of stillbirth was calculated from 36 weeks until the gestational age at delivery. RESULTS: 201,740 live births and 878 stillbirths were included in the analysis. The risk for the adverse neonatal outcome was highest with delivery at 36 to <37 weeks(18.9%), lowest with delivery at 39 to <40 weeks age (6.1%), and increased after 40 weeks gestational age (p<0.001)

TABREF391.text: Obstetric Mode of Delivery and Attention-Deficit/HyperactivityDisorder: A Sibling Control Study. Eileen A Curran, 1 Ali S Khashan, 1,2 Christina Dalman, 3 Louise C Kenny, 1 John F Cryan, 4 Timothy G Dinan, 4 Patricia M Kearney. 2 1 University College Cork, Cork, Ireland; 2 University College Cork, Cork, Ireland; 3 Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, Sweden; 4 University College Cork, Cork, Ireland. INTRODUCTION:Birth by Caesarean section(CS) may affect psychological development through changes in gut microbiota or stress response. Our objective was to assess the impact of mode of delivery, specifically birth by CS on the development of attention-deficit/ hyperactivity disorder(ADHD), using data from the Swedish national registers. METHODS: Mode of delivery included: unassisted vaginal delivery(VD), assisted VD, elective CS or emergency CS. ADHD was determined using International Classification of Diseases version 10(F90 or F98.8), or prescription for ADHD medication. The study cohort included all singleton live births in Sweden from 1990-2008. We used Cox regression for data analysis in the total cohort, adjusting for perinatal and socio-demographic factors. We then stratified our Cox regression analysis by maternal ID to assess the association among sibling matches. RESULTS: There 1,722,548 children in our cohort, and 47,778 cases of ADHD(2.8%). 1,241,366 families were included in the sibling-matched analysis including 6,976 families discordant on both mode of delivery and ADHD. When compared to unassisted VD, there was little evidence of an association between assisted VD and ADHD in the total cohort(HR=1.02; [95%CI:0.98-1.06]) or sibling-matched(HR=1.05; [95%CI:0.93-1.18]) analyses. For elective CS, the HR was 1.15(95% CI:1.11-1.20) in the total cohort, and 1.05(95%CI:0.93-1.18) with sibling-matched analysis. For emergency CS, the HR was 1.16(95%CI:1.12-1.20) in the total cohort and 1.13(95%CI:1.01-1.26) with the sibling-matched analyses.

TABREF392.text: United States Birth Weight References for Twin and Triplet Pregnancies and Timing of Delivery.Stephen J Bacak, 1 Dongmei Li, 2 Timothy D Dye, 1 Tulin Ozcan. 1 1 University of Rochester Medical Center, Rochester, NY, USA; 2 University of Rochester Medical Center, Rochester, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: Our study objective was to provide national birth weight (BW) references for gestational age and gender for twin and triplet pregnancies. METHODS: Twin and triplet live births between 22-41 weeks were abstracted from the 2004-2013 Natality Public Use files from the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) for the United States (n=1,346,477 for twins and n= 54,235 for triplets). The gestational age at delivery (GAD) is generated through NCHS algorithms. GAD, computed based on LMP, obstetric estimated gestation age, infant BW and plurality, was used for calculating percentiles of BW at each gestational week for male and female infants separately. The mean, standard deviation, and percentiles (3rd, 5th, 10th, 50th, 90th, 95th, and 97th) of BW were calculated for gestational age and gender. Histograms of all twin and triplet BW were used to describe the overall BW distribution. Analysis was conducted using SAS 9.4. RESULTS: Twin male BW percentiles were higher than female BW percentiles except for 24 and 25 weeks. Twin growth plateaus and decreases at 38 weeks. The 10th, 50th, and 90th percentiles of twin BW born at 38 weeks were 2319g, 2834g, and 3320g in males compared to 2231g, 2720g, and 3185g in females. Nine percent of twins remain undelivered after 38 weeks. Triplet male BW percentiles were higher than female BW percentiles except for 22 and 23 weeks. Triplet growth continues to increase until 35-36 weeks. The 10th, 50th, and 90th percentiles of BW born at the 36th gestational week were 1758g, 2296g, and 2760g for male triplets, compared to 1616g, 2183g, and 2608g in female triplets. BW appears to decrease in triplets that remain undelivered after 36 weeks. Thirty-six percent of triplets remained undelivered after 36 weeks. CONCLUSIONS: Delaying delivery until after 38 weeks in twins and after 36 weeks for triplets does not improve birth weight. These updated BW references may be an alternative to using singleton BW charts in twins and triplets in clinical practice and research.Intergenerational Risk of Breech Presentation. Marlayna Townsend, 1 Alison Fraser, 2 Tyler Bardsley, 3 Yue Zhang, 3 Michael Varner. 4 1 University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA; 2 Huntsman Cancer Institute, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA; 3 University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA; 4 University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Many obstetric complications cluster in families.

TABREF393.text: CONCLUSIONS: Parents who were themselves born breech have an increased risk of breech presentation and delivery in their first-born children. This result suggests an inheritable risk for breech presentation, although we can not exclude environmental contributions.More Data Supporting That Intra-Amniotic "Sludge" Does Not Affect Pregnancy Outcome in Patients Undergoing Cerclage for Short Cervix. Ferehteh Boozarjomehri, 1 Margaret Dziadosz, 2 Morgan M Peltier, 1 Fatima S Boozarjomehri, 3 Anthomy M Vintzileos, 1 Ilan Timor-Tritch, 2 Frederick Naftolin. 2 1 Winthrop University Hospital, Mineola, NY, USA; 2 New York Univ Sch Med, New York, NY, USA; 3 Swarthmore College, Swarthmore, PA, USA. INTRODUCTION:Previously we showed that presence of intraamniotic "sludge" (IAS), an ultrasound (US) finding of hyperechoic matter in amniotic fluid (AF) close to internal os, did not change pregnancy outcome in asymptomatic patients (pts) undergoing high cerclage for sonographycally short cervix (Cx). We aim to find if addition of 22 patients (pts) to previously reported 46 changes the result.METHODS:A case records of 68 consecutive pts, who underwent high MacDonald cerclage betweent 16-24 6/7 weeks (wks) gestation for a short Cx (<25 mm), from 2007-2015 were evaluated. Pre-cerclage transvaginal US images were reviewed for Cx length, funneling and presence or absence of IAS. All procedures were performed or supervised by single operator (FB). Baseline morphalogical characteristics and pregnancy outcomes were compared between those with and without IAS. RESULTS: 36/68 pts had IAS present, 32 did not. Comparison of the two groups is shown.

TABREF394.text: Simultaneous Recording and Analysis of Uterine and Abdominal Muscle Electromyographic Activity (EMG) in Nulliparous WomenDuring Labor. Xueya Qian, Pin Li, Robert E Garfield, Shao-Qing Shi, Huishu Liu. GuangzhouWomen and Children's Medical Center,  Guangzhou Medical University, Guangzhou, China.  INTRODUCTION:  The aim was to record and characterize EMG signals from the uterus and abdominal muscles during the 1 st and 2 nd stages of labor and define relationships to contractions. METHODS: Nulliparous patients without any treatments were used (n = 63, 30 during 1 st stage, 33 during 2 nd stage). EMG of uterine and abdominal muscles was simultaneously recorded from electrodes placed on patients' abdominal surface using PowerLab hardware and LabChart software (ADInstruments, New South Wales, Australia) with filters to separate uterine (low frequency) and abdominal (high frequency) EMG. Contractions of uterine muscles were also recorded using tocodynamometry connected to the PowerLab. RESULTS: During the 1 st stage of labor, when abdominal EMG is absent, uterine EMG bursts temporally correspond to contractions. In the 2 nd stage uterine EMG bursts usually occur at same frequency as groups of abdominal bursts and precede abdominal bursts, while abdominal EMG bursts (not uterine EMG) correspond to contractions and are accompanied by feelings of "urge to push" by the patients.Table showsparameters of uterine and abdominal EMG bursts at different stages (mean values ± SEM). There are significant differences (P<0.01) between uterine EMG during 1st stage vs. 2nd stage of labor and uterine vs. abdominal EMG. CONCLUSIONS: 1). Uterine and abdominal EMG accurately reflect electrical activity of the muscles during labor and are valuable to assess progress and effort. 2). During 1 st stage of labor uterine EMG is responsible for contractions and during 2 nd stage uterine and abdominal muscle both participate in labor. 3). Electrical signals from the uterus and abdominal muscle change during the progression of labor. 4). Uterine EMG influences abdominal muscle EMG initially through a CNS reflex that contributes to the impulse to "push" and voluntarily-induced contractions.The Effect of Infertility Treatment on Term Maternal/Neonatal Outcomes and Optimal Timing for Delivery in Conception-AssistedSingleton "Premium Pregnancies". Gustavo Vilchez, 2 Cecilia Maldonado, 1 Josephine Doo, 2 Jing Dai, 1 Robert J Sokol. 1 1 Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, MI, USA; 2 University of Missouri at Kansas City School of Medicine, Kansas City, MO, USA. INTRODUCTION: Pregnancies achieved with infertility treatment are increasing significantly, and are associated with higher morbi/mortality.

TABREF395.text: of Conception Type on Pregnancy Outcomes in Twin Gestations. Laura Meints, 1 David Akers. 2 1 University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA; 2 University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA. INTRODUCTION:Little is known about the effect of type of conception on pregnancy outcomes. We aim to quantify perinatal risks associated with type of conception in twin gestations. METHODS: This study is a secondary analysis of a multicenter, randomized, controlled trial to evaluate 17-OH progesterone (17-OHP) in twin gestations to prevent preterm birth (PTB). Exposure was type of conception: spontaneous, ovulation stimulation (OS), in vitro fertilization or intracytoplasmic sperm injection (IVF/ICSI), and intrauterine insemination (IUI). Primary outcome was gestational age at delivery (EGA). Secondary outcomes were indication for delivery, mode of delivery, birthweight, gestational diabetes (GDM), preeclampsia, markers of neonatal morbidity, and neonatal mortality. We performed univariate and multivariable linear regression with generalized estimating equations to determine the potential association between primary outcome and BMI. Results were considered statistically significant if p<.05. RESULTS: There were 1316 women included in the analysis: 855 with spontaneous conceptions, 118 with OS, 311 with IVF/ICSI, and 32 with IUI. Women by type of conception were significantly different in age, race, BMI, tobacco use, chorionicity, parity, previous PTB, marital status, and receipt of 17-OHP. In the univariate analyses, there was a statistical difference in EGA (p=.0003) by type of conception. In univariate analyses, statistically significant differences were also seen by type of conception in mean birthweight (p=.0003), indication for delivery (p<.0001), GDM (p=.017), and preeclampsia (p<.0001). In adjusted models, none of these relationships remained statistically significant. No significant differences were seen in measures of neonatal morbidity or mortality. CONCLUSIONS: This data shows no increased risk for maternal or neonatal morbidity in twin gestations by type of conception.Factors Associated with Longer Duration of Pregnancy After OpenFetal Myelomeningocele Repair. Christina E Rodriguez, 1 Henry L Galan, 1 Nicholas Behrendt, 1 Shane Reeves, 1 Kenneth W Liechty, 2 Rony Marwan, 2 Michael Handler, 3 Corbett Wilkinson, 3 Jeannie Zuk, 1 Zhaoxing Pan, 1 Timothy M Crombleholme, 2 Michael V Zaretsky. 1 1 Colorado Fetal Care Center, Aurora, CO, USA; 2 Colorado Fetal Care Center, Aurora, CO, USA; 3 Colorado Fetal Care Center, Aurora, CO, USA. INTRODUCTION: Our objective was to determine the clinical characteristics that correlate with duration of pregnancy following prenatal open fetal myelomeningocele repair. METHODS: This was a retrospective cohort of women who underwent open fetal myelomeningocele repair at a single institution from 2013-2014. Medical records were abstracted for clinical characteristics including gestational age at time of procedure, total operative time, myelomeningocele repair time, change in transvaginal cervical length

TABREF396.text: r=0.37, P=0.03) correlation. No statistically significant correlation was found for total operative time, myelomeningocele repair time, or location of hysterotomy. CONCLUSIONS: Operative time, gestational age at repair, myelomeningocele repair time, and location of hysterotomy did not influence the duration of pregnancy following open prenatal myelomeningocele repair. Only a change in cervical length postoperatively correlated with earlier delivery. Pre-and post-operative measurement of cervical length may identify a subset of patients requiring more intensive surveillance following open myelomeningocele repair.Impact of Increased Parity in the Success of Vaginal Birth After Cesarean Section (VBAC). Katherine Apostolakis-Kyrus, 1 Ginikachukwu B Ikwuezunma, 1 Chibbi Iwelu, 1 Christine J Secrest, 2 Luis M Gomez. 1 1 The University of Tennessee Health Science Center, Memphis, TN, USA; 2 Georgia Regents University, Augusta, GA, USA. INTRODUCTION: To determine if an increased number of vaginal deliveries increases VBAC success.METHODS: This is a retrospective cohort study that reviewed 233 singleton cases of attempted trial of labor after cesarean section (TOLAC) from 2007 to 2010. The primary outcome was successful vaginal birth after cesarean section. We stratified patients by parity, body mass index, race, and age. Statistical analysis was done using commercially available software. Continuous variables were analyzed using the Chi-square and Fisher's exact tests. A p-value of 0.05 was considered significant. RESULTS: There was a statistically significant difference between women who had a previous spontaneous vaginal delivery (SVD) versus no prior vaginal delivery in their success of having a VBAC, p value < 0.001. Of the 233 TOLAC attempted, 175 (75%) cases were successful. Of 59 women who had one previous vaginal delivery, 45 (76%) had successful trials of labor compared to 96 women out of 109 (88%) women who had a history of multiple vaginal deliveries. In our cohort, the success of VBAC increased significantly when a patient had 3 or more vaginal deliveries (P=0.02, after adjusting for confounders). BMI >35 decreased the success of VBAC only for women older than 35 y-o who had 2 or less prior vaginal deliveries (P=0.04). White race was an independent successful prognostic factor for a successful VBAC (P=0.02). CONCLUSIONS: In our cohort, women with 3 or more previous vaginal deliveries have an increased rate of successful VBAC. Success of VBAC is greater in women of white race. BMI >35 may decrease the rate of success especially in women older than 35 y-o who had less than 3 prior vaginal deliveries.Revision of a Failed Cerclage Is Associated with Higher Risk of Premature Birth Compared to Primary Cerclage. FereshtehBoozarjomehri, 1 Margaret Dziadosz, 2 Morgan M Peltier, 1 Fatima S Boozarjomehri, 3 Anthony M Vintzileos, 1 Ilan Timor-Tritch, 2 Frederick Naftolin. 2 1 Winthrop UnivHosp, Mineola, NY, USA; 2 New York Univ Sch  Med, New York, NY, USA; 3  Swarthmore College, Swarthmore, PA, USA.INTRODUCTION:Little is known about pregnancy outcome of revising a failed cerclage, previously placed for a midtrimester short cervix (Cx). Our previous data reported higher risk of premature birth in patients (pts) with a revision compared with single cerclage. We aim to find if addition of 23 pts to previously reported 54 changes the result. METHODS: This is a cohort of 77 pts with ultrasound (US) cervix length (CL) of <25mm, at 16-24 6/7 weeks (wks) who underwent MacDonald cerclage in 2007-2015. nine pts required revision to correct a failed cerclage. Failed cerclage was defined as presence of prolapsed membrane beyond the cerclage or CL distal to the cerclage of <1 cm. Delivery gestational age (GA) and other other obstetrical outcomes were compared between 2 group. RESULTS: There were 4 pregnancy losses (2 in 1st attempt, 2 in revision). 1 pt in the primary cerclage group was lost to follow-up.

TABREF397.text: Long-Term Oral Indomethacin (LIT) Stabilizes Cervical Length, No Matter How Short, in Prolongation of Pregnancies at Risk forPreterm Delivery. Bilge Cetin-Demirkaya, Rinat Benziv-Gabbay, Jerome Kopelman, Sifa Turan, Chris R Harman, Ozhan M Turan. University of Maryland, Baltimore, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION:

TABREF398.text: RESULTS: 80 LIT cases with 586 serial CL measurements were studied. Median GA at LIT start was 22w (18-24), with median CL of 15 mm (4-25). Median duration of LIT was 55 days (3-101). Women on LIT generally showed a modest increase in CL(0.3-0.5 mm/week). Median changes in CL between initial and last exam were +4 mm. Mean GA at delivery was 37 1/7 w. Regardless of initial CL measurement, initiation of LIT helped to keep CL stable as it is (p>0.05). Small performance differences for the 0-5mm group (shorter duration, earlier median delivery GA) were not statistically significant. Choosing larger study cohorts, for example, CL <15mm (N=44) vs >15mm (N=36), differences are negligible -change in CL (12mm to 17mm vs 20mm to 20mm) , total prolongation (>7w for both), delivery GA (37w for both), all did not differ (p >0.05 for all).

TABREF399.text: Association Between Cervical Exam After Ripening with Foley Balloon Catheter and Mode of Delivery. Ashley N Battarbee, Anna Palatnik, Danielle Peress, William A Grobman. Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA. INTRODUCTION: To evaluate the association between cervical exam after ripening with foley balloon catheter and the chance of vaginal delivery (VD).

TABREF400.text: New Data on Pregnancy Outcome After Placement by a Single Operator of "High" Cerclage in Second TrimesterPatients with Sonographycally Short Cervix. Fereshteh Boozarjomehri, 1 Margaret Dziadosz, 2 Morgan M Peltier, 1 Marcos Cordoba, 3 Fatima S Boozarjomehri, 4 Anthony M Vintzileos, 1 Ilan Timor-Tritch, 2 Frederick Naftolin. 2 1 Winthrop University Hospital, Mineola, NY, USA; 2 New York University School ofMedicine, New York, NY, USA; 3 Rockford Memorial  Hospital, Rockford, IL, USA; 4  Swarthmore College, Swarthmore, PA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Cerclage for cervical (Cx) insufficiency is a common procedure. However, there is operator variation in technique that may impact its effectiveness in improving pregnancy outcome. Previously we showed high success rate of cerclage performed on mid-trimester sonographycally short Cx. We aim to find if addition of 23 patients (pts) to our previously reported 54 pts would change the result. METHODS: We studied 77 consecutive pts with ultrasound (US) Cx length of <25 mm, at 16-24 6/7 weeks (wks) who underwent a high MacDonald cerclage from 2007-2015. High cerclage was defined as cerclage (mersilene tape) suture placement 5 cm above the external os, intracervical-Foley (balloon filled above the internal os). Amnioreduction (transabdominal amniocentesis) was used in pts with very short Cx (bulging membrane or 0-2 cm Cx length). All pts received pre-op antibiotics, pre, post-op indomethacin and regional anesthesia. All procedures performed or supervised by a the single operator (FB). Post-op Cx US were performed immediately and 2 wks post-op to evaluate Cx length and cerclage quality. RESULTS: 64 of 77 pts (83%) had amnioreduction. The distribution of pre and post-op Cx lengths were as follows: Preop Cx lengths: 23 pts (30%) >15 mm, 54 pts (70%) <15 mm, 29 pts (38%) <10 mm, and 18 pts (23%) <5 mm, (mean 11 mm, median 11 mm, range 0-25 mm). Post-op Cx lengths: in 39 pts (51%) were between 40-50 mm and in remaining 38 pts (44%) between 30-40 mm, (mean of 41 mm, median of 41, range 30-55 mm). 1 pt was lost to follow-up. Outcome in 76 pts: 4 pts (5.3%) delivered at <24 wks, 4 pts (5.3%) at 24-25 wks (%), 2 pts (2.6%) at 26-28 wks, 8 pts (10.5%) at 28-32 wks, 7 pts (9.2%) at 33-34 wks, 10 pts (13%) at 35-36 wks and 41 pts (54%) at >=37 weeks. In total 67% and 76% of deliveries occurred at >34 and >32 wks, respectively CONCLUSIONS: This is the largest reported group of high cerclages. Under appropriate condition and using the optimal technique, high cervical cerclage by an experienced operator in pts with sonographycally short Cx appears safe and is associated with excellent pregnancy outcomes.Antenatal Magnesiumsulphate for Neuroprotection ReducesPunctate White Matter Laesions at 30 Weeks MRI in the Human Neonate. Jan B Derks, Chalana M Sol, Jeanette Van Leeuwen, Kristin Keunen, Eduard J Mulder, Linda S De Vries, Floris Groenendaal, Petra M Lemmers, Manon J Benders. University Medical Center Utrecht, Utrecht, Netherlands. INTRODUCTION: In preterm infants, antenatal magnesiumsulphate (MgSO4) improves neurological outcome when administered during premature labor before 32 weeks of gestation (Rouse et al.)

TABREF401.text: ). Punctate white matter lesions (PWML) were reduced at 30 weeks MRI (19,4% vs 45,2%, p value 0.002), but not at 40 weeks MRI. There was no increase in neonatal complications, including early intubation for respiratory insufficieny or hypotension. CONCLUSIONS: Magnesiumsulphate does not increase neonatal side effects and is associated with less PWML at 30 weeks MRI. The clinical consequences need to be elucidated in long term followup.The data have to be interpreted with caution due to the retrospective character of the study.Suboptimal Antenatal Corticosteroid (ACS) Administration AmongWomen with Spontaneous Preterm Birth (PTB). T Manuck, S Romero, S Esplin, S Parry, H Zhang, H Huang, J Biggio, R Bukowski, G Saade, W Andrews, D Baldwin, Y Sadovsky, U Reddy, J Ilekis, M Varner. for PTB Research, Bethesda, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: ACS improve neonatal outcomes, but it can be difficult to know when to give ACS. We sought to examine ACS use by gestational age (GA), and to determine factors associated with use. METHODS: Secondary analysis of a prospective, multicenter study of spontaneous PTB. We included women w/non-anomalous singleton pregnancies delivering 23.0-33.9 wks. Women receiving ACS ≥2 days before delivery had a 'complete' ACS course. We examined the relationship between sociodemographic factors, pregnancy history, maternal medical co-morbidities, and foreboding PTB risk factors (short cervix, vaginal bleeding, +/-oligo w/out PPROM) and ACS use. RESULTS: 967 women met inclusion criteria. 114 (12%) received no ACS, 362 (37%) got a partial ACS course, and 491 (51%) got a complete course. Groups are compared by ACS course(Table). Neonatal ACS exposure varied by GA (p=0.002),Figure.In regression models, delivery GA (aOR for 23 weeks=0.39; aOR for 24-30 wks ranged 1.5-2.2, compared to delivery at 32-33 wks), PPROM (aOR 1.67, 95% CI 1.28-2.18), and foreboding PTB risk factors (aOR 1.36, 95% CI 1.02-1.84) were associated with receiving a complete course of ACS. Other factors remaining in the model included maternal medical co-morbidities, white race, and clinical site. CONCLUSIONS: 51% of women with SPTB at 23-34 wks received a complete course of ACS prior to delivery. Decisions regarding ACS timing are complex, and may be influenced by GA, socioeconomic factors, & current pregnancy complications.Further Evidence That the Presence of "Sludge" Does Not Justify the Need for Amniocentesis to Rule Out Infection in Patients withSonographycally Short Cervix. Fereshteh Boozarjomehri, 1 Margaret Dziadosz, 2 Morgan M Peltier, 1 Fatima S Boozarjomehri, 3 Anthony M Vintzileos, 1 Ilan Timor-Tritch, 2 Frederick Naftolin. 2 1 Winthrop UnivHosp, Mineola, NY, USA; 2 New York Univ Sch Med, New York, NY, USA;  3  Swarthmore College, Swarthmore, PA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Previously we found that biomarkers for infection, rates of infection at time of cervical (Cx) cerclage and pregnancy outcomes were similar between patients (pts) with Intra-amniotic "sludge" (IAS), an ultrasound (US) finding of hyperechoic matter in the amniotic fluid (AF) close to internal os, and without IAS. We aim to find if addition of 23 pts to previously presented 41 pts changes the result. METHODS: Records from 64 consecutive pts who underwent MacDonald cerclage between 16-24 6/7 weeks (wks) for sonographycally short Cx (<25mm) from 2007-2015 were reviewed. Pre-cerclage transvaginal US images were evaluated to determine Cx length and presence or absence of IAS. AF was collected at time of cerclage (transabdominal amniocentesis) and evaluated for presence of infection by culture, Gram stain (GS), glucose (Glu), red (RBC) and white blood cell (WBC) count. RESULTS: Cohort of 64 pts with AF studies prior to cervical cerclage were reviewed and results are in table 1. 43%) did not. All culture and GS results were negative. No differences between groups were detected with regard to Glu, RBC or WBC. Pregnancy outcomes were similar for gestational age at delivery, and rates of delivery at <24 <25, <28, <32, <34, and <37 wks. Base line Cx lengths were similar between groups. Cerclage occurred at slightly earlier GA and women were slightly older for IAS Group. CONCLUSIONS: IAS does not indicate presence of infection. In this series of pts with sonographycally short Cx, IAS was not associated with a difference in rate of premature delivery. The presence of IAS in asymptomatic pts with a short Cx at mid-trimester does not constitute an indication for an amniocentesis to rule out IA infection or increased risk for premature birth.

TABREF402.text: Respiratory Morbidity in Pregnancies at Risk for Late Preterm Delivery in Relation to Cord Blood Concentrations of Betamethasone and Cortisol.Cynthia Gyamfi-Bannerman, for the Eunice Kennedy Shriver NICHD MFMU. MFMU, Bethesda, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: Low cord blood fetal cortisol levels are associated with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). An inverse relationship is theorized between betamethasone (BMZ) and cortisone (CTZ) cord blood concentrations. However, the association of BMZ levels with respiratory morbidity (RM) is unknown. Our objective was to assess the relationship of fetal BMZ and CTZ with neonatal RM after late preterm (LP) exposure to BMZ or placebo. METHODS: We measured BMZ phosphate and CTZ levels in cord blood in an ancillary to the Antenatal Late Preterm Steroids trial, a multicenter, double-blind randomized trial of BMZ versus placebo to decrease RM in infants of women at risk for LP delivery (34-36 weeks). Samples were aliquoted, frozen at -80°C, and analyzed in batches. We tested the association between CTZ levels and the adverse composite respiratory primary outcome of the parent trial: continuous positive airway pressure or high flow nasal cannula for ≥2 hrs, oxygen requirement with FiO2≥30% for ≥4 hrs, mechanical ventilation or perinatal death, within 72 hrs of life. We also assessed RDS and transient tachypnea of the newborn in relation to CTZ levels and whether the relationship varied by BMZ level. A Z-test for interaction was used to assess variation by BMZ status. RESULTS: Of 385 women, 184 received placebo and 201 received BMZ. There was an inverse relationship between BMZ and CTZ levels which disappeared after adjusting for time from last dose. There was no association between BMZ level and RM in those exposed to BMZ. For every log unit increase in CTZ*, there was a significant decrease in RM in the placebo group, but not the BMZ group. Delivery mode did not modify this effect.*Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: Decreased fetal CTZ levels are related to adverse respiratory morbidity. Administration of BMZ mitigates these findings.Antenatal Glucocorticoid Administration Alters Cardiac Function in BaboonOffspring. INTRODUCTION:Women threatening premature labor receive glucocorticoids (GC) to accelerate fetal lung maturation. While benefits are well documented, experimental animal studies show that long term effects on offspring remain a concern. In a nonhuman primate model shown to have altered phenotype following fetal GC exposure(Rodriguez  JS et al. Am J Obstetrics. 2011 204 545). We determined long term changes in cardiac function in offspring exposed to GC during fetal life. METHODS: We studied control (CTL, 5 Males, 10 y) and antenatal GC exposed (GC, 5 Males, 10 y) baboons. Maternal baboons received 2 days IM betamethasone (175 µg/kg/day) at 0.6, 0.65, and 0.7 gestation (GC) vs saline (CTL). Offspring cardiac MRI evaluation was performed to evaluate cardiac motion, including tissue tagging sequence for rotational analysis. Data analysed (Harmonic Phase Flow, Interactive and Augmented Modelling Group, UAB, Barcelona, Spain). Student's t test, *p < 0.05. RESULTS: Left ventricular rotation was less in GC vs. CTL in the latter half of systole, most pronounced at the midventricular level(Fig 1; end

TABREF403.text: of Risk Stratification and Fetal Heart Rate (FHR) Interpretation Algorithms for Earlier Intervention (EI) in Cases of Fetal Acidemia.Stephanie Lin, Isaac Esplin, Sean Esplin. Intermountain Healthcare, Murray, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION: The goal of FHR monitoring is to prevent hypoxic injury to the fetus. We sought to determine if the use of risk stratification at admission and FHR interpretation algorithms would result in earlier intervention (EI) in cases of fetal acidemia (pH<7.1). METHODS: Complete FHR tracings were reviewed. Cases and controls were randomly selected from term, singleton deliveries that occurred between 2010-2014 with arterial cord blood gas and ≥2 hours of FHR monitoring. Cases had pH <7.10 without an unpreventable cause of acidemia. Rules for intervention for two FHR interpretation systems (5 Tier (5T) and Clark) were developed. The Holmgren Risk Score (HRS) was applied 1 hr after admit to stratify patients as low risk (LR), moderate risk (MR), or high risk (HR) for pH <7.1. Modified rules for the 5T (M5T) and Clark (MC) algorithms were applied to MR and HR tracings (figure 1). No algorithm was applied to LR patients. Percent of cases identified for EI ≥ 30 min prior to their actual delivery time, false positive rate (FPR), number of additional cesarean deliveries (CD), and number of additional CD per case identified for EI were determined. *Figure(s) will be available online. RESULTS: 265 tracings were reviewed (41 with pH <7.1 and 224 with pH ≥7.1). There were 43 LR, 126 MR, and 96 HR patients.

TABREF404.text: Gene Set Enrichment Investigation into Variation in Clinical Response to Indomethacin (indo) Tocolysis for Threatened SpontaneousPreterm Birth (SPTB). T Manuck, S Watkins, S Esplin, S Parry, H Zhang, H Huang, J Biggio, R Bukowski, G Saade, W Andrews, D Baldwin, Y Sadovsky, U Reddy, J Ilekis, M Varner,M Yandell, L Jorde. GPN, Bethesda, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION:We hypothesized that maternal genotype affects variable response to indo for SPTB tocolysis. METHODS: Secondary analysis of a prospective, multicenter study of SPTB. 46 women w/singleton pregnancies were classified as indo responders (RES) if delivery was ≥2 days after indo or non-responders (NRES) if delivery was w/in 2 days of indo rx. All women were exome sequenced. Sequence variation between RES and NRES was analyzed with the Variant Annotation, Analysis & Search Tool (VAAST) using a recessive inheritance model & locus heterogeneity. Genes scored by VAAST with p<0.05 were then analyzed using (a) Protein Analysis Through Evolutionary Relationships (PANTHER) to assess for over-/ under-representation of gene sets and (b) Database for Annotation, Visualization, and Integrated Discovery (DAVID) to evaluate gene groupings & disease associations. Phenotype Driven Variant Ontological Re-Ranking Tool and GROUPER reclassified genes and evaluated for disease burden; both of these new VAAST algorithms used an established PTB candidate gene list (dbPTB). RESULTS: 29 indo RES were compared w/17 NRES. RES and N-RES had similar genetic ancestry. 755 genes identified by VAAST had p<0.05. PANTHER revealed a higher than expected # of genes in GO groups listed inTable 1after Bonferroni correction.DAVID and GROUPER results are in Tables 2&3. *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: Systematic analysis of maternal exome variation using multiple gene set algorithms identifies enrichment in several pathways & implicates new candidate genes, a first step in applying pharmacogenomics to threatened SPTB.First-Trimester Serum Concentrations of Secreted Frizzled-RelatedProtein 4 Are Increased in Women Who Develop Gestational Diabetes. Joost HN Schuitemaker, 1,2 Edwin van Bloois, 2 Jacqueline E Siljee, 3 Arie Franx, 4 Thomas IFH Cremers, 2,5 Wendy PH Koster. 4 1 University Medical Center Groningen, University of Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands; 2 IQ Products BV, Groningen, Netherlands; 3 National Institute for Public Health and the Environment, Bilthoven, Netherlands; 4 University Medical Center Utrecht, University of Utrecht, Utrecht, Netherlands; 5 University of Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands. INTRODUCTION:Gestational diabetes (GDM) is a major health problem affecting 1-10% of all pregnancies. Risks related to adverse pregnancy outcomes or even possible health issues later in life might be reduced by early screening. We investigated whether secreted frizzledrelated protein 4 (sFRP4), recently identified to play a role in the regulation of glucose resistance, has prognostic value in the first trimester of pregnancy to determine the risk to develop GDM. METHODS: Samples used in this study were derived from women participating in the routine Dutch first-trimester Down syndrome screening between 2011 and 2012. For the current nested case-control study we selected 50 serum samples drawn between 10-12 weeks GA from women who developed GDM and 100 matched women with a healthy pregnancy. The concentration of sFRP4 was determined by ELISA (Pregnostic ® -GDM, IQ Products bv, Groningen, The Netherlands).RESULTS:The median sFRP4 concentration in the GDM group was 91.2 ng/mL versus 93.0 ng/mL in the control group (p=0.0297). Analysis learned that a cut-off value of 130 ng/mL showed the highest OR (3.75; 95%CI 1.72 -8.18) and was indicated as the most optimal cut-off value.program, Centering was not associated with a significant difference in the risk of excess gestational weight gain compared to IPC. Future efforts should determine how to tailor and use group prenatal care to decrease rates of excess gestational weight gain.Gestational Weight Gain, BMI and Pregnancy Outcomes in Obese Pregnant Women in the UPBEAT Behavioural Intervention RCT.Annette Briley, Paul T Seed, Claire Singh, Nashita Patel, Lucilla Poston, UPBEAT Consortium. King's College London, London, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: The UPBEAT RCT (ISRCTN 89971375) evaluated a behavioural intervention in 1555 obese pregnant women (mean BMI 36.3 kg/m 2 ). The intervention led to reduced gestational weight gain (GWG) with no difference in primary maternal (gestational diabetes, GDM by IASPSG criteria), or infant (large for gestational age, LGA) outcomes 1 . The aim of this study is to determine (1) the effect of the intervention on GWG allowing for prepregnancy BMI and (2) association of GWG and key pregnancy outcomes. METHODS: Estimated GWG from pre-pregnancy to 34-36 weeks in the cohort by randomized group was assessed. RESULTS: The intervention did not affect the number of women in the recommended IOM range for GWG but led to an increase in women who lost weight(Table 1). The reduction in GWG was greatest for obesity category III (Interaction test: P=0.005) (Table 2). Table1: GWG in UPBEAT cohort

TABREF405.text: Reduction in GWG due to intervention, by BMI categoryIn control women (n=566), there was no significant association between GWG and LGA (p=0.31), SGA (p= 0.18), pre-eclampsia (p= 0.50), caesarean section (p= 0.34). GWG at 27-28 +6 weeks was not associated with GDM diagnosis; but subsequently treatment for GDM led to reduction in GWG at 34-36 weeks (-2.0 kg, CI 1.2 to 2.8, P<0.0001). CONCLUSIONS: Obese women ≥ 40 kg/m 2 may be most receptive to behavioural intervention. The unexpected lack of association with pregnancy outcomes likely reflects universal GDM testing and effective treatment. The influence of treatment should be considered in guideline development.1.Poston L et al. Lancet Diabetes and Endocrinology 2015;3:767-777. TABREF406.text: Relationship Between Vitamin D Status and PregnancyOutcomes. Veronica T Boyle, 1,2 Eric B Thorstensen, 1 David Mourath, 3 M Beatrix Jones, 4 Lesley ME McCowan, 5 Louise C Kenny,6,7  Philip N Baker. 1,2 1 University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; 2 University of Auckland,Auckland, New Zealand; 3 Linkoping University, Linkoping,  Sweden; 4 Massey University, Auckland, New Zealand; 5  University ofAuckland, Auckland, New Zealand; 6 University College Cork, Cork,  Ireland; 7 University College Cork, Cork, Ireland.  INTRODUCTION:  The main role of vitamin D is to ensure adequate calcium absorption but the nuclear receptor is found in many tissues including the placenta. Rates of Vitamin D insufficiency and deficiency vary with location but affect 50-90% of pregnant women, thus it is important to understand possible effects on maternal and neonatal outcomes. Our aim was to investigate whether serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration in early pregnancy was associated with pregnancy complications. METHODS: Serum samples were collected at 15 weeks' gestation from women in Auckland, NZ who participated in the SCOPE study; a prospective pregnancy cohort of nulliparous women. Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration was analysed by liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry. Pregnancy complications investigated were gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), preeclampsia, spontaneous pre-term birth (SPTB) and small for gestational age (SGA). RESULTS: Samples from 1715 women were analysed. Mean total 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration was 72.9nmol/L (SD 27.0). There was a wide range of concentrations (4.7-176.3 nmol/L). 53.7% of women were vitamin D insufficient (25-hydroxyvitamin D <75 nmol/L) and 18% were vitamin D deficient (25-hydroxyvitamin D <50 nmol/L). In logistic regression analysis a lower 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration was associated with GDM (p=0.03) but this relationship was not significant after correcting for body mass index, ethnicity and season of sampling (p = 0.6). 25-hydroxyvitamin D was not associated with development of preeclampsia (p= 0.2), SPTB (p=0.3) or SGA (p=0.3). CONCLUSIONS: Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentration at 15 weeks' was not associated with later development of GDM, preeclampsia, SPTB or SGA. 25-hydroxyvitamin D concentrations were higher in this New Zealand nulliparous cohort than in many previous cohorts and the incidence of vitamin D deficiency was lower; this may in part explain weak or absent associations. controlled trials of women who were being induced and had modified Bishop scores of 4 or less (Miso-Obs-303 and 004). Subjects were divided into HTNsive disorders of pregnancy and no HTNsive disorder. RESULTS: A total of 1116 women were randomized to receive the DVI; 268 (24%) had HTNsive disorders of pregnancy. The median time to vaginal delivery was 1693 minutes (Q1, Q3: 1112.0, 2333.5) for women with HTNsive disorders of pregnancy and 1335 minutes (Q1, Q3: 861.5, 1847.5) for those with no HTNsive disorder (p<0.0001). The cesarean rate was 31% vs. 25.5% in women with HTNsive disorders of pregnancy and the no HTNsive disorder group, respectively. Data presented as (n)%, except as noted, Wilcoxon Rank Sum used for p value, *p<0.0001 CONCLUSIONS: Preeclampsia and other HTNsive disorders of pregnancy are important factors to consider when counseling patients regarding expectations for a successful labor induction. Our findings suggest that those with HTNsive disorders of pregnancy may have slower labor progress than those with no HTNsive disorder, thus consideration should be given to allow more time to achieve vaginal delivery. However, the benefits of a vaginal delivery should be balanced with the potential risks of prolonged labor in mothers with HTNsive disorders.Is Duration of Balloon Tamponade Associated with PostpartumHemorrhage Outcomes? Brett D Einerson, 1 Moeun Son, 2 Patrick Schneider, 2 Ian Fields, 2 Emily S Miller. 2 1 University of Utah Health Sciences Center, Salt Lake City, UT, USA; 2 Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Chicago, IL, USA. INTRODUCTION:The optimal duration of intrauterine balloon tamponade (IUBT) for the management of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is unknown. We sought to determine whether the duration of IUBT is associated with PPH outcomes. METHODS: A retrospective cohort of women with PPH from 2007-2014 who received IUBT. Women were excluded if the duration of IUBT was ≤2 hours or if hysterectomy was required prior to planned IUBT removal as these represented failures of IUBT. We compared the group of IUBT for 2-12 hours to the group of IUBT for >12 hours. Outcomes included endometritis, estimated blood loss (EBL) after balloon placement, blood transfusion, peripartum hysterectomy, uterine artery embolization, intensive care unit (ICU) admission, and length of hospital stay. Univariable and multivariable analyses were used. RESULTS: 274 women with PPH met inclusion criteria. Women with IUBT >12 hours were more likely to have undergone cesarean (57% vs. 38%, P=0.008), but other risk factors for PPH (maternal age, grand multiparity, placenta previa, induction/augmentation of labor, and chorioamnionitis) and EBL prior to IUBT placement did not differ between the groups. IUBT >12 hours was associated with a higher rate of endometritis (27% v. 15%, P=0.047), a higher rate of transfusion (74.4% v. 59.3%, P<0.028), and a longer mean hospital stay (3.7 days vs. 3.1 days, P=0.002). Other morbidities including EBL after balloon placement, UAE, hysterectomy, and ICU admission, were not different between the groups. After adjusting for potential confounding, the associations between IUBT >12 hours and endometritis, transfusion, and hospital stay were no longer present.CONCLUSIONS:There are no differences in clinical outcomes associated with IUBT duration beyond 12 hours compared to removal at or prior to 12 hours.Second Stage Length and Third and Fourth Degree LacerationsAmong Nulliparous Women. Mariam Naqvi, Allison Bryant, Anjali Kaimal. Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA. INTRODUCTION: This study was undertaken to examine the relationship between the length of the second stage of labor and third and fourth degree lacerations among term nulliparas.

Magnetic Resonance Imaging for the Diagnosis of Morbidly Adherent Placenta: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis.Bradley D Holbrook, Nathan R Blue, Pranita A Nirgudkar, Ellen L Mozurkewich. University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA. INTRODUCTION: Placenta accreta, increta, and percreta, collectively known as morbidly adherent placenta (MAP), lead to significant maternal morbidity and mortality due to abnormal invasion of the chorionic villi into the myometrium. Its prevalence is increasing as the incidence of cesarean delivery rises. Both ultrasound (US) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) have been employed to identify this condition prenatally. Our objective is to compare the test characteristics of US versus MRI in the diagnosis of morbidly adherent placenta. METHODS: We performed a search of the Medline, EMbase, and Cochrane databases using a variety of search terms and combinations. Search results were crosschecked against the reference list of a prior systematic review and other review articles germane to the topic to ensure completeness. We evaluated English language, full-text studies; these were included only if they included blinded interpretations of both US and MRI in each study patient, and if the diagnosis of MAP was confirmed by intraoperative or pathologic findings. We computed the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) with 95% confidence intervals (95% CI) of US and MRI. RESULTS: 520 studies were identified with our initial search; review of reference lists from other reviews added an additional 95 studies, for a total of 615. Titles and abstracts were reviewed, and relevant titles were read in detail. Seven studies met criteria for inclusion, with a total of 276 patients. Sensitivities for US and MRI were 82.8% and 67.6%, specificities were 75.3% and 71.5%, PPVs were 76.1% and 70.9%, and NPVs were 88.9% and 76.4%, respectively(table 1).CONCLUSIONS:Both US and MRI are moderately sensitive and specific for the diagnosis of morbid adherent placenta. These two testsSaturday Postersappear essentially equivalent. Compared to US, MRI does not offer significant improvement in test characteristics to predict morbidly adherent placenta.Pregnancy Following Letrozole Treatment in Infertile Women with PCOS or Unexplained Infertility Has Low Risk of CongenitalAnomalies and Serious Adverse Events. Esther Eisenberg, 1 Michael P Diamond, 2 Richard S Legro, 3 Hao Huang, 4 Heping Zhang, 4 Reproductive Medicine Network. 1 1 Eunice Kennedy Shriver NICHD, Bethesda, MD, USA; 2 Augusta University, Augusta, GA, USA; 3 Penn State University College of Medicine, Hershey, PA, USA; 4 Yale School of Public Health, New Haven, CT, USA.INTRODUCTION: Prospectively collected data on pregnancy outcomes and risk of congenital anomalies in conceptions following exposure to medications for ovarian stimulation is sparce. Patients and clinicians need reliable information to aid in selecting appropriate treatment. Letrozole is approved for the adjuvant treatment of breast cancer and is used off label to stimulate ovulation in infertile women. Key issues for the use of letrozole are pregnancy outcomes and risk of teratogenicity. METHODS: We sought to identify adverse effects of ovarian stimulation with letrozole compared to clomiphene citrate (CC) or gonadotropins (Gn) on pregnancy outcomes in an observational cohort of infertile women who conceived in the PPCOSII and AMIGOS clinical trials conducted by the Reproductive Medicine Network. Data on pregnancy loss, pregnancy related complications and congenital anomalies were collected prospectively. Statistical analysis was with chi-square or Fisher's exact test for categorical data; for continuous data, Wilcoxon rank-sum test was used to test differences between two groups and Kruksal-Wallis test to test differences among groups of three or more. RESULTS: A total of 572 pregnancies were conceived with medical treatment: 232 with letrozole, 201 with CC, 139 with Gn, and 18 were conceived spontaneously. Baseline characteristics were comparable in all treatment groups. Outcomes of pregnancy loss, serious adverse events, antenatal and post-partum complication and congenital anomaly rates were comparable among the groups, though hyperemesis and mixed pregnancy (loss+live birth) were significantly increased in the Gn group, and gestational diabetes was significantly increased in pregnancies conceived with letrozole and CC. Congenital anomalies occurred in 3% of all deliveries with no difference among treatment groups. CONCLUSIONS: Ovarian stimulation with letrozole is associated with comparable pregnancy outcomes as CC and similar low risk of congenital anomalies as other medications used for ovarian stimulation.Severe Maternal Morbidity and Associated Risk Factors During Delivery Hospitalization in Large Teaching Hospitals in the UnitedStates, Australia and England, 2007-2013. Heather S Lipkind, 1 Ellie B Turner, 2 Jess Collins, 2 Radek Bukowski, 1 Katherine Campbell. 1 1 Yale University, New Haven, CT, USA; 2 Dr. Foster, London, United Kingdom. INTRODUCTION: The Dr. Foster Global Comparators (GC) Project is an international hospital network created in 2011 as a global benchmarking collaborative.This study utilized the GC database to identify pregnancy complications and related risk factors that led to severe maternal morbidity (SMM) during delivery hospitalizations in large university based hospitals in the United States, Australia and England. METHODS: Data from delivery hospitalizations between the years 2007-2013 were identified using the GC database. We utilized hospitalizations with maternal diagnoses and procedures that indicated a possible life-threatening diagnosis or a life-saving procedure using published algorithms from the Center for Disease Control. The frequency of SMM was calculated for each country. Multivariable analysis was used to examine the association between SMM and patient characteristics within each country.RESULTS: From 2007-2013 there were a total of 606,813 deliveries including 54.5% from England, 30.8% from the US, and 14.7% from Australia. These deliveries came from eighteen hospitals. The overall SMM rate was 8.2 per 1000 deliveries; 15.6 in the US, 8.2 in Australia and 5.0 in England. Most women that were classified as having a severe morbidity had codes for DIC, renal failure, hysterectomy, maternal cardiac disease and eclampsia. For all countries advanced maternal age, hypertension, diabetes and substance abuse were significantly predictive of SMM with hypertension having the strongest association (aOR [95% CI]; US 4.56 [3.86-5.39], Australia 7.90 [3.18-19.67] and England 11.70 [5.76-23.78]). CONCLUSIONS: Severe maternal morbidity was identified in large hospitals in all three countries but the rates differed by country. The predictors of adverse outcomes were consistent regardless of location. Exploring the differences in facility and country based care could help modify practice and improve obstetrical outcomes.Effects of Body Mass Index on the In Vitro Fertilization Outcomes inPatients with Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome: A Meta-Analysis. Juan Qian, 1 Wenjie Zhou, 2 Danhua Pu, 2 Jie Wu. 2 1 Shengze Hospital of Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing, China; 2 The First Affiliated Hospital of Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing, China. INTRODUCTION: To study the effects of body mass index (BMI) on in vitro fertilization/intracytoplasmic sperm injection (IVF/ICSI) outcomes in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) patients. METHODS: We searched for all published articles indexed in PubMed

TABREF411.text: Neonatal Outcomes Among Pregnancies Complicated by IntrahepaticCholestasis (ICP) According to Bile Acid Level. Christina A Herrera, 1 Vickie Baer, 1 Robert M Silver, 1 Michael W Varner, 1 Alexandra G Eller, 1 Tracy A Manuck. 1,2 1 University of Utah & Intermountain Healthcare, Salt Lake City, UT, USA; 2 University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, USA. INTRODUCTION:Bile acids are commonly used to diagnose and risk stratify ICP. We sought to compare neonatal outcomes by bile acid level. METHODS: Retrospective cohort of women suspected to have ICP with bile acid data. Women were stratified by maximum bile acid: <11 µmol/L (normal, no ICP), 11-40 µmol/L (mild ICP), 40-80 µmol/L (moderate ICP), and ≥80 µmol/L (severe ICP). Delivery gestational age, birth depression, and neonatal morbidity (any: HIE, NEC, BPD, IVH grade 3/4, death) were compared. For multiple gestations, the worst outcome was studied. RESULTS: 789 women were included. 327 had normal bile acids, 321 had mild, 91 had moderate, and 50 had severe elevation. Demographic characteristics were similar between groups. Additional clinical variables are shown in theTable.Rates of morbidity, birth depression, and delivery gestational age are shown in theFigure.There were 2 stillbirths, 1 in the mild and 1 in the moderate group. 189 women (24%) delivered preterm. In limited regression models controlling for gestational age, severe bile acid elevation remained associated with severe neonatal morbidity (aOR 5.7, 95% CI 1.2-26.5, p=0.027). CONCLUSIONS: Delivery gestational age was inversely related to bile acid elevation. Neonates delivered to women with severe bile acid elevation had higher rates of severe neonatal morbidity.Marijuana Use in Pregnant Teens Before and After Legalization.Christina E Rodriguez, 1 Jeanelle Sheeder, 1 Torri D Metz.1,2 1 University of Colorado, Aurora, CO, USA; 2 Denver Health Medical Center, Denver, CO, USA. INTRODUCTION: The legalization of recreational and medical marijuana is increasing across the United States. Despite marijuana dispensaries only selling to adults above 21 years of age, we hypothesized that marijuana use in pregnant teenagers would increase after legalization in Colorado.

Similarly, among women with thyroid autoimmunity, there were no differences in likelihood of preterm delivery (RR 1.27; 95% CI 0.65, 2.46), gestational diabetes (RR 1.41; 95% CI 0.54, 3.69), or preeclampsia (RR 1.07; 95% CI 0.56, 2.03). CONCLUSIONS: Among women with 1 to 2 prior pregnancy losses with SCH, or thyroid autoantibodies there was no increased risk of preterm delivery, gestational diabetes or preeclampsia. It's All About the Head (Circumference): Head Circumference vs. Birth Weight as a Risk Factor for Vacuum Extraction Failure. Doron Kabiri, Michal Lipschuetz, Sarah M Cohen, Oren Yagel, Lorinne Levitt, Shmuel Herzberg, Yossef Ezra, Simcha Yagel, Hagai Amsalem. Hadassah Hebrew Medical Centre, Jerusalem, Israel. INTRODUCTION:Vacuum extraction (VE) fails in 6-9% of trials; nulliparity, fetal macrosomia, and occipitoposterior presentation are among the reported risk factors for failed VE. We have previously shown that large fetal head circumference (HC) is an independent risk factor for vacuum delivery. The aim of this study was to determine whether large HC increased the risk of VE failure as compared to high fetal birth weight (BW). METHODS: This EMR-based study included all attempted VE performed in a tertiary center between January 2010 and December 2012. All term singleton live births were eligible. We assessed the risk of failed vacuum extraction in cases with HC≥95 th centile (Large HC) vs. those with HC<95 th centile (Normal HC) and BW≥95 th centile (Large BW) vs. those with BW<95 th centile (Normal BW). Other neonatal and maternal parameters were also evaluated as potential risk factors. Cases were divided into 4 groups according to HC and BW(Table 1). Multinomial multivariable regression provided adjusted odds ratio (aOR) for vacuum extraction failure while controlling for potential confounders. RESULTS: During the study period 24,800 deliveries met inclusion criteria, of which 1,834 had vacuum extraction attempt. We identified 117 cases of vacuum extraction failure, for failure rate of 6.4%. The aOR for vacuum extraction failure in cases of large HC was 2.61 (95% CI 1.58-4.30 P<0.001), while high BW was not significant. Primiparity and occipito-posterior presentation were also found to be significant risk factors for failed VE.CONCLUSIONS:Large HC is significantly associated with risk of failed VE, while high BW is not. In addition to known risk factors we propose that fetal HC measured in the last week before delivery may contribute to the decision whether or not to attempt vacuum extraction.Penetrating Trauma in Pregnancy. This study describes penetrating injuries in pregnant patients and examines patients with admission SBP < 90mmHg to determine if this predicts poor maternal and pregnancy outcomes. TABREF425.text: Levels of Soluble Immune Mediators Do Not Vary According to Ethnicity in Mothers of Infants Affected by Anti-Ro MediatedCongenital Heart Block. Shilpi Mehta-Lee, 1 Robert Clancy, 2 Judith James, 3 Jill Buyon. 4 1 New York Univ. LangoneMed. Ctr., New York, NY,  USA; 2 NYU Langone Med. Ctr., New York, NY, USA; 3  Univ. of Oklahoma Hlth. Sci. Ctr., Oklahoma City, OK, USA. INTRODUCTION: Anti-Ro autoantibodies are associated with congenital heart block (CHB) in 2% of women who carry them. Identifying mediators that may alter fetal response to anti-Ro may identify fetuses at risk of CHB and risk of demise. This study aimed to understand if the levels of immune mediators in women with CHB varied by ethnic group. METHODS: Soluble immune mediators (N= 32) (cytokines, chemokines, soluble receptors) were examined using validated multiplex bead-based (xMAP) or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays in serum from a cohort of 36 anti-Ro+ women with CHB complicated pregnancies. Autoantibodies were measured by Bio-Rad Bioplex ANA2200 and recombinant/native Ro60/52 proteins by ELISA. Univariate and multivariate regression compared levels between women with infants with CHB identifying as non-Hispanic white versus ethnic minorities. RESULTS: Levels of soluble mediators were examined in women identifying as non-hispanic white (n=28) versus other (n=8). Levels of 32 immune mediators between mothers (NH white versus all minorities) whose infants were affected by CHB were not significantly different.CONCLUSIONS:We found no evidence that that ethnicity affects results of soluble immune mediators. Further research to understand if demographic factors affect immune mediators, or predict the severity of CHB is warranted.
