TABREF437.text: Immunological and Inflammatory Response After Antenatal Supplementation with Lactobacillus Rhamnosus in Low-RiskPregnant Women. Bo Jacobsson, 1 Verena Sengpiel, 1 Staffan Nilsson, 2 Maria Hallingstrom, 1 Anders Elfvin, 3 Anne-Lise Brantsaeter, 4 Mahsa Nordquist, 1 Ronny Myhre, 4 Teresa Cobo. 1 1 Sahlgrenska Academy, University of Gothenburg, Gothenburg, Sweden; 2 Chalmers University, Gothenburg, Sweden; 3 Sahlgrenska Academy, University of Gothenburg, Gothenburg, Sweden; 4 Institute of Public Health, Oslo, Norway. INTRODUCTION:The obsjective was to evaluate whether supplementation with Lactobacillus rhamnosus (LGG) in low-risk pregnant women interfere on maternal immunological or inflammatory response. METHODS: Interventional study. Low-risk women randomized at week 8-10 of pregnancy to supplementation with LGG (10 8 CFU) or placebo until delivery. Maternal blood was sampled at recruitment, at weeks 25 and 35. Fluorescence activated cell-scanning analysis; FOXP3 colouring and Toll-like receptor stimulation with Lactobacillus plantarum, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) was used to evaluate the response of 26 parameters. Variables were log transformed and data presented with geometric mean and geometric standard deviation. Baseline values and changes from baseline were compared with two sample t-tests. RESULTS: Twenty women included in each arm. There were not differences on maternal characteristics, inflammatory or immunological parameters either before treatment or at weeks 25 and 35.

TABREF442.text: Blood Levels of Placental Growth Factor: A Novel Biomarker for the Identification of Fetal Growth Restriction. Zoe A Broere-Brown, 1 Sarah Schalekamp-Timmermans, 1 Vincent WV Jaddoe, 2,3 Eric AP Steegers. 1 1 Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, Netherlands; 2 Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, Netherlands; 3 Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, Netherlands. INTRODUCTION:Distinction between fetuses who are growth restricted (FGR) from those who are not is vital. In this study we assessed whether cord blood levels of placental growth factor (PLGF) can serve as a tool to retrospectively identify fetal growth restriction.METHODS:This study was embedded in the Generation R study, a large prospective population based cohort study. Live singletons with data available concerning fetal growth and cord blood PLGF levels were included (n=3462). To adjust for gestational age PLGF multiple of the median (MoM) values were calculated. Using repeated measurements analyses growth curves of neonates with a PLGF MoM level <p10 were compared with neonates with a PLGF MoM level >p10. RESULTS: Median PLGF MoM level was 1.0 (3.2). Neonates with a PLGF MoM level <p10 (i.e. 0.67) showed a significantly different fetal growth pattern (p < 0.01) showing a deviation from the growth curve from approximately 30 weeks of gestation onwards. This resulted in a significantly lower birthweight of 0.58 SD (90% range 0.46-0.70, p<0.001) and an increased risk for a deviating growth curve of ≥30 percentiles ( OR 1.60, 95% CI 1.21-2.11, p<0.01). CONCLUSIONS: Cord blood PLGF might be a promising biomarker in retrospectively determine fetal growth restriction.Impaired Glucose and Lipid Metabolism in Fetal GrowthRestriction Placenta. In 30 wk female soleus muscle (m) we measured area under the curve of peak force isometric contraction to electrical stimulation (PF AUC), and GLUT-4, insulin receptor (IR) and IRsubstrate-1 (IRS-1) mRNA by PCR. Analysis: ANOVA / linear regression. RESULTS: E16 dam [25(OH)D3] pl was higher in PRE HF compared to control (30.0±4.6 vs. 63.0±10.4 nmol/L, p<0.05). [25(OH)D3] pl was higher in 30 wk POST HF mice, regardless of PRE diet (p<0.01). Soleus m.GLUT-4 and IR mRNA levels were reduced in POST HF mice regardless of PRE diet (p<0.05). Lower soleus PF AUC was associated with lower [25(OH)D3] pl in C/C (B=3074, p<0.01, R 2 =0.80) and C/HF (trend) mice. But greater peak contractile force was associated with lower [25(OH)D3] pl in HF/C mice (B=-1287, p<0.05, R 2 =0.53), and no association in HF/HF mice. In HF/C mice, greater PF AUC was associated with greater IRS-1 mRNA levels (B=3.57Xe -5 , p<0.05, R 2 =0.55). CONCLUSIONS: Reduced GLUT-4 and InsR mRNA in POST HF mice may mediate in part the glucose intolerance previously observed in this model. Maternal CD8+ T Cell Depletion Prevents Inflammation-Induced Perinatal Brain Injury. Jason Rosenzweig, 1 Jun Lei, 1 Wael Alshehri, 1 Nader Alhejaily, 1 Wenyu Zhong, 1 Michael McLane, 1 Andrea Facciabene, 2 Irina Burd. 1,3 1 JHU SOM, Baltimore, MD, USA; 2 University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA; 3 JHU SOM, Baltimore, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: Divergent mechanisms contribute to preterm birth and the associated adverse neurologic sequelae in offspring. In prior studies, lipopolysaccharide (LPS) was shown to increase CD8 T cell infiltration in placenta. We sought to determine the mechanisms by which CD8 T cells contribute to perinatal brain injury by studying the effect of CD8 depletion on adverse neurologic outcomes. METHODS: To deplete CD8 T cells, 200 mg anti-CD8 antibody was administered to CD-1 dams intraperitoneally (IP) at E14 and E16. Dams were randomly assigned to five groups: saline (NS), LPS (25 mg intrauterine (IU), LPS + CD8 depletion (LPS+DEP), NS + CD8 deletion (NS+DEP), and no surgery (Control) (N = 4-6 dams per group). Flow cytometry of placenta and maternal serum, and histology (Nissl staining) of fetal/perinatal brain regions were performed. Preterm birth and neurodevelopment in offspring were assessed. Immune profiling of placentas was performed. RESULTS: While DEP did not prevent LPS-induced preterm birth (p>0.05), LPS+DEP significantly improved negative geotaxis neurobehavioral test performance over LPS exposure ( Figure; p<0.001). LPS+DEP significantly improved cortical neuronal density compared to LPS exposure (Table; p<0.05). CD8 depletion was confirmed by flow cytometry on maternal serum and placentas. We are monitoring cervical changes during pregnancy with shear wave elasticity methods. We previously reported that cervical ripening with misoprostol had considerably smaller effect on shear wave speed (SWS) in the rhesus macaque cervix vs the human. Our objective here was to determine if we could detect changes in viscoelasticity of the cervix by using a more robust SWS estimation method and accounting for microstructural differences between the macaque and human cervix. METHODS: Ultrasound SWS estimation was performed on ex vivo cervices of 13 misoprostol-ripened and 14 control (unripened) macaques undergoing necropsy for reasons unrelated to our study. SWS estimates were made along the cervix from the internal os to the transition zone between the distal end of the macaque cervix (bulbous with serpentine canal) and the proximal end (cylindrical with straight canal, like human). Cervical stiffness and viscosity were assessed with SWS and the slope of a linear model to the frequency dependence of the shear wave phase velocity vs. frequency, respectively. RESULTS: A gradual increase in SWS was observed along the cervix from the internal os to the transition zone. Average SWS in the ripened group (6.3m/s) was slower (indicating softer tissue) than in the unripened (7.4m/s). This difference of 1.1 m/s is similar to that observed in the S-093 In women with premature cervical shortening, cervical stretching starts at the internal os, which may be seen on ultrasound as a cervical funnel. We sought to construct patient-specific 3D finite element (FE) computer simulation models of the pregnant uterus and cervix to understand how anatomical and tissue mechanical factors influence cervical tissue stretch and shortening. METHODS: We generated FE models (FeBio 2.3.1) using a custom computer script (Trelis Pro 15.1.3) based on input parameters from transabdominal and transperineal ultrasound measurements (GE Voluson E8). For the baseline model, uterine diameter, uterine thickness, cervical length, cervical diameter, and cervical angle with anterior lower uterine segment (LUS) were measured for a 35 y/o normal P0 patient at 21 weeks (Fig.1A&B ). Cervical angle was ranged from 90 to 110 degrees from the anterior LUS ( Fig.1B-D) . The uterus and cervix were modeled as collagenous composite materials, and the fetal membrane as a nonlinear hyperelastic material. Intrauterine pressure was applied over the physiological range for 21 weeks (0 to 1 kPa), and the cervical stretch at the internal os was evaluated. RESULTS: The cervical angle of 90° with respect to the anterior LUS has the lowest simulated stretch concentration at the cervix internal os. Maximum tissue stretch and percent surface area of cervix above a 10% stretch threshold both increase directly with cervical angle (Fig.1B-D) . *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: Cervical angle is a critical factor contributing to internal os tissue stretch. As cervical angle deviates from 90° with respect to the anterior LUS, simulated cervical stretch increases. These results may explain how mechanical therapies such as a pessary change cervical angle and may contribute to the prevention of preterm birth. We therefore aimed to examine how labour-like cord occlusions with worsening acidemia alter BRS in dependence on preexistent hypoxia. METHODS: Near-term ovine fetuses were chronically instrumented with catheters, electrodes and inflatable cord occluders. Normoxic (N/UCO, N=9) and hypoxic (H/UCO, N=5) fetuses had average arterial O2Sat prior to UCOs of > or < than 55%, respectively. All animals were subjected to UCOs of 1 min duration every 2.5 min with increasing occlusion strength as repetitive mild (1 h), moderate (1 h), and severe (up to 2 h) UCO series or until fetal arterial pH was < 7.00. Blood pressure (BP) was continuously recorded and spontaneous BRS indices were calculated at baseline (60 min) and for each of the UCO series (20 min segments) (cf. doi: 10.1139/ y09-070). Results are presented as means ± SEM for p<0.05.

Trends in the Route of Delivery of Twin Pregnancies in the United States, 2006 -2013. Zhoobin Bateni, 1,2 Steven Clark, 1,2 Alex Vidaeff, 1,2 Amir Moaddab, 1,2 Gary Dildy, 1,2 Bahram Salmanian, 1,2 Pardis Hosseinzadeh, 1,2 Susan Ramin, 1,2 Karin Fox, 1,2 Wesley Lee, 1,2 Henry Lee, 4 Jimmy Espinoza, 1,2 Haleh Sangi-haghpeykar, 1,2 Diana Racusin, 1,2 Amir Shamshirsaz, 1,2 Yair Blumenfield, 3 Kjersti Aagaard, 1,2 Michael Belfort, 1,2 Alireza Shamshirsaz. 1 The rate of cesarean delivery in twin pregnancies peaked at 75.3% in 2009, and was significantly lower (74.8%) in 2013 (p=0.003). Cesarean rates in nulliparous twin deliveries were higher than the total cesarean rates and increased from 75% in 2006 to a peak of 78% in 2013. *Figure(s) will be available online. Cesarean delivery for twins in which one fetus presented as breech peaked at 92.18% in 2010, falling slightly but significantly in the ensuing 3 years. Our data demonstrated that the decrease in the cesarean delivery rate to be exclusively due to fewer cesareans in non-Hispanic white patients (p<0.001).The rate of vaginal birth after cesarean in twin pregnancies remains under 5%. CONCLUSIONS: The recent decrease in the cesarean delivery rate in twin gestation was happened for the first time after three decades and appears to be largely attributable to a decline in cesareans among multiparous women and pregnancies complicated by breech presentation in non-Hispanic white women, and may reflect a health care disparity that deserves further research.

Elevated Red Cell Distribution Width Is Associated with Adverse Obstetric Outcomes. Lauren Theilen, 1,2 Benjamin Horne, 3 M Sean Esplin. 1,2 1 University of Utah Health Science Center, Salt Lake City, UT, USA; 2 Intermountain Healthcare, Salt Lake City, UT, USA; 3 Intermountain Healthcare, Salt Lake City, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Elevation in the red cell distribution width (RDW), a quantitative measure of anisocytosis, predicts increased mortality risk for a variety of cardiovascular, pulmonary, and other chronic diseases in non-obstetric populations. We aim to determine whether an elevated RDW during pregnancy is associated with adverse obstetric outcomes. METHODS: We identified all women in a single healthcare system with a singleton delivery between 2005-2015 and >1 complete blood count drawn during pregnancy. We included the RDW drawn at 2 time points (T1 at < 20 weeks and T2 from 21 weeks through 1 week prior to delivery). Outcomes considered included hypertensive disease of pregnancy (HDP), preterm birth (PTB), mean gestational age at delivery (GAD), mode of delivery, neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) admission, maternal length of stay after delivery (mLOS), and neonatal length of stay after delivery (nLOS). The frequency of each outcome was reported as percent per RDW quartile. Odds ratios were calculated for the 4 th quartile compared to the 1 st quartile, and p-values were calculated for the trend across quartiles. RESULTS: We identified 139,425 women with an RDW at T1 and 54,297 women with an RDW at T2. The association of an increased RDW with obstetric outcomes is described in Table 1 . At both time points, increasing RDW was associated with an increased risk for HDP, cesarean, NICU admission, greater mLOS, and greater nLOS. Women with an elevated RDW at T2, but not at T1, had an increased incidence of preeclampsia and spontaneous PTB. CONCLUSIONS: Elevated RDW was associated with adverse obstetric outcomes, perhaps due to stress, inflammation, or hypoxemia during pregnancy. Further investigation of the predictive value of these findings is warranted. *Figure(s) will be available online.

Mode of Delivery for Gastroschisis. Alexander M Friedman, Cande V Ananth, Zainab Siddiq, Mary E D'Alton, Jason D Wright. Columbia University, New York, NY, USA. INTRODUCTION: The objective of this study evaluating pregnancies complicated by gastroschisis was to determine the proportion of women undergoing planned cesarean versus attempted vaginal delivery. METHODS: This population-based study of U.S. natality records from 2005-2013 evaluated pregnancies complicated by gastroschisis. Women were classified based on whether they attempted vaginal delivery or underwent planned cesarean. Obstetric, medical, and demographic characteristics were evaluated. Multivariable log-linear regression models were developed to determine factors associated with mode of delivery. RESULTS: Of 5,985 pregnancies with gastroschisis, 63.5% (n=3,800) attempted vaginal delivery and 36.5% (n=2,185) underwent planned cesarean delivery. The rate of attempted vaginal delivery increased from 59.7% in 2005 to 68.8% in 2013 (FIGURE) . Earlier gestational age and Hispanic ethnicity were associated with lower rates of attempted vaginal delivery. These factors retained significance in the adjusted log-linear model. CONCLUSIONS: Attempted vaginal delivery is becoming increasingly prevalent for women with a pregnancy complicated by gastroschisis. Recommendations from research literature findings may be diffusing into clinical practice. A significant proportion of women with this anomaly still deliver by planned cesarean suggesting further reduction of surgical delivery for this anomaly is possible. *Figure(s) will be available online. For most uncomplicated pregnancies in the United States, a healthcare visit 4 to 6 weeks postpartum is recommended to assess maternal health, and is an opportunity to promote wellness and establish preventive care. Although postpartum data are limited, there are concerns that compliance with postpartum visits may be suboptimal. We studied whether pregnancy and delivery factors such as prenatal care, severity of maternal and newborn conditions, and sociodemographic characteristics were related to the likelihood of not having a postpartum visit. METHODS: We conducted a cross-sectional analysis of 64,952 women who completed the U.S. Centers for Disease Control Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System (PRAMS) Phase 6 survey in 2009-2011 from 17 states and NYC that included a Yes/No question about receiving a maternal postpartum checkup. We calculated chi-square tests, t-tests, and risk ratios (RR) with 95% confidence intervals (CI) using SAS software to study the association between maternal factors and lack of a postpartum visit. RESULTS: Compared to women who attended a postpartum visit, women who missed the visit were younger, more likely to be unmarried, less-educated, with lower income, without insurance, and smokers (all p<0.001). Newborn complications resulted in noncompliance with the postpartum visit, as mothers of preterm newborns (p<0.001) and newborns in the NICU at birth (p<0.001) were more likely to fail to attend a postpartum visit. Lack of other medical care was also related to noncompliance. Compared to women with adequate prenatal care, those with intermediate (RR: 1.79 (95% CI: 1.70-1.88)) or inadequate (RR: 2.71 (95% CI: 2.53-2.91) care were more likely to be noncompliant. Women who delivered at home and whose newborns were never hospitalized were more than twice as likely to not attend a postpartum visit (both CONCLUSIONS: We show here that a serum sFRP4 concentration higher than 130 ng/mL in the first trimester of pregnancy is associated with an almost four-fold higher risk to develop GDM later in pregnancy.

Increased Betatrophin and WISP1 Levels in Gestational Diabetes. Gulcin Sahin Ersoy, 1 Tugba Altun Ensari, 2 Ozge Cevik. 3 1 Kartal Dr. Lutfi Kirdar Education and Research Hospital, Istanbul, Turkey; 2 Etlik Zubeyde Hanim Education and Research Hospital, Ankara, Turkey; 3 Cumhuriyet University, Faculty of Pharmacy, Sivas, Turkey. INTRODUCTION: Betatrophin and WISP1 have recently been introduced as novel adipokines. They play a role in the regulation of glucose homeostasis and lipid metabolism. The aim of this study was to compare serum levels of betatrophin and WISP1 in healthy non-pregnant women and pregnant women with gestational diabetes and normal glucose tolerance. METHODS: Circulating WISP1 and betatrophin were measured in 52 pregnant women with GDM (GDM group) and 60 body mass index matched pregnant women with normal glucose tolerance (Non-GDM group) as well as 51 healty age matched non-pregnant women (Control group) by ELISA.RESULTS: WISP1 levels were significantly increased in patients with GDM compared to Non-GDM and Control groups (p<0.001). Similarly, betatrophin levels were increased in GDM group when compared to Non-GDM and Control groups (p<0.001). As well as, betatrophin levels were significantly higher in Non-GDM group than Control group (p<0.001)

back_matter.text: Non-GDM Control P The Institute of Medicine (IOM) recommends all obese pregnant women gain 5-9kg of weight to optimize pregnancy outcomes, regardless of obesity classification. The UK Better Eating an Activity Trial (UPBEAT: ISCRTN 89971375) 1 randomized women to a dietary and physical activity intervention or standard antenatal care. In this cohort there was no association between gestational weight gain (GWG) and key adverse outcomes (gestational diabetes, cesarean section, pre-eclampsia) apart from birthweight (BW). We devised a novel method to estimate appropriate GWG based on BW centiles. METHODS: GWG from pre-pregnancy weight was estimated in control women. BW were converted to World Health Organisation (WHO) centiles, and to Z-scores. Linear regression was used to predict BW Z-scores from BMI class and GWG. As the centiles are based on a healthy normal population, a mean Z-score of 0 can be regarded as healthy. This also maximises the number of appropriately grown for gestational age (AGA) neonates with BW within the 10 th and 90 th centiles. Appropriate GWG was calculated for for all women and for BMI obesity classes I (30-34.9 kg/m 2 ) II (35-39.9), and III (≥40) by setting the expected average to 0; with Confidence Intervals by the delta method. RESULTS: Complete data was available for 566 women in the control arm. The mean BW Z-score was .0459×gestational weight gain -.208 (class I), -.201 (class II), -.129 (class III). Appropriate GWG was estimated as .208/.0459=4.53 (class I) and similarly for other classes.

In the UPBEAT obese cohort, a smaller GWG (2-6 kg) than IOM recommendation may be appropriate to maximise the number of AGA neonates. This analysis does not consider other major outcomes, such as caesarean section or gestational diabetes. An additional advantage of this method is that keeping BW and GWG as continuous measures greatly increases the statistical power of standard analyses. The analysis provides a novel approach to assessment of optimal weight gain. It should be repeated in a large unselected cohort of obese and non-obese pregnant women. The goal of this study is to determine whether group prenatal care, delivered through the Centering Pregnancy®(Centering) model, is associated with a decreased risk of excess gestational weight gain compared to individual prenatal care (IPC).

This was a retrospective cohort study of women who received prenatal care at UCSF Medical Center and delivered between July 2011 and December 2014. Women self-selected participation in Centering or IPC. Inclusion criteria were: age 18-45, singleton pregnancy with no fetal anomalies, lack of significant chronic medical problems, such as pre-gestational diabetes, enrollment in prenatal care by 20 weeks, and attendance at ≥ 5 prenatal visits of their chosen prenatal care type. Demographics, self-reported pre-pregnancy weight and body mass index (BMI), and maternal weight at the time of delivery were collected from the medical record. Excess gestational weight gain was defined by the 2009 Institute of Medicine (IOM) guidelines based on a woman's prepregnancy BMI. The student's t-test, chi-squared test, and multivariate linear and logistic regression were then performed, where appropriate. RESULTS: 2,998 women were included: 125 in Centering and 2,873 in IPC. The groups were similar with regard to maternal age (mean 33.0 years), race (50.8% Caucasian and 24.7% Asian), and pre-pregnancy BMI (23.8 mg/kg2) (p >0.05). There was no significant difference in the proportion of women who gained excess gestational weight between Centering and IPC (46.4 vs 43.3%, p=0.49). When controlling for confounding factors, such as maternal age, race, starting BMI, and gestational diabetes, there was no significant difference in the risk of gaining excess gestational weight (OR 0.92, CI 0.62-1.34) or in the mean amount of excess weight gained (9.8 vs 10.3 lbs, p =0.39) between Centering and IPC. CONCLUSIONS: Although self-empowerment and group discussion of nutrition, diet, and exercise are components of Centering's prenatal Increased lipogenesis results from transcriptional activation of many genes in the liver including ACCα,which catalyzes carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, the rate-limiting step in fatty acid synthesis. In humans, the ACACA gene encodes ACCα. We hypothesized that upregulation of ACACA expression and fatty acid synthesis in the livers of fetuses of MO ewes would contribute to the previously reported increases in organ and tissue adiposity observed in these offspring. Objective: To determine if increased fetal liver ACCα expression contributed to the increased adiposity of MO offspring, and investigate ACACA gene methylation changes as a potential contributor to expression changes.

Council (NRC) recommendations, n=7) and controls (CTR; fed 100% of NRC, n=7) were collected at necropsy on d135 of gestation. Fetal liver tissue was snap frozen on liquid nitrogen and stored at -80ºC. RNA-Seq reads were aligned to the Ovis aries v3.1 reference genome using STAR and read counts per gene were generated by HTSeq. Differentially expressed genes were identified using the DESeq2 package in R. DNA methylation was evaluated by bisulfite sequencing. Differentially methylated CpG dinucleotides were analyzed by the methylKit package in R. Protein expression of ACCα was determined by western blot. Group differences were evaluated by ANOVA. RESULTS: ACCα mRNA and protein expression increased (P<0.05) in MO fetal livers versus CTR. In a preliminary assessment of DNA methylation, we have focused on 5 CpG sites with notably decreased methylation in fetuses of MO ewes within a 1.5 kb upstream from its promoter region.

back_matter.text: We have obtained a more complete picture of how ACCα regulation is affected in MO fetal livers by utilizing a multi-omic approach. These data fit the typical model where a decrease in DNA methylation in the promoter region of a gene is correlated with an increase in its expression and provide a possible mechanism of regulation for ACCα via fetal imprinting.

Polymorphism in the KCNQ1 Gene May Influence Insulin Secretion in Japanese Pregnant Women. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is a multifactorial disease, and pregnant women with GDM have a higher risk of later developing type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).Quantitative trait loci (QTL) analysis has previously been used to reveal the causative genetic factors in complex disease. In this study, we aimed to identify the risk genetic variants that are associated with insulin resistance or secretion in pregnant Japanese women using QTL analysis. METHODS: This study included a total of 299 Japanese women with singleton pregnancies who underwent the diagnostic 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) in late pregnancy at Keio University and the National Center for Child Health and Development (GDM: n=128; normal OGTT: n=171). Of the T2DM risk variants previously reported, 45 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in 36 candidates (Japanese minor allele frequency > 30%) were genotyped using DNAs from maternal peripheral blood samples. Logistic regression analyses were used to test between genetic variants and results of the 75g-OGTT, as well as genetic variants and the homeostasis model assessment as an index of insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) or Insulinogenic Index (I.I.).

In both groups, the T allele of rs163184 (KCNQ1) was associated with decreased I.I. (p=0.002, 95% CI: -1.17--0.24). No SNPs were associated with HOMA-IR. In the GDM group, the T allele of rs163184 (KCNQ1) was associated with increased serum glucose levels in the 75g-OGTT at 60min (p=0.035, 95%CI: 0.001-0.024). CONCLUSIONS: This is the first report assessing genetic variants of GDM using QTL analysis. KCNQ1 may affect insulin secretion in pregnant Japanese women.

Placental Corticotrophin-Releasing Hormone (pCRH) Is Associated with Shorter Gestation and Birth Weight. CRH is a key regulator of the stress system. During pregnancy in primates, CRH is produced by the placenta and released into the maternal and fetal compartments, where it is believed to play key roles in development and parturition. The objective of this study was to determine the association of pCRH with length of gestation and fetal growth. METHODS: 603 participants were recruited across 4 US sites. Maternal blood samples were obtained at two visits between 12-20 weeks and 32-35 weeks gestation. pCRH was measured by RIA in duplicate, averaged and log transformed. Change in pCRH between the first and second visits was calculated and adjusted for the time interval between visits. Birth outcomes were abstracted from the medical record. The associations of the natural log of pCRH with gestational length and fetal growth were assessed via multiple linear and logistic regression analysis. RESULTS: Median pCRH in the third trimester was 433.5 pg/ml with a range of 53.4 -7488.8 pg/ml and IQR of 458.0 pg/ml. Higher log pCRH during the third trimester was associated with shorter gestational length (β=-0.1804, p=0.0002) as well as small for gestational age at birth (OR 2.1 (1.3,3.2), p<.001) and preterm birth (OR 1.8 (1.1,3.1), p=0.031). For every 2 SD increase in log pCRH in the third trimester, gestational age decreases by 3.0 days. Similarly, the change in log pCRH from the second to third trimester also predicted shorter gestational length (β=-0.1747, p<.001) small for gestational age (OR 2.0 (1.3,3.0), p=0.002) and preterm birth (OR 1.8 (1.3,3.0), p=0.038). For every 2 SD increase in log pCRH from second to third trimester, gestational age decreases by 4.8 days.These relationships remained significant after adjustment for maternal age, race, education, income, and obstetric complications. pCRH in the second trimester alone was not associated with birth outcomes. CONCLUSIONS: Higher pCRH during the third trimester of gestation and change in pCRH from second to third trimester is predictive of shorter gestation and small for gestational age birth. Future studies should examine how upstream factors, stress and inflammation, influence pCRH and risk for adverse birth outcomes
Effects

RESULTS: Plasma testosterone levels increased 2-fold in testosteroneinjected rats. Placental and fetal weights were lower in rats with elevated testosterone. Uterine artery blood flow was lower and resistance index was higher in testosterone group. Radial and spiral artery diameter and length, number of fetoplacental arterial branches, and umbilical artery diameter were reduced in testosterone group. In addition, markers of hypoxia in the placenta and fetuses were elevated in testosterone group. The magnitude of disruption in placental vasculature and hypoxia were greater in male than female placentas. Intriguingly, different sets of angiogenic and blood vessel morphogenic genes were dysregulated in male and female placentas. CONCLUSIONS: Elevated maternal testosterone induces decrease in uterine arterial blood flow and fetal sex related uteroplacental vascular changes, which may set a stage for subsequent sex-differences in adult onset diseases.

Remodeling In human pregnancy, the maternal aorta undergoes remodeling, with increases in diameter and elasticity. Although the underlying mechanisms are unknown, animal studies of injury-related remodeling in large conduit arteries indicate that phenotype switching of the vascular smooth muscle (VSM) and Tet2 gene-mediated epigenetic VSM genome are required. Based on these data, we hypothesized that pregnancy related remodeling of the aorta is also likely to involve alteration in Tet gene expression, as well as epigenetic alteration of the VSM genome. To test this hypothesis, we have begun to characterize pregnancy-related modifications of the aorta in mice.

All studies were performed in 6 week old C57B6 mice obtained from JAX. Timed matings were based on observation of a copulatory plug. Sections of the abdominal aorta were removed in varying stages of pregnancy. Aortic diameters were determined from paraffin-embedded cross-sections using Metamorph TM software. DNA and RNA were prepared by standard methods. Gene expression studies were performed by qPCR. Levels of 5-hydroxymethylcytosine (5hmC) and 5-methylcytosine (5mC) were determined using a commercial ELISA kit (Zymo). Immunohistochemistry was performed using commercially obtained antibodies. RESULTS: Analysis of sections of abdominal aortas from 3 separate animals at each of several gestational timepoints, showed that the cross sectional area enlarges up to 4 fold by e15.5, indicating extensive expansive remodeling. RNA expression analysis and immunohistochemistry of Myh11 and Myocd, established markers of VSM differentiation, showed that both are downregulated 20-to 30-fold, consistent with dedifferentiation of the VSM from a contractile to a secretory phenotype. The expression of all three members of the Tet gene family were downregulated 10-to 30-fold as well. In keeping with the observed downregulation of Tet genes, genome-wide assessment of 5hmC and 5mC indicated that the level of both DNA modifications were altered by approximately 5%. CONCLUSIONS: To our knowledge, this is the first demonstration that pregnancy-related remodeling of the maternal aorta is likely to have an epigenetic basis. Future work will focus on how the elastic properties of the aorta are altered in pregnancy, and on how long the physiologic and epigenetic modifications endure in the postpartum period. Female specific risk factors such as pregnancy disorders might play a role in gender differences in stroke. The aim of this study was to assess the prevalence of pregnancy disorders among women with a history of stroke, and to compare stroke characteristics between women with and without a history of adverse pregnancy outcome. METHODS: Female participants of the multicenter Dutch Acute Stroke Study, conducted among patients admitted for acute ischemic cerebrovascular events between 2009-2013 were sent a structured followup questionnaire to collect data on reproductive health and pregnancy history. RESULTS: A questionnaire was sent to 464 living female patients, of whom 152 consented to participate (32.8%). Mean age was 63.2 years at admission for stroke and 67.7 years at follow-up. In total, 130 of the participants (85.5%) reported at least 1 pregnancy with a mean age at first pregnancy of 25.0 years. Miscarriage occurred in 21 (19.6%) and premature delivery in 13 (10.0%) of the women. A hypertensive pregnancy disorder (HPD), including gestational hypertension and (pre-) eclampsia, was reported by 37 (34.3%) of the participants. Patients with a HPD more often had hypertension (64.4% vs 42.2%; p=0.025), but there was no association with other cardiovascular risk factors. There was no association between HPD and Oxford stroke classification (total anterior circulation infarct, partial anterior circulation infarct, lacunar infarct or posterior circulation infarct; p=0.791), stroke severity as measured by the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (p=0.924), and outcome at three months after admission as measured by the as measured by the Modified Rankin Scale (p=0.782) or EQ5D (p=0.244).

The often-reported miscarriages and hypertensive pregnancy disorders in this cohort of women who suffered from ischemic stroke might reflect a common pathophysiologic pathway. There was no association between hypertensive pregnancy disorders and stroke characteristics and stroke severity. Potassium oxonate, inhibitor of the enzyme uricase only present in rodents, was also injected ip (125mg/kg/day). Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) a pathogenic stimulus was used for comparative analysis. On G22, caesarean section was performed and placentas collected and either frozen for protein analysis by ELISAs or fixed for histological analysis. RESULTS: Elevated uric acid levels at the end of gestation in rats dosedependently led to fetal growth restriction (FGR), with 45% of the pups presenting fetal weight below the 5 th centile of pups from vehicle-injected dams. Significantly elevated levels of IL-1b, IL-6 and TNFa were found in placentas from uric acid exposed dams. Histological analysis revealed clusters of immune cells within the placental labyrinth of uric acid exposed rats, on the fetal side, even though gross placental morphology remained intact. These cell clusters were highly positive for the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-1b. Although immune cells were observed in LPS-exposed placentas, they were restricted primarily to the vessels and never formed the clusters observed following prenatal uric acid exposure. CONCLUSIONS: In summary, we found that elevated uric acid level during gestation is a strong inducer of placental inflammation in rats leading to FGR. This new model of non-infectious inflammation during pregnancy will be used to address the placental mechanisms involved in the negative impact of inflammation on the fetus and will allow to test new therapeutic strategies.

Racial and Social Disparities in Inflammatory Gene Expression During Pregnancy. Pre-term birth patterns are challenging to understand, e.g., it is unexpectedly prevalent among Black and Hispanic women of higher social classes. Pathways contributing to these patterns are not well understood, though inflammation could play a role. METHODS: Data are from a multisite prospective study of 593 pregnant women, from whom peripheral blood was drawn during the 2nd and 3 rd trimesters. RNA was extracted from leukocytes for qPCR of 19 proinflammatory transcripts, shown to be increased in response to stress. Demographics were gathered by patient report, and pregnancy risks via chart review. RESULTS: Confirmatory factor analyses revealed the RNA targets loaded on a single principal component. Thus, a composite inflammatory endpoint was examined by repeated-measures ANOVA, with trimester, race, and education as predictors. There was no across-the-board racial differences in inflammatory gene expression, but a significant 3-way interaction emerged (F = 2.17, p = .04.). Specifically, gene expression differed based on the mix of racial background and educational attainment. Among Whites (n=364), there were negligible educational differences in inflammatory gene expression, but among Blacks (n=95) and Latinas (n=113) there was a reverse gradient, such that as education increased, so did inflammatory gene expression. This gradient was most prominent in the 3rd trimester, when university-educated Blacks had composite values that were .25 standard deviation units higher than similarly educated Whites (and .40 units higher than high-school educated Blacks.) These patterns remained significant (F = 2.22, p = .04) even after adjusting for maternal age, parity, obstetric risk, gestational age at blood draw, and the relative proportion of monocytes vs. lymphocytes in the qpCR specimen. CONCLUSIONS: These data suggest that inflammatory activity is paradoxically increased in minority women with higher educational attainment. This reverse social gradient may reflect the physiological toll of social mobility, or the greater exposure to discrimination in mixed-race workplace settings.
