We observed 376 metabolites and prioritized 15 metabolites for analysis based on differences between sample groups. Sphingomyelin and phosphocholine (PC) species were significantly associated with preterm labor independent of pathogen identity (p=0.04, p=0.01 respectively). Cases with severe fetal lung injury were tightly grouped by PCA and significantly associated with 4 lipids from 3 different classes. A single PC species was highly correlated with duration of infection with a hyperpathogenic GBS strain (R 2 =0.99). Further, an inverse dynamic profile was found for guanine with lower and higher abundancies correlated with <24h and >24h of infection, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: Preterm labor and fetal lung injury were associated with similar metabolic signatures independent of pathogen identity. The duration of intrauterine infection was highly associated with levels of guanine and, in the case of a hyperpathogenic GBS strain, with a single PC species. This untargeted metabolic analysis has the potential to identify novel biomarkers for improved diagnostic, prognostic and therapeutic interventions for preterm labor. the role of endothelin-1 (ET-1) as both a constrictor of uterine myometrial smooth muscle and a pro-inflammatory mediator. The phospholipase C pathway stimulated by ET-1 leads to activation of protein kinase C, which in turn activates sphingosine kinase (SphK). Recently we showed that SphK inhibition prevents lipopolysaccharide-induced preterm birth in a murine model. We now show that SphK inhibition also rescues timed pregnant dams challenged with tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNFa).

A total of 17 timed pregnant embryonic day (E) 15.5 C57BL/6 mice, weighing between 28 and 35 g, were used for in vivo studies. The control group (n=9) was injected intraperitoneally (ip) with TNFa dissolved in 0.5 mL PBS at T=0 and 50 µL polyethylene glycol (PEG) 400 at T=1 and 7 h. The treatment group (n=8) was also injected ip with the same dose of TNFa and then injected with 50 mg/kg SphK inhibitor (SKI II) dissolved in PEG 400 at T=1 and 7 h. After injections at T=7 h, mice were continuously observed for time of delivery and number of pups dropped. Mice that did not deliver were observed until T=24 h. All mice were euthanized and necropsied to confirm pregnancy and the number of pups retained in utero was recorded. The retained placentas and uteri were harvested and stored at -80 °C or in 10% neutral buffered formalin at room temperature. RESULTS: Inhibition of SphK with SKI II significantly decreased the percent of TNFa-challenged timed pregnant mice delivering prematurely from 88.9% to 25.0%, (p < 0.05). SKI II also rescued pups from spontaneous abortion, reducing the percent pups prematurely dropped in the TNFa challenged mice from 18.9% to 8.3%. None of the 101 pups tracked in the study showed evidence of teratogenic effects and no toxic effects were observed in the dams. We now plan to examine the profile of pro-inflammatory cytokines in tissue lysates and sera from both groups to test whether SKI II acts by suppressing inflammation. CONCLUSIONS: Inhibition of sphingosine kinase may have broad applications in the management of inflammation induced preterm birth.

Maternal The effect of cortisol exposure on its cellular targets depends on both the amount produced and on the sensitivity of glucocorticoid receptors. Pregnancy produces a progressive increase in HPA axis activity, resulting in a period of relative hypercortisolism. However, there are no systematic studies to date that have examined variation in glucocorticoid receptor (GR) sensitivity and its changes in gestation. The aims of the study were to quantify change in GR sensitivity from early to late gestation, and to characterize the maternal determinants of GR sensitivity across gestation. METHODS: GR sensitivity was assessed in 158 pregnant women at two time periods, 12-20'6 and 32-35'6 (second and third trimester), using an ex vivo stimulation assay. The inhibition of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) stimulated pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL1b, TNF-α) by leukocytes after co-incubation with increasing levels of dexamethasone provided a marker of GR sensitivity. RESULTS: GR sensitivity diminished significantly with progression of pregnancy (F=5.216. p=0.009, see Figure 1 ). Both race and maternal BMI were independently associated with cytokine concentrations in the GR sensitivity assay. Overall production of pro-inflammatory cytokines was significantly higher in Black women compared to women of other race/ethnicity (F=6.002. p=0.003). Maternal BMI was significantly associated with greater reduction of GR sensitivity in later pregnancy (F=7.082, p=0.003). *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: The association of higher maternal pre-pregnancy BMI with reduced GR sensitivity during pregnancy may represent a mechanism underlying differential susceptibility to the potentially detrimental effects of excess cortisol exposure on fetal development, birth outcomes, and subsequent child health. . Current clinical management proposes the use of a collagen plug (or amniopatch) to avoid the loss of amniotic fluid. To improve this poorly efficient mechanical strategy, vitamin A (as a well-known healing substance) could be proposed as an adjuvant of this plug to promote amniotic re-epithelization. The aim of this work was to test the pro-healing properties of all-trans retinoic acid (atRA, an active derivative of vitamin A) on primary amnion derived epithelial cells. METHODS: Twelve fetal membranes were collected at term after healthy pregnancies. Primary amniocytes, amnion and chorion explants were treated with atRA or its vehicle (DMSO) and used for transcriptomic analysis. The induction/repression of genes expression by atRA was firstly confirmed by RT-qPCR at 24h and also studied after 6, 12 and 48h. Protein accumulations were confirmed by immunocytochemistry. The effect of atRA on wound healing was tested by scratch-assay on primary amniocytes and then by proliferation and migration assay. These scratch assays were also realized using specific atRA induced gene inhibitors or siRNA.

The transcriptomic analysis allowed the identification of numerous genes regulated by atRA particularly in the amnion and primary amniocytes, whereas only 2 were highlighted in the chorion. Functional RARE binding site DR5 type were localized by promotology study and the retinoic-induction of genes was confirmed at transcript and protein level. AtRA improves wound-healing of primary amniocytes by promoting cell migration but not proliferation, property strongly affected by the use of specific siRNA. CONCLUSIONS: Our results show a pro-migratory effect of atRA on primary amniocytes, leading to a healing improvement of up to 80% in vitro. We demonstrate that these effects are mediated by the regulation of numerous genes acting in the dynamic and generation of the extracellular matrix. By providing new elements to understand how atRA exerts their pro-healing properties, this work proposes atRA as a promising candidate, in the pathophysiological context of pPROM. The relationship between short inter-pregnancy interval (SIPI) and preterm birth is well established, but the relationship between SIPI and short cervix has not been studied. Our objective was to determine if the relationship between inter-pregnancy interval (IPI) and preterm delivery (PTD) was related to cervical shortening. METHODS: This is a secondary analysis of a prospective cohort study designed to assess the relationship between cervical length (CL) and PTD. Patients were included if they had one previous delivery, transvaginal cervical lengths obtained at 22-24 weeks and complete pregnancy outcome data available. We excluded nulliparous women, and patients with an indicated PTD, abruption, and intrauterine fetal demise. IPI was classified in years. The women were divided into two groups: Group 1 with an IPI of <1 year and Group 2 with an IPI of >1 year. The primary outcome was short cervix (CL< 2.5cm) at 24 weeks. The secondary outcome was the incidence of PTD <37 weeks. Bivariate analyses were performed using chi-square, Fisher's exact test, and Student's t-test where appropriate. Logistic regression was used to adjust for confounders (age, pre pregnancy weight, smoking, and previous PTD), and the interaction between short cervix and IPI was examined in a regression model. RESULTS: There were 155 women in Group 1 and 328 women in Group 2. There was no difference in the incidence of short cervix by the length of inter-pregnancy interval (10.0 % in Group 1 and 12.9% in Group 2, p=0.35). Women with SIPI had a significantly shorter CL at 24 weeks when compared to women in Group 2 (33.6 mm vs. 35.5mm,p=0.03), but this association disappeared when adjusted for confounders (p=0.14).

In a logistic regression model SIPI and short cervix were independently associated with PTD. CONCLUSIONS: The relationship between SIPI and preterm birth is not explained by a short cervix. They remain independent risk factors for preterm delivery. *Figure(s) will be available online. In term or preterm birth (PTB), cervical changes precede the onset of labor. Defining the molecular changes that drive cervical remodeling is necessary for risk detection and prematurity prevention. We have determined that LPS-mediated premature cervical ripening occurs by a distinct mechanism as compared to term ripening. While the mechanical integrity of the cervix is reduced in both term and LPS-mediated ripening, the structural reorganization of fibrillar collagen occurring in term does not occur in infection-mediated PTB. Despite low abundance relative to collagen fibers, elastic fibers also contribute to tissue mechanical function. The elastic fiber is comprised of elastin, microfibrillar and other associated proteins. In the current study we test the hypothesis that infection disrupts elastic fiber integrity to facilitate cervical compliance and induce PTB.

The following studies were carried out using mouse cervices from gestation day 15 untreated (NT), day 18 (term), day 15 + intrauterine LPS (d15LPS), and day 15 + sham surgery (sham) groups. Elastic fiber structure and morphology was visualized using Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and immunofluorescence staining for elastin (IF). Biomechanical testing of tissue recoverability to measure elastic fiber integrity was performed. Elastin abundance was assessed by Fastin Elastin assay. RESULTS: Elastic fiber ultrastructure (TEM) appears disrupted in cervices from d15LPS mice compared to d15 controls and d18. The biomechanical test for recoverability of d15LPS samples was significantly reduced compared to d15, indicating disrupted elastic fiber integrity. This measurement at term was not significantly different from d15. Assessment of the core component of the elastic fiber, elastin, indicates no significant change in extractable elastin abundance (Fastin assay) or morphology (IF) in d15LPS or d18 compared to d15 controls. CONCLUSIONS: This study identifies structural (TEM) and functional (biomechanical) defects in elastic fibers in LPS-mediated premature ripening that are distinct from term ripening. These results motivate further studies to determine mechanisms that disrupt elastic fiber organization specifically in LPS-mediated premature cervical ripening. These findings provide new insights into the diverse mechanisms by which the cervical ECM can be reorganized to increase compliance and facilitate cervical opening. is a key transcription factor that modulates cell defense mechanisms against endogenous and exogenous stress. Previously, we reported that thrombin increased matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and prostaglandin (PG) synthesis in human amnion mesenchymal cells. Here we sought to determine if activation of Nrf2 alters the effect of thrombin on prostaglandin synthesis, protease activation, and cytokine release in human amnion mesenchymal cells. Further, we analyzed the effect of Nrf2 activation on thrombin-induced preterm labor in mice.

Human amnion mesenchymal cells were treated with thrombin ± Nrf2 activators (diethyl maleate (DiEM) or 15-deoxy-delta-12,14-prostaglandin J2 (15d-PGJ2)). Gene expression was quantified by qPCR. COX2 protein and nuclear Nrf2 were analyzed by Western blot. PGE2 and cytokines levels in conditioned media were assayed by ELISA and Inflammatory Cytokine Human Magnetic 5-Plex Panel. Precisely time-mated pregnant mice were injected with thrombin ± 15-dPGJ2. RESULTS: As expected, thrombin (2U/ml 24h) increased MMP1 (9.5-fold, P<0.001), MMP9 (5.6-fold, P<0.001), and COX2 (200-fold, P<0.001) in amn mesenchymal cells. Pre-incubation with Nrf2 activators (100 µM DiEM or 5 µM 15d-PGJ2), however, profoundly repressed thrombin-induced MMP1 (68 ± 5.9 %), MMP9 (45 ± 5.4 %), and COX2 (97 ± 0.7 % inhibition). In addition, Nrf2 activation inhibited thrombininduced COX2 protein levels (77%, p < 0.01) and secretion of PGE2, IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8, TNFα (88-92%, all p < 0.01) in the media. Pregnant mice were injected with intrauterine vehicle, thrombin (2U/ml), 15d-PGJ2, or Thr+15d-PGJ2 on d17. Thrombin induced preterm birth in all mice (23.4 ± 1.9 h). Whereas vehicle and 15d-PGJ2 did not alter gestational length, 15d-PGJ2 delayed thrombin-induced preterm birth significantly (54.4 ± 9.6 h, p<0.05).

The results indicate that Nrf2 activation represents a key stress response in amnion mesenchyme cells and in pregnant mice to mitigate the adverse pro-inflammatory effects of thrombin on the fetal membranes. We suggest, therefore, that pharmacologic activation of Nrf2 may prevent preterm premature rupture of the membranes associated with dysfunctional thrombin generation (during pregnancy (e.g., subchorionic hemorrhage or bleeding). PGE2 is the primary prostaglandin that mediates cervical ripening. Since inflammation and progesterone receptor (PR) function represent important pathways involved in both term and preterm labor, we investigated effects of PGE2, IL-1β, or both on human cervical stromal cells (hCSCs) and compared these responses to that of myometrial cells. METHODS: RT-qPCR and immunoblotting of cytoplasmic and nuclear fractions of highly differentiated primary hCSCs from nonpregnant and pregnant women. H3 and α-tubulin were used to normalize protein input. RESULTS: hCSCs were strikingly more responsive to the effects of IL-1β (0.008 -1 ng/ml) on IL-8 than myometrial cells (15,000-compared with 500-fold, p < 0.01). Further, IL-1β-induced increases in COX-2 mRNA (>1000-fold, p <0.01) and protein (162-fold) were dramatically increased relative to IL-1β-induced changes in myometrial cells (55-fold and 40fold respectively, p < 0.01). PGE2 attenuated IL-1β-induced increases in COX-2 mRNA and protein (from 162-to 5-fold) despite the fact that IL-1β-induced nuclear translocation of p65 was not altered. Importantly, both IL-1β and PGE2 profoundly suppressed 15-PGDH (from 1.0 ± 0.12 to 0.34 ± 0.03 for Il-1β; to 0.11 ± 0.01 RU/h36b4 for PGE2, p < 0.01) and the progestational transcription factor MiTF-CX (from 1.0 ± 0.31 to 0.04 ± 0.01 for IL-1β; to 0.07 ± 0.03 RU/h36b4 for PGE2, p<0.01). Whereas IL-1β decreased PR-A (2-fold) and -B (4-fold) in hCSCs, surprisingly, PGE2 increased nuclear PR-A 33-fold and PR-B 3.4-fold. IL-1β suppressed PGE2-mediated induction of PR mRNA (from 6.7 ± 0.9 to 3.0 ± 0.31 R.U./h36B4, p <0.05) and protein (PR-A, 18-fold; PR-B, 1.6-fold) possibly through suppression of the cervical PGE2 receptor EP2 (63 ± 3%, p <0.01). CONCLUSIONS: hCSCs are extraordinarily sensitive to the proinflammatory cytokine IL-1β increasing IL-8 and COX-2 and decreasing the progestational nuclear transcription factor MiTF-CX and 15-PGDH. IL-1β and PGE2 do not synergistically activate proinflammatory pathways in the cervix. Interestingly, whereas IL-1β downregulates PRs, PGE2 increases PR in hCSCs with disproportionate increases in PR-A. Taken together, IL-1β and PGE2 result in complex, but different, inflammatory and progestational transcription factor profiles in human cervical stromal cells.

The Once regular contractions had been established for 20+ minutes baseline measurement of contraction frequency, contraction peak, contraction duration, work per contraction (average area under curve) and total work (area under all contractions) were made. The inhibitor compound was then added, effects upon contractility measured in the next 10 minutes. The effect of the inhibitor upon agonist (OT) was then measured by adding increasing concentrations of OT (1, 10, 100nM) at 10 minute intervals. RESULTS: Atosiban was studied at 6, 60 and 600nM. Atosiban had no effect upon spontaneous concentrations. Atosiban antagonized the effects of oxytocin upon the rate of contractions and peak tension with a dose dependent effect, although at lowest concentrations the effects were partly agonist. OBE001 was studied at equimolar concentrations (6, 60 and 600nM). OBE001 inhibited spontaneous contractions in a dose dependent way, affecting rate, contraction peak tension, and contraction duration and therefore having an overall effect upon total work. OBE001 antagonized the effect of OT in a dose dependent way, affecting all parameters and leading, at 600nM concentration, to a complete abolishment of contractility. CONCLUSIONS: When comparing the effect of Atosiban and OBE001 at equimolar concentrations, there was little difference at 6nM, but OBE001 was superior to Atosiban at 60nM and 600nM, and unlike Atosiban, totally inhibited contractility. Therefore, OBE001 appears to be a promising candidate tocolytic with a better tocolytic profile than Atosiban.
Myometrium. Scott D Barnett, Heather R Burkin, Iain LO Buxton. University of Nevada, Reno -School of Medicine, Reno, NV, USA.
back_matter.section: S-097 GSNOR Expression and Regulation in Preterm Laboring

back_matter.text: The posttranslational modification of proteins is a key regulator of cellular function. It is known that the S-nitrosation of cysteines via endogenous nitric oxide (NO) acts as a mediator of disease (Anand and Stamler 2012). Our analysis of the myometrial S-nitrosoproteome has revealed that several smooth muscle contractile proteins are differentially S-nitrosated based upon the state of labor in INTRODUCTION: The transition of the pregnant myometrium to an actively contractile state requires a complex series of regulatory events. The objective of this study was to identify miRNA transcripts differentially expressed during myometrial contractions in term and preterm labor. METHODS: Myometrial specimens were collected from women undergoing cesarean delivery in the setting of: 1) spontaneous preterm birth (PTB) with clinical and/or histologic chorioamnionitis (HCA, n=5); 2) PTB without labor (PTNL, n=5); 3) term birth in absence of labor (TNL, n=5); and 4) spontaneous term labor (TL, n=5). MiRNA sequencing was performed using the Illumina HiSeq2500 platform. After adaptor trimming, quality control, and mapping to the miRBase 21 database, statistical and pathway analyses were performed using a combination of bioinformatic tools. RESULTS: Relative to the non-laboring state, term labor was associated with differential expression of 40 mature miRNAs (FDR < 0.1), 16 of which increased in abundance. For these, 675 validated mRNA targets were identified. Up-regulated miRNA targets were enriched for transcripts mapping to interleukin-1 receptor, nuclear factor kappa-B, and MAP kinase signaling pathways, while targets of down-regulated miRNA were enriched for pathways relating to autophagy/senescence, DNA damage response, and NOTCH signaling. Only 7 miRNAs differed between the HCA and PTNL specimens, and the HCA specimens exhibited heterogeneous clustering among the TL and non-laboring miRNAomes ( Figure) . In both scenarios, labor was associated with increased expression of the immunomodulatory miRNAs miR-146b and miR-223. CONCLUSIONS: We identified a mature miRNA expression signature associated with term labor in the human myometrium. A subset of these miRNAs was also differentially regulated during preterm labor, albeit with less consistency. The present data suggest novel regulatory roles for miRNAs in mediating uterine contractions. *Figure(s) will be available online.

Crosstalk Between the Uterine Myocyte Endoplasmic Stress Response and the Antioxidant Response During Pregnancy. Saiprasad Ramnarayanan, 1 Pancharatnam Jeyasuria, 1,2 Jennifer C Condon. 1,2 1 Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, MI, USA; 2 NICHD, Detroit, MI, USA. INTRODUCTION: The uterine endoplasmic reticulum stress (ERSR) regulates gestational length through increased non-apoptotic caspase 3 (CASP3) activation (1). There is growing evidence that pregnancy associated oxidative stress, which also acts as a regulator of ER stress plays an important role in the timing of labor (2). In other systems protein kinase RNA-like endoplasmic reticulum kinase (PERK), an important activator of the ERSR, has been shown to regulate reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels through activation of an antioxidant signaling cascade, resulting in increased levels of nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)-like 2 (NRF2) and its downstream antioxidant target NADPH dehydrogenase quinone 1 (NQO1). We examined the crosstalk between the ERSR and oxidative stress in vitro and in vivo in the myometrial tissues from pregnant mice and women. METHODS: Telomerase immortalized human myometrial cells (hTERT-HM) were transfected with PERK siRNA and treated in the absence or presence of the ERSR inducer tunicamycin (TM) (5µg/ml). ROS levels were measured using dichlorofluorescein diacetate fluorescence assay. Western blotting and qPCR analysis were performed on human (GA 32-42) and mouse (E6-19) myometrial tissues to measure NRF2, NQO1 protein and mRNA levels. RESULTS: PERK knockdown in hTERT-HM cells revealed decreased activation of the antioxidant response in response to TM treatment. These events resulted in elevated ROS production and consequently increased apoptotic CASP3 activation. These data demonstrate that disabling the uterine myocyte ERSR impairs the local pro-survival anti-oxidant response. Uterine levels of pPERK, NRF2 and NQO1 in the human and mouse tissues increased in late gestation. CONCLUSIONS: The pregnant uterus experiences increasing amounts of oxidative stress towards term. Our in vitro analysis reveals that the uterine myocyte has the capacity to host an anti-oxidant signaling cascade in an ERSR dependent manner preventing oxidative stress induced cell damage and cell death. In vivo, it is critical to regulate the levels of oxidative stress to avoid cell damage signals that activate inflammatory responses that can lead to the onset of preterm birth. The myometrium goes through phases of differentiation during pregnancy to become a powerful contractile tissue at term. Small heat shock proteins (HSP) are a family of ten (HSPB1-B10) stress molecules that are versatile mediators of health and disease. Phosphorylated HSPB5 is reportedly involved in aiding actin filament dynamics and immune cell activation. Thus, it was hypothesized that HSPB5 would be highly expressed in the myometrium during the contractile and labour phases of myometrial differentiation when such processes are prominent. METHODS: Rat uterine tissue samples (n=4 per timepoint) were collected from non-pregnant rats, from day (d) 6, d12, d15, d17, d19, d21, d22, d23 (labour) of pregnancy, as well as 1-day post-partum (PP). Samples of gravid and non-gravid horns were also collected from unilaterally pregnant rats on d19 and d23 (n=4 each timepoint). The spatio-temporal

expression of serine-59 phosphorylated (pSer59) HSPB5 protein was then examined in these models using immunoblot and immunofluorescence analysis. For co-localization experiments, hTERT-human myometrial cells were cultured under standard conditions in supplemented DMEM/ F12 media. Cells were then immunostained for pSer59-HSPB5, CD63 and/or Kindlin-2 and analyzed by confocal microscopy. RESULTS: pSer59-HSPB5 protein detection was significantly increased from d19 through to PP (ANOVA, Neuman-Keuls, p<0.05). pSer59-HSPB5 was also readily detected in the cytoplasm and juxtamembrane regions of myometrial cells during late pregnancy and labour. In unilaterally pregnant rats, pSer59-HSPB5 protein expression was significantly elevated in gravid uterine horns at both d19 of gestation and d23 (labour) compared to non-gravid horns (t-tests, p<0.05). Confocal microscopy analysis of hTERT-HM cells also demonstrated that pSer59-HSPB5 co-localized with the exosomal marker CD63 as well as with the focal adhesion protein Kindlin-2 at the ends of actin filaments. CONCLUSIONS: pSer59-HSPB5 is highly expressed in myometrium during late pregnancy and labour and expression appears to be regulated by uterine distension. HSPB5 may be involved in regulating actin filament dynamics and could be secreted by exosomes as a prelude to involvement in immune activation in the myometrium. Preeclampsia is a pregnancy specific hypertensive disease. It is characterized by impaired placental angiogenesis and compromised uterine spiral artery remodeling, and has been considered to be an ischemic placental disease. AMP activated protein kinase (AMPK) protects against ischemia/reperfusion injury in a variety of organs. Thus, we hypothesized that compromised AMPK activity is involved in the development of preeclampsia. METHODS: Placental tissue was collected from 20 normotensive and 20 PE complicated nulliparous subjects, whom were admitted in the department of Obstetrics, the first affiliated hospital of Chongqing Medical University and chose non-labored caesarean delivery in the absence of other complications. mRNA was measured by q-PCR, protein expression was measured by WB, and the transwell assay was performed by the use of ACEA real-time cell analyzer. RESULTS: mRNA levels of AMPKα1 and AMPKα2, as determined by q-PCR did not identify any significant differences in placentas from term normal and preeclampsia pregnancies (n=4, AMPKα1 transcript 1 p=0.08, AMPKα1 transcript 2 p=0.28 and AMPKα2 p=0.72), and there were no differences in protein expression as determined by Western blotting (n=18, p=0.39). However, AMPK phosphorylation increased 1.97 fold in preeclampsia placentas (vs. normal, n=18, p=0.01). Moreover, the phosphor-Akt level was decreased 41% in preeclampsia compared with normal placentas (n=7, p=0.01). HTR8 trophoblast cells were treated with specific AMPK agonist AICAR (2.47-200µM) or specific AMPK inhibitor Compound C (1.25-20µM) for 24 hours; real time cell analysis demonstrated that the migration of HTR8 cells was downregulated by AICAR but upregulated by Compound C in a dose-dependent manner. CONCLUSIONS: AMPK phosphorylation is increased in term preeclampsia placentas, indicating that preeclampsia is associated with enhanced AMPK activity. However, pharmacological inhibition of AMPK significantly enhanced HTR8 cell migration whilst a AMPK agonist inhibited cell migration. Paradoxically, some researchers have reported lower risk of pregnancy-related hypertension (PRH) among immigrants when compared to their non-immigrant counterparts. The lack of consistency and the absence of a synthesis of studies investigating the associations between immigration status and PRH represent a gap in our understanding of socio-ecological roots of PRH METHODS: A literature search of PubMed/MEDLINE, CINHAL, Ovid, and Web of Knowledge bibliographic databases was conducted, covering studies that investigated the role of migrant status on PRH, published after January, 2000. Of the 310 papers identified, 16 studies met the inclusion criteria. For each study, we computed relative risks that compared PRH risk in immigrants versus non-immigrants. A meta-analysis using a random-effects model was used to generate a pooled relative risk estimate. One-way sensitivity analyses and an assessment of publication bias were conducted. RESULTS: Fourteen of the sixteen studies reported lower rates of PRH among immigrant populations (those born outside of the country of study), compared to non-immigrants *Figure(s) will be available online. The pooled estimate of the relative risk of PRH represented a statistically significantly lower risk among immigrants versus non-immigrants (RR = 0.74; 95% CI: 0.67, 0.82). CONCLUSIONS: The body of evidence indicates that immigrant populations, in general, have lower risk for PRH. Due to the methodological limitations of included studies, namely limited adjustment for confounders such as duration of immigration and other socio-behavioral factors, we recommend larger longitudinal studies with well-defined and operationalized measures of immigrant status, PRH, and reliable confounders. Preterm birth (PTB) accounts for 11.5% of total births. Inflammation accompanies most of the preterm labors which, in turn, leads to PTB We have provided evidence that activation of PPAR-γ via rosiglitazone prevents inflammation-induced PTB. Since macrophages participate in the pathophysiology of inflammation-related preterm labor, we aimed to determine whether rosiglitazone alter various pathways known to be involved in PPAR-γ signaling and PTB. METHODS: Pregnant mice (E16.5) were divided into 4 groups, and treated as outlined in Table1.0. The LPS+Rosi group received Rosiglitazone 6hrs after an LPS (lipopolysaccharide) injection. Two hours after injection, uterine and decidual tissues were collected. Next, macrophage isolation using (MACS) Magnetic cell sorting and F4/80+ antibody was performed. Expression levels of anti-oxidative factors and Toll like receptor 4 were semi-quantified by qRT-PCR in the isolated macrophages.

: Macrophages (both from uterine and decidual tissues) from the LPS group showed increased levels of Toll like receptor 4 (Tlr4), Cyclooxygenase 2 (Cox2) and lowered expression of anti-oxidative factors Heme oxygenase 1 (HO1) and Nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)-like 2 (Nrf2). Macrophages from the LPS + Rosi group showed significant downregulation of the TLR4 expression (≥ 1.5 folds, p≤0.05, n=5) and upregulation of HO1 and NRF2 expression (≥ 1.5 folds, p≤0.05, n=5). Expression of Cox2 was downregulated, but this did not reach statistical significance. CONCLUSIONS: Activation of PPAR-γ via Rosiglitazone reduced the rate of LPS-induced preterm birth by downregulating the inflammatory response. This may be achieved by down-regulating the expression of the LPS receptor, TLR4, and increasing in the anti-oxidative response.

Antiphospholipid , with a single amino acid substitution of Lysine (K) to Asparagine (N) can excise hydrophobic peptides 165-fold greater, resulting in an altered peptide repertoire presented by HLA class I molecules on the cell surface. We reported that the fetal ERAP2N allele is associated with preeclampsia (PE) in the African Americans. However, how this substitution and enhanced trimming ability of ERAP2 impacts the immune response has not been determined. This finding could potentially provide insight to the immunological pathogenesis of PE.

We utilized an in vitro transfection system in a wellcharacterized trophoblast cell line, JEG-3, lacking endogenous ERAP2 expression and expressing only a single class I HLA-C molecule. pTracer-RFP vectors specifically expressing ERAP2K or ERAP2N were transfected into JEG-3 cells, followed by a lymphocyte activation assay using isolated total peripheral blood lymphocytes. The lymphocytes were phenotyped and measured using flow cytometry with fluorescently labeled CD3, CD8, CD56, CD69, and CD11a antibodies. Western blot analysis was performed on transfected JEG-3 cells to determine ERAP2 expression and the HLA repertoire. RESULTS: NK and T cells activation responses to ERAP2N expressing JEG-3 cells were increased significantly compared to ERAP2K expressing JEG-3 cells. These lymphocytes also expressed the killing surface marker CD11a, indicating that these cells possess the ability to kill target cells.Interestingly, the change in peptide repertoire in transfected JEG-3 cells did not alter the HLA-C, HLA-E, or HLA-G surface molecule expression level compared to untransfected JEG-3 cells. CONCLUSIONS: These findings provide new insights into the immunological pathway by which fetal ERAP2N contributes to the pathogenesis of preeclampsia.

Pregnant WT and miR-155 KO mice were treated with poly I:C or saline on gestational days (gd) 13, 15, and 17 prior to sacrifice on gd 18. Tissues were harvested at gd 18 and kept at -80ºC for subsequent analysis. qRT-PCR reactions were performed in placentas from all mouse groups. miRNA abundance was calculated using the -∆∆C t method. Western blots were performed and infrared visualization was used followed by densitometric analyses using LICOR Odyssey system. RESULTS: miR-155 expression increased in placentas of P-PIC WT (pregnant treated with poly I:C) mice compared to P WT (pregnant) mice by the binding of transcription factors NF-kB and AP-1 to the promoter of miR-155. Suppressor of cytokine signaling 1 (SOCS1) is predicted as a putative target of miR-155 by Targetscan and is known to prevent overactivation of immune responses which failed to increase in P-PIC WT mice. ICAM, a marker of inflammation increased significantly in P-PIC WT mice. P-PIC miR-155 KO mice did not exhibit increased placental levels of NF-kB, AP-1 and ICAM or decreased levels of SOCS1. Recurrent preeclampsia may play a larger role in future cardiovascular risk than previously recognized. We determined the relationship between recurrent preeclampsia and poor cardiovascular outcomes up to 25 years after pregnancy using a longitudinal population cohort in Canada.

We extracted 594,808 women who were pregnant more than once between 1989-2013 from hospital discharge abstracts for the province of Quebec. We identified women with recurrent (n=5,437), isolated (n=22,110), or no preeclampsia (n=567,261). We abstracted all future hospitalizations for cardiovascular outcomes or procedures, including heart failure, ischemic heart disease, stroke, any heart procedure, coronary artery bypass graft, coronary angioplasty, or aorta repair. Using time-to-event analysis, we estimated hazards for each outcome (hazard ratio, HR; 95% confidence interval, CI), comparing recurrent and isolated preeclampsia with no preeclampsia. We adjusted for age, year, parity, and deprivation, and censored women who died or had no event by March 31, 2014, the last day of follow-up. RESULTS: Incidence of any cardiovascular disease was higher for recurrent (105 per 1000) and isolated (60 per 1000) than no preeclampsia (30 per 1000). Recurrent preeclampsia was more strongly associated with poor cardiovascular outcomes than isolated preeclampsia. Compared with no preeclampsia, women with recurrent preeclampsia had greater risk of any cardiovascular disease (HR 3.7; 95% CI 3.4-4.0), heart failure (HR 3.5; 95% CI 2.4-5.3), ischemic heart disease (HR 3.1; CI 95% 2.3-3.9), stroke (HR 2.2; 95% CI 1.6-3.1), any heart procedure (HR 1.6; 95% CI 1.2-2.1), coronary artery bypass graft (HR 3.0; 95% CI 1.1-8.2), coronary angioplasty (HR 3.4; 95% CI 2.2-5.3), and aorta repair (HR 5.7; 95% CI 2.7-12.3). Isolated preeclampsia was associated with any cardiovascular disease, but more weakly (HR 2.1; 95% CI 2.0-2.3). CONCLUSIONS: Recurrent preeclampsia presents greater risk for future cardiovascular disease than isolated preeclampsia. Previously reported long term cardiovascular risks may be disproportionately greater for women with recurrent preeclampsia. , and a 47, XY, +12) were processed using our newly developed short-DNA library preparation method and sequenced on the MinION nanopore sequencer. The number and quality of sequences was monitored in real-time and the sequencer was stopped when sufficient sequencing data was collected. A customized bioinformatics pipeline was developed to analyze the sequences generated and perform cytogenetic analysis. RESULTS: Our short DNA fragment library preparation method increased the final products from <5% to 63%, and enabled sequencing of 500 reads in 3 min and 40,000-80,000 reads in 2-4 hours. Using the short DNA fragment library preparation and analysis pipeline we obtained sufficient numbers of reads for successful determination of gender and aneuploidy in all samples within 2-4 h with chance of a type I and II error for detecting aneuploidy of p<0.001 and p β-aneuploidy < 0.05, respectively. CONCLUSIONS: The MinION nanopore sequencer has the potential to serve as an ultra-portable tool for rapid clinical and research applications.

Sex Specific Effects of Prenatal Betamethesone (Beta) Exposure and Unilateral Nephrectomy on Angiotensin -(1-7) (Ang-(1-7))-Mas Receptor Expression and Inhibition of Sodium Uptake by Ang-(1-7) in Ovine Proximal Tubule Cells. Yixin Su, 1 Jianli BI, 1 Mark C Chappell, 2 James C Rose. 1 1 Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston-Salem, NC, USA; 2 Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston-Salem, NC, USA. INTRODUCTION: Antenatal Beta is used clinically to accelerate fetal lung maturity, but prenatal exposure to elevated levels of glucocorticoids reduces nephron number in animals Reductions in nephron number in early life increase the risk for impaired renal function following a second insult to the kidney and may be associated with imbalance between Ang-II /AT1 receptor and Ang-(1-7)/Mas-receptor pathways within the kidney. The objective of this study was to determine if antenatal glucocorticoid exposure combined with a second insult (acute loss of nephrons -unilateral nephrectomy) would alter the effects of Ang-(1-7) on Na + uptake in renal proximal tubule cells (RPTC) and Ang-(1-7)-Mas receptor gene expression in adult sheep kidney.

Male and female sheep were administered betamethasone (2 doses of 0.17 mg/kg, 24 hours apart) or vehicle at the 80th day of gestation and delivered at term. Sheep underwent unilateral nephrectomy at 1 year and the remaining kidney was obtained 3 weeks later at necropsy. Renal cortex samples were collected for analysis of Ang-(1-7)-Mas receptor protein expression by western blot.. RPTC were cultured for 7-10 days and the fluorescence dye sodium green was employed to determine cytoplasmic Na+ uptake.

In male vehicle and Beta sheep Ang-(1-7) was more effective in reducing Na uptake in cells from the kidney remaining after unilateral nephrectomy (2 nd kidney). In contrast, in females there was no effect of acute loss of nephrons on responses to Ang-(1-7).The ability of Ang-(1-7) to decrease Na + uptake was greater in RPTC from Beta females than in cells from Beta males. Prenatal Beta exposure decreased Angiotensin-(1-7)-Mas receptor expression in male sheep compared with vehicle treatment (F=8.28; P<0.01). There was no significant difference in Angiotensin-(1-7)-Mas receptor expression in female sheep exposed to Beta and following nephrectomy. CONCLUSIONS: These data suggest that acute nephron loss in males enhances ability of Ang-(1-7) to inhibit Na + uptake by RPTC. In addition, the greater effectiveness of Ang-(1-7) in RPTC from Beta females vs Beta males may be due to greater expression of Mas receptor in the females. Previously we have reported that 30 min of transient hypoxic hypoxia (HH) upregulates the expression of inflammation and apoptosis markers in fetal cerebral cortex (CTX), and the administration of ketamine attenuates these responses. The present experiments test the hypothesis that UCO produces a robust inflammatory and apoptotic response in the fetal CTX, and the treatment with ketamine reduces these responses. METHODS: An extravascular occluder was placed around the umbilical cord in chronically catheterized fetal sheep (125d). A 30-minute UCO decreased fetal P a O 2 50%. Half of the fetuses received ketamine (3mg/ kg) intravenously 10 min prior to UCO (n=4/group). 24 hours after the experiment, fetal brains were collected and mRNA were extracted and hybridized to ovine Agilent 15.5k microarray. Differentially regulated genes were determined using empirical Bayes moderated t-test and twoway ANOVA for microarray data and qPCR calculations, respectively, and DAVID Bioinformatics to identify significant up-and downregulation of biological processes. We also performed real-time qPCR of key inflammation and apoptosis mediators (NFKB, CD14, MYD88, BAD, and CASP3). The criterion for statistical significance was p<0.05. RESULTS: UCO upregulated cellular catabolic processes (p≤0.05), with a trend for upregulated apoptotic and cell death pathways (p=0.08 and 0.06, respectively), but no effect on inflammation or apoptosis pathways. There were no significant downregulated pathways induced by UCO. Also, the administration of ketamine did not show any effect on either group of animals (±UCO). Real-time qPCR validation of specific target genes confirmed our array results. CONCLUSIONS: UCO did not induce an inflammatory or apoptotic response on the fetal CTX. This is in contrast to the inflammation/apoptotic response to HH (with the same magnitude and duration of hypoxia). We conclude that the inflammation/apoptosis in fetal CTX after HH is secondary to a maternal response to HH and is not a direct response to cellular oxygen deprivation. The incidence of GDM is rapidly increasing worldwide, and GDM is known to result in both early perinatal complications and long-term effects such as cardiovascular disease in offspring. AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) is cardioprotective, especially in the treatment of ischemia/reperfusion (I/R). Therefore, we hypothesized that AMPK is involved in the cardiac disease of offspring exposed to in utero hyperglycemia, in particular, the response to I/R of male offspring. METHODS: 8 weeks-old female Sprague-Dawley rats were mated with age matched male. GDM animal model was established by administering streptozotocin (35 mg/kg) on E8.5 via i.p. injection. The blood glucose level, GTT, ITT of the male offspring were measured at 22-24 weeks of age, and then the offsprings were subjected to 20 min of global ischemia followed by 30 min of reperfusion by the use of Langendorff system. Cell signaling was determined by western blot.

The average glucose level of diabetic animals during pregnancy was >16.7mmol/L (vs. control, N=4, P<0.05). The body weight of the GDM male offspring were significantly higher than control male offspring from the age of 8 weeks (N=16, P<0.05); the heart weights and heart weight/body weight ratio was also higher in the GDM group vs. Cortisol is essential for fetal development, organ maturation and transition to ex-utero life. This is facilitated by an endogenous increase in maternal cortisol across gestation. Cortisol bioavailability and local tissue delivery is regulated by corticosteroid binding globulin (CBG). CBG also binds progesterone, but with over a 3 fold lower affinity. To investigate the regulation of cortisol bioavailability in-utero, we assessed cord blood levels of free and total cortisol, high and low affinity CBG (haCBG and laCBG) and progesterone across gestation. METHODS: Cord blood samples were collected at birth from preterm (n=141) and term (n=176) neonates. High and low affinity CBG levels were assessed by an in-house ELISA. Total cortisol and progesterone was measured by electro-chemiluminescence immunoassay and ELISA, respectively. The fraction of free cortisol was determined using a temperature-controlled ultrafiltration/ligand-binding method. All clinical data were collected from medical records. RESULTS: Total cortisol, free cortisol, the proportion of haCBG and progesterone increased across pregnancy (p<0.05 for all). Compared to reference ranges for women in the luteal phase, progesterone levels in cord blood were over 100-fold higher (mean 7476 nM/L, IQR 4184-9697nM/L). Free cortisol fractions were elevated three-fold in gestation compared to previous reports in adults. While the progesterone to CBG ratio did not change over gestation, it was correlated with free cortisol concentrations at each gestational time point (r=0.155, p=0.03). CONCLUSIONS: We propose that high progesterone concentrations result in a displacement of cortisol from CBG, allowing predominant free cortisol in the neonatal circulation. This high free cortisol fraction may allow a fetal-specific cortisol tissue distribution required for fetal development. This does not appear to be driven by alterations in haCBG or laCBG levels. This 'progesterone switch' in CBG function in utero potentially has important physiological implications for neonatal transition.
Whole . We hypothesized that α7nAChR agonism will decrease pro-inflammatory phenotype of fetal microglia, while antagonistic stimulation will do the opposite.

We sequenced the transcriptome of 6 ovine fetal near-term naïve (in vivo NaCl exposed) microglia cultures with 3 controls (NC) and 3 in vitro LPS-exposed (NL); 2 second-hit (SH) samples pre-exposed to LPS in vivo with 1 control (SHC) and 1 LPS-exposed in vitro (SHL); 3 NC samples were exposed to A (NA) and 3 naïve-microglia samples exposed to B (NB), both followed by 6h incubation with LPS. Differentially expressed (DE) genes (padj < 0.1) were represented in heat map and enriched with ToppGene for pathways, Biological process and molecular function (Bonferroni < 0.05). Affected pathways were explored with the reactome and the STRING database.

In NB group, we observed an up regulation of inflammatory pathways NFKB, TNF alpha and Jak-STAT. Our results confirmed the role of heme oxygenase 1 (HMOX1) and Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase (FBP) in SH and NB microglia. Comparison of NA to NB shows that immune response (P = 1.8 x 10 -9 ) and JAK-STAT cascade involved in growth hormone signalling pathway (P = 6.61 x 10 -4 ) are down regulated. We observed opposite response in NA 3 samples; differential analysis of unique DE genes revealed that Iron uptake and transport was significantly enriched in the reactome (P = 8.38 x 10 -5 ). CONCLUSIONS: Pro-inflammatory microglial phenotype acquired in vitro by LPS stimulation is reversed with α7nAChR agonistic stimulation, evidenced by up regulation of HMOX1 and down regulation of FBP genes. Disparity analysis of NA 3 response highlights the role of iron metabolism during fetal neuroinflammation. This phenomenon is reversed by antagonistic α7nAChR stimulation. These results suggest a therapeutic potential of α7nAChR agonists in early treatment or re-programming of brain microglia in neonates exposed to in utero inflammation to augment postnatal brain development trajectory.

In Utero Exposure to IL-1β Elicits Circadian Rhythm Biomarker Upregulation. Michael Tsimis, 1 Jason Rosenzweig, 1 Saleh Alhasan, 1 Yazid Alrajeh, 1 Irina Burd. 1,2 1 Johns Hopkins University SOM, Baltimore, MD, USA; 2 Johns Hopkins University SOM, Baltimore, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: Previously, we have reported that exposure to maternal inflammation results in upregulation of IL-1β in the fetal brain, perinatal brain injury, and subsequent development of circadian rhythm aberrations in the adult offspring. In this study, we tested the hypothesis that IL-1β plays a role in fetal brain programming for circadian rhythm formation. METHODS: At E17, CD1 dams were randomly allocated to receive either intraperitoneal injection of phosphate buffered saline (PBS) (n=6) or injection (1 mcg/kg) of mouse recombinant IL-1β (n=13). Gene expression was analyzed utilizing quantitative PCR (QPCR) for the following markers: IL-1β, DBP (D site of albumin promoter binding protein), Nos1, IL-6, Mtnr1b (melanopsin receptor 1b), TNFα, IL-4, CLOCK (Circadian Locomotor Output Cycles Kaput), and IL-10. The gene expression data was log transformed and the student's t test was run using Qbase v.3.0 (Belgium) with significance set at p<0.05. Behavioral testing was performed at postnatal day (PND) 5, 9, and 13.

The QPCR showed that IL-1β and DBP both were significantly upregulated with exposure to IL-1β *Figure(s) will be available online. while Nos1, IL-6, Mtnr1b, TNFα, and IL-4 were all upregulated and approached significance. CONCLUSIONS: In utero exposure to increased levels of IL-1β resulted in circadian rhythm gene upregulation within 24 hours. Based on our data, we believe that IL-1β plays an important role in fetal programming of circadian rhythms. (n=4), inflammation + hemorrhage group (n=6) and artificial placenta group (n=3) 48 hours later since the surgery. Inflammation + hemorrhage group was administered G-CSF and LPS to induce inflammation and withdrawn a 40 % of fetal blood to induce cerebral ischemia. The fetuses of artificial placenta group were connected to the pumpless artificial placenta with placement of the catheters into the umbilical vessels and administered vasopressin to induce cerebral ischemia. MRI scans were performed for fetal brain at 108-117 days gestation and we histologically checked fetal brain. RESULTS: There were significant differences in basic characters between three groups. Histological focal WMI was observed 50% (n=3) of inflammation + hemorrhage group and all (n=3) of artificial placenta group. Abnormal signal intensities on MRI scans (T1: high intensity, T2: low intensity) were observed in that histological focal WMI. One of 3 cases which were not induced WMI in inflammation + hemorrhage groups showed diffuse abnormal intensities (T2: high intensity) at bilateral deep white matter on MRI scans. CONCLUSIONS: We could success to analyze WMI following cerebral ischemia in preterm sheep with MRI scans in this study. And also, we could show the abnormal intensity of focal or diffuse WMI on MRI scans. These data suggest that MRI scans are useful to detect characteristic appearances of histologic changes in deep white matter in preterm fetal sheep.

Characterization INTRODUCTION: Through CAP's efferent vagus nerve, α7 nAChR expressed on peripheral macrophages reduce the pro-inflammatory cytokine expression. While adult CAP has been studied, its function in fetus is hardly known. We hypothesized that agonistic stimulation of α7nAChR in fetal brain microglia will reduce IL-1β secretion, thus mimicking CAP. METHODS: 8 ovine near-term fetuses were instrumented with catheters, recovered 3 days and were injected LPS (400 ng IV) or NaCl to induce inflammation. At 54h, at necropsy primary microglia and astrocyte cultures were derived. Microglia (n=8) were studied 2 weeks and astrocytes (n=10) -4 weeks after in vivo LPS/NaCl exposure (DOI: 10.3389/fncel.2015.00294). The cells were pre-incubated with AR-17779 (α7nAChR agonist, 10 ng, "A10") for 2h followed by LPS (100 ng) for 6h or NaCl exposure. Thus, in vitro LPS exposure meant single hit to in vivo animals receiving NaCl and second-hit (SH) (microglia: n=2; astrocytes: n=1) to those having received LPS in vivo. IL-1β secretion was measured in supernatant (ELISA). RESULTS: 5 microglia and 8 astrocyte cultures showed an unexpected increase, rather than decrease, in IL-1β after A10 treatment (Fig. 1, 2) , regardless gender. In SH microglia, LPS induced 74-or 2-fold IL-1β increase. In SH astrocytes, LPS induced 0.4-fold IL-1β increase. *Figure(s) will be available online.CONCLUSIONS: CAP's traditional anti-inflammatory role may not hold in the developing brain. Stimulating α7nAChR on fetal glia has pro-inflammatory effect in most cases. Further studies are needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying this observation and its therapeutic implications. . At 54 h post first LPS, animals were euthanized and brain and terminal ileum tissues were collected and analyzed by immunohistochemistry for Iba1+ microglia/macrophages signal intensity. Results are reported for p<0.05. RESULTS: LPS 400 and 800 resulted in a similar IL-6 rise at 3 h post LPS, no change in brain inflammation, and an increase of Iba1 intensity in ileum macrophages. Vx+LPS400 resulted in a surprising anti-inflammatory effect: IL-6 was diminished to control levels on D2; similar behaviour was seen in brain and gut. Vx+LPS800 led to the expected increase in brain, but not gut, inflammation, compared to Vx+LPS400 and bringing it to Control or LPS group levels ( Fig. 1 ). *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: Contrary to adult CAP function in mitigating sepsis, low-grade inflammation in fetus is diminished by CAP withdrawal. This counter-intuitive effect of CAP is abolished and the expected proinflammatory role of CAP withdrawal is revealed upon exposure to a higher endotoxin dose. This bimodal CAP behaviour requires further study to gauge therapeutic consequences of targeting CAP. Maternal obesity has been demonstrated to increase fetal overgrowth as well as adult disease risk in the offspring for a range of diseases including metabolic syndrome, type II diabetes and cardiovascular disease. The placenta is the interface of nutrient transport to the fetus and Glut1 is the main glucose transporter. By isolating the role of glucose transport levels to the fetus, we have created a mouse model to examine the role of different levels of glucose on fetal health outcomes. METHODS: Active transgenesis utilizing a hyperactive piggyBac transposase-based plasmid was used to generate a transgenic mouse line using pronuclear injection (te-PNI). This approach combines high transgenesis rates and low transgene insertion numbers with the ease of using te-PNI. The plasmid used contains an shRNAmir against Glut1 under the control of the CYP19I.1 promoter for placental trophoblast specific expression and a Tet-on system to allow for time point specific induction. The vector also contains the gene for EGFP, which allows for visual confirmation of transgenic mice. Knockdown of Glut1 expression was induced in transgenic mice between E 14.5 and E18.5.

Nicotine was administered to pregnant rats via subcutaneous osmotic minipumps from day 4 of gestation to day 10 after birth, in the absence or presence of a ROS inhibitor, N-acetyl-cysteine (NAC) in drinking water. Experiments were conducted in 8 month old age male offspring. Isolated hearts were in a Langendorff preparation. RESULTS: Perinatal nicotine treatment significantly increased ischemia and reperfusion-induced left ventricular injury, decreased post-ischemic recovery of left ventricular function and coronary flow rate. In addition, nicotine enhanced cardiac ROS production and significantly attenuated Protein kinase C Ɛ (PKC Ɛ ) protein abundance in the heart. Although nicotine had no effect on total cardiac Glycogen synthase kinase-3β (GSK3β) protein expression, it significantly increased the phosphorylation of GSK3β at serine 9 residue in the heart. NAC inhibited nicotine-mediated increase in ROS production, recovered PKC Ɛ gene expression and abrogated increased phosphorylation of GSK3β. Of importance, NAC blocked perinatal nicotine-induced increase in ischemia and reperfusion injury in the heart. CONCLUSIONS: These findings provide novel evidence of a causative role of increased oxidative stress in perinatal nicotine-induced developmental programming of ischemic sensitive phenotype in the heart, and suggest potential therapeutic targets of anti-oxidative stress in the treatment of ischemic heart disease. Increasing parity has been shown to be associated with offspring adiposity, inflammation, and impaired glucose metabolism in an animal model. However, similar studies examining the impact of parity and higher birth order in humans are lacking. The goal of this pilot study was to evaluate the effects of parity on the fetal programming of gene expression in neonates. METHODS: Foreskin samples were collected from 55 non-anomalous neonates. Parity was abstracted from review of medical records. Samples were flash frozen, and RNA was isolated from the epidermal/dermal layer. Nine epidermal/dermal samples were excluded (n=4 from twins; 2 from preterm infants; 3 due to RNA degradation). RNA expression levels were analyzed using the NanoString Technologies nCounter system. Expression of genes involved in glucose/lipid metabolism and inflammatory response was quantified and normalized to housekeeping genes. The average gene expression levels among neonates born to mothers with a lower parity (1 or 2) (n = 35) vs. higher parity (3 or more) (n = 11) were compared, using Student's t test.

The mean parity was 1.54 ± 0.51 vs. 3.64 ± 0.92, in the low vs. high parity group respectively. Expression levels of oxidative and inflammatory stress response genes -cytochrome P450 1b1 (p<0.01) and hypoxia inducible factor 1 alpha (p<0.01), as well as apoptotic regulatory genes, B-cell lymphoma 2 (p<0.05) were significantly increased in babies born to women with a higher parity. Likewise, tissue from these infants was also noted to have significantly increased expression of adipocyte differentiation markers chemerin (p<0.01), cAMP responsive element binding protein 1 (p<0.01), forkhead box protein O1 (p<0.01), very low density lipoprotein receptor (p<0.01), suggestive of an increased adipogenic milieu. Interestingly, both adiponectin receptor 2 (p<0.05) and fatty acid transport protein 4 (p<0.01) were significantly down-regulated. CONCLUSIONS: Genes involved in the inflammatory response as well as metabolism were differentially expressed in infants born to mothers with a lower vs. higher parity. Further studies are warranted to evaluate if these changes will be sustained through epigenetic interactions.

Offspring Fed a High Fat Diet. Baifeng Yu, Erin Zinkhan. University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Fetal growth restriction (FGR) and consumption of a high fat diet (HFD) predispose to insulin resistance in both humans and animal models. Despite the prevalence of a HFD, little is known about the mechanism through which FGR increases insulin resistance in the context of a maternal HFD. Tissues important in the pathogenesis of insulin resistance include visceral adipose (VAT) and subcutaneous adipose (SAT). In healthy individuals, insulin initiates the insulin signaling cascade resulting in increased glucose transporter (Glut4) protein at the cell surface to increase glucose uptake from the blood. An endogenous inhibitor of the insulin signaling cascade (Socs3) prevents insulin signaling. We hypothesized that FGR rats from dams fed a HFD (FGR+HFD) would demonstrate insulin resistance in young rats by increasing VAT and SAT protein levels of Socs3. METHODS: Adult female rats were fed a HFD prior to mating through gestation and lactation. FGR was induced by uterine artery ligation at E19 of a 21 day gestation. At postnatal day 21 (D21) rats were weaned to the same maternal HFD. We measured serum glucoses during an intraperitoneal glucose tolerance test (GTT), calculated the area under the curve of the GTT, and measured protein levels of the insulin signaling cascade of VAT and SAT with western blot. RESULTS: FGR+HFD male and female rats had increased fasting serum glucoses on GTT at 30, 60, 90, and 120 minutes (all timepoints p<0.05) and increased area under the curve on GTT (male: control+HFD 356+/-13, FGR+HFD 432+/-13* mg/dL/hr; female: control+HFD 323+/-7, FGR+HFD 456+/-15* mg/dL/hr). FGR+HFD male and female rats had decreased VAT and SAT Glut4 protein (male VAT: control+HFD 8. *p<0.05. CONCLUSIONS: FGR+HFD increases serum glucoses during GTT and decreases VAT and SAT Glut4 protein in young male and female rats. Increased adipose tissue Socs3 protein may inhibit insulin signaling and induce insulin resistance in young FGR+HFD rats. We speculate that inhibition of Socs3 protein will improve insulin resistance in FGR+HFD rats. Since nicotine is highly addictive, women may use nicotine replacement therapies and electronic cigarettes to aid in their cessation attempts. However, studies from our group have demonstrated that in rats MNE during gestation and lactation leads to postnatal hypertriglyceridemia, which is strongly associated with cardiovascular disease (CVD). Intrahepatic triglyceride accumulation can occur, in part, due to impaired lipid loading capacity in white adipose tissue (WAT). Since (i) MNE has been shown to induce ER stress in other tissues, and (ii) ER stress can adversely affect adipocyte function, we predicted that nicotine-exposed offspring would have increased ER stress in WAT. Therefore, we hypothesize that MNE alone will adversely impact adipose function leading to hypertriglyceridemia and CVD long-term. METHODS: Female rats received daily subcutaneous injections of vehicle or nicotine bitartrate (1mg/kg) from 2 weeks prior to mating until weaning. Visceral gonadal WAT was harvested from male and female 26 week old offspring. Formalin fixed WAT was stained with H&E to quantify adipocyte cell areas. Steady-state mRNA expression in markers of adipogenesis and adipose tissue function along with ER stress were quantified via real-time PCR. Significant differences were determined using Student t-tests (n=11-15/group). RESULTS: MNE significantly decreased adipocyte cell area (p<0.001) and increased expression of genes associated with adipocyte differentiation (SREBP1c, PPARα/∆; p<0.05) and lipolysis (ATGL p<0.05) in male and female offspring. Also, MNE increased expression of GRP78 (p<0.01), ATF4, spliced XBP-1, and CHOP (p<0.05) suggesting an aggravated ER stress response in WAT. Markers of proliferation and lipogenesis were unaffected. CONCLUSIONS: MNE decreased adipocyte size, resulting in impaired lipid storage and long-term hypertriglyceridemia. This exposure was also associated with augmented ER stress. Future studies assessing the role of nicotine-induced ER stress in altering adipocyte size and lipid storage will uncover molecular mechanisms promoting adipose dysfunction and hypertriglyceridemia long-term.
back_matter.section: S-145 Fetal Growth Restriction Induces Insulin Resistance in Young Rat

back_matter.text: Effects . BP responses to MCh administration in vivo was not different between groups, but prior treatment with the nitric oxide synthase inhibitor L-NAME revealed a shift in hemodynamic responses in SHR offspring that was absent in SHR+Resv offspring, suggesting a loss of NO signaling in treated offspring. In isolated mesenteric vessels, conversion of the inactive precursor bET-1 to active ET-1 was lower in Resv-treated rats (-28%; P<0.05), and this difference could be normalized by L-NAME treatment. CONCLUSIONS: Resv treatment during development mitigated the development of hypertension and caused persistent alterations in vascular responsiveness in SHR. However, targeted treatment exclusively during pregnancy may be warranted for resveratrol to avoid the growth restriction in the postnatal (pre-weaning) phase.

Fetal Autophagy is an adaptive process of cell survival by sequestration, degradation and recycling of damaged organelles via lysosomal machinery. We have shown disruption in autophagy in placentas of obese women. To study the role of autophagy in placenta, a conditional knockout (KO) mouse with placenta-specific deletion of autophagy-related gene 7 was created. We reported that placentas of KO mice show mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress. Five-monthold offspring of KO mice develop obesity and hyperglycemia following 8 weeks exposure to a high fat diet (HFD, 45% fat) vs. regular diet (RD, 17% fat). We hypothesized that placental dysfunction would give further programming effects in these mice. METHODS: Plasma, adipose and heart tissues of male or female wild type (WT) and KO mice fed RD or HFD (n=5-10/group) were collected. Plasma adiponectin, insulin, heart and adipose tissue weight, adipocyte size were measured and heart tissue were stained with Masson's trichrome. RESULTS: No significant changes in plasma adiponectin were seen, though there was a slight decrease (p=0.2) in male KO/HFD mice. Insulin levels in male but not female WT/HFD and KO/HFD mice were increased compared to RD-fed (p<0.05), and in KO it was higher than WT within each diet group. There were no differences in heart weights across groups. Visceral fat mass was greater in both male and female WT/ HFD and KO/HFD vs. RD-fed mice (p<0.05). Male and female KO/HFD mice, however, had significantly higher fat accumulation than WT/HFD, WT/RD and KO/RD (p<0.05). Only male WT/HFD and KO/HFD mice showed increased adipocyte size vs. RD-fed (2-and 3-fold respectively, p<0.05). Adipocyte size has been previously shown to be increased in metabolically unhealthy individuals. While we observed cardiac fibrosis in all HFD-fed mice, the area of fibrosis was significantly greater in KO vs. WT mice, and in males vs. females in each HFD-fed group (p<0.05). CONCLUSIONS: In summary, in a mouse model of placental dysfunction caused by defective autophagy, we were able to recapitulate metabolic abnormalities seen in the offspring of obese women in a sex-dependent manner: this included hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia, accumulation of visceral fat, increase in adipocyte size and myocardial fibrosis. Alterations in imprinted genes have been implicated as a potential link between maternal exposures, in utero growth, and longterm health and disease. Grb10, an imprinted gene expressed from the maternal allele in the placenta and fetal liver, is critical to fetal growth in the mouse. Changes in the peri-conception environment, such as a high fat diet or in vitro fertilization, alter Grb10 expression and DNA methylation. GRB10 has been linked to adult metabolic health as well and GWAS studies identified GRB10 as a diabetes susceptibility gene. In the present study, using wild type (WT) mice, mice lacking the maternal Grb10 allele (Grb10 (-/+) , mice lacking the paternal Grb10 allele (Grb10 (+/-) and null mice (Grb10 (-/-) ), we investigated the role of Grb10 in body composition and metabolic function in adulthood.

We assessed body composition, fasting glucose, fasting insulin, glucose tolerance, insulin tolerance, and response to glucagon stimulation tests in the four groups of mice between 16-24 weeks of age. We examined insulin sensitivity by quantifying downstream targets of the insulin signaling pathway including p-Akt, p-GSK-3ß and p-S6K1 at baseline and following insulin challenge; glycogen content in liver was also quantified. RESULTS: Body weight, lean body mass, and pancreatic weight were significantly increased in Grb10 (-/+) and Grb10 (-/-) mice in adulthood (p<0.05 vs. WT). We also observed lower fasting glucose, lower fasting insulin levels and improved glucose tolerance in mice lacking the maternal Grb10 allele (n>15/group, p<0.05). Insulin sensitivity was markedly improved in muscle tissue in Grb10 (-/+) and Grb10 (-/-) vs. WT mice, and p-AKT, p-GSK-3ß and p-S6K1 were significantly increased (p<0.05 vs. WT) following insulin administration. Mice lacking the maternal allele also had a blunted response to glucagon administration, which may be due to the observed decrease in glycogen stores in the liver of the maternal heterozygote and null mice (p<0.05 vs. WT). CONCLUSIONS: Loss of the maternal Grb10 allele alters insulin signaling resulting in improved insulin sensitivity and decreased hepatic glycogen stores. These findings, combined with the known affects of Grb10 on fetal weight, suggest that Grb10 is a critical link between early embryo exposures, growth kinetics and long-term metabolism. To study the association between mTOR/p70S6K signaling pathway and early growth response 1 (Egr1) in regulating cognitive decline of ovariectomized (OVX) mice.

Cognition function of OVX-mice and Sham controls were assessed by Morris water maze (MWM) and electro-physiological examination analysis. Expressions of Egr1, mTOR, and p70S6K in mice hippocampus were detected before and after intra-cerebroventricularly rapamycin-treatment using qPCR and Western blot. Furthermore, we investigated the expression of mTOR and p70S6K in neuroblastoma (SH-SY5Y) cells transfected with Egr1 interference fragment or Egr1overexpressing plasmid. Changes of Egr1 level with rapamycin were also studied. RESULTS: Compared with controls, we found escape latency increased, time in target platform quadrant reduced, and synaptic plasticity damaged in OVX-mice. And expressions of Egr1, mTOR and p70S6K in the hippocampal of OVX-mice were obviously increased relative to that in Sham group. After intra-cerebroventricularly rapamycin-treated, cognition decline was significantly improved, and expression of mTOR/ p70S6K and Egr1 were statistically down-regulated in OVX mice compared with vehicle controls. Additionally, in human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells, either the Egr1 interference fragment or the Egr1-overexpressing plasmid transfection did not alter the expression of mTOR and p70S6K, while rapamycin-treated decreased Egr1 expression. CONCLUSIONS: Our data suggests that increased Egr1 expression, relating to cognitive decline in OVX, is regulated by mTOR/p70S6K pathway. Interestingly, mTOR inhibitor-rapamycin, reducing the Egr1 level, might be a potential therapeutic target in postmenopausal cognitive decline. Females have an increased prevalence of anxiety disorders, including Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) compared to males. The increase may be due to estrogen, since decreased estrogen levels affect the onset and severity of OCD. Additionally, mutations in estrogen receptor genes have been implicated in OCD and obesity; the mechanisms remain unclear. We previously reported that AKAP13 significantly augmented estrogen-dependent activation mediated by estrogen receptors alpha and beta. The objective of this study was to further characterize the behavior AKAP13 haploinsufficient mice and assess the possible contribution of obesity to OCD in the murine model. METHODS: Generation of AKAP13 +/-mice, as previously reported.

The following behavioral assays were performed: grooming, nestlet shredding, and marble-bury in adult AKAP13 +/-mice and controls. For grooming assays, behaviors were captured by video and scored. Weight measurements were also obtained. For statistical analyses, test outcomes were compared by genotype and sexes using one-way ANOVA with Bonferroni adjustment for multiple comparisons and T-Tests where appropriate. RESULTS: AKAP13 was expressed in brain regions involved in complex behaviors, appetite/satiety, and estrogen receptor expression.The grooming assay demonstrated OCD behavior in AKAP13 +/-mice compared to controls (p≤0.05). Haploinsufficient female mice exhibited increased total grooming (p<0.05), and increased incomplete bouts (p<0.05), where incomplete bouts demonstrated a departure from the cephalocaudal grooming pattern. Similarly, AKAP13 +/-mice shredded a greater percentage of their nestlets than controls. In the marble-bury assay, the AKAP13 +/-male and female mice buried more marbles (p<0.05), consistent with OCD behavior. Furthermore, AKAP13 +/-mice of combined sexes were found to be heavier than controls between 3-6 months old (p< 0.05) and greater than 6 months old (p<0.05). Female +/-mice were heavier than controls at 3-6 months (p<0.05), but the males did not show significant differences. CONCLUSIONS: These data support the conclusion that mice haploinsufficient for AKAP13 exhibit traits consistent with OCD. Additionally, these data support a potential connection between obesity and OCD, and add to the body of knowledge suggesting sex differences in anxiety disorders. Malnutrition coupled with maternal stress and anxiety may affect the fetus' brain at its vulnerable stage of development that may favor the development of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). Therefore, we aim to examine whether perinatal exposure to HG is associated with increased risk of ASD later in life.

We conducted a retrospective cohort study using medical records from children born between 1991-2009 in Kaiser Permanente Southern California hospitals (n=406,465). ICD-9-CM codes from the hospital inpatient and outpatient physician encounter, laboratory, and pharmacy records were used to ascertain the exposure and outcomes of interest. Adjusted hazard ratio (HR) and 95% confidence interval (CI) were used to quantify the associations. RESULTS: One in sixty-six children was diagnosed with ASD. Two percent of pregnancies were complicated by HG. Compared with unexposed children, exposed children were more likely to be male and of White or African-American race/ethnicity. Exposed children were more likely than unexposed children to develop ASD (HR 1.56, 95%CI 1.34-1.82). A stratified analysis by gestational age at exposure revealed that children exposed to HG in the first and second trimester of pregnancy were significantly more likely to develop ASD; 1.57-fold (95%CI 1.31-1.87), and 1.58-fold (95%CI 1.13-2.20), respectively, compared to unexposed children. HG was associated with increased risk of ASD across all racial/ ethnic groups except Blacks and Asian/Pacific Islanders. CONCLUSIONS: These findings demonstrate an association between hyperemesis gravidarum and autism spectrum disorder. Further research is needed to delineate the role hyperemesis gravidarum may play in the subsequent development of autism spectrum disorder.

We found significant differences at mRNA level between healthy and arresting CAS in ENDO LY (CXCR3 and CCR5), endometrium (CXCL10, CXCR3, CCL5, CCR5, and DARC), and CAM (CCL1). Some of these differences were also noted at protein level (CXCL10, CXCR3, CCL5, and CCR5) in endometrium and CAM. CD45+ immunohistochemistry revealed significantly higher localization of endometrial lymphocytes in the endometrium associated with healthy conceptuses compared to their arresting counterparts. CONCLUSIONS: Findings in this study provide a first direct evidence about differential chemokine expression between healthy and arresting CAS, potentially contributing towards a shift in immune cell functions at the maternal-fetal interface. However, a limiting factor in utilizing placental pathology to its full potential is the lack of standardization in placental examination. To standardize evaluation, we developed an Examination Rubric, containing evidence-based criteria for grading severity of lesions. We postulate the Rubric will improve lesion reporting and enhance quality of placental examination. We evaluated the interobserver variability in lesion grading between two pathologists using the Rubric. METHODS: Placentas sent to CHEO Pathology between Oct 1, 2013 -Dec 31, 2014 were randomly selected for evaluation (n=100). Pathology reports were reviewed for demographic data and macroscopic findings. Histology slides for each report were examined using the Rubric by two experienced perinatal pathologists, masked to clinical information apart from gestational age at delivery and macroscopic findings. Interobserver agreement between pathologists was assessed using weighted kappa (κ) scores with 95% confidence intervals. RESULTS: Of the first 100 cases selected, gestational age at delivery was not provided on the pathology report in 37 cases. An additional 61 cases were selected to obtain 100 cases with gestational age at delivery. Interobserver agreement between the pathologists varied, with welldefined lesions having higher agreement (maternal inflammatory response, κ=0.81 [0.70, 0.93]) and more subjective lesions having poorer agreement ( increased syncytial knots, κ=0.53 [0.37, 0.70]). Less common lesions (fibrinoid change) had either perfect agreement (κ=1.0) or were not observed.

In a large proportion of cases, gestational age at delivery was not provided. As lesions are evaluated in the context of placental age, omitting this information represents a major issue for reporting. Our preliminary evaluation of the Rubric identified grading criteria of lesions requiring revisions. Following revision, an additional set of cases will be reviewed to determine if the Rubric results in decreased variability and higher detection rates of significant lesions compared to non-standardized evaluation.

Coates, Rachael Bok, K Joseph Hurt. University of Colorado, Aurora, CO, USA. INTRODUCTION: Hydrogen sulfide (H 2 S) is produced endogenously from L-cysteine (L-Cys) by cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) and cystathionine γ-lyase (CSE). L-Cys can be degraded by cysteine deoxygenase (CDO) and cysteine sulfinic acid decarboxylase (CSAD) or glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminases (GOT1 and GOT2). In murine uterus, we have shown decreased CDO and increased CSE expression at labor on gestational day 19 (E19), suggesting increased L-Cys availability and H 2 S production. Inducing preterm (E15) labor or delaying term delivery (E19) with RU486 or progesterone (P 4 ) does not alter cysteine metabolic enzymes. We hypothesize that there may be compartment specific regulation of cysteine metabolism in uterus and placenta. We examined the expression of CBS, CSE, CDO, CSAD, GOT1 and GOT2 in placenta during mouse gestation and labor, and compared with non-pregnant (NP) maternal liver expression of these enzymes. METHODS: Placentae were collected from timed pregnant C57/Bl6 mice on gestational day 15-19 and at labor. Placentae were combined for each litter, and analyzed by western blot using specific antibodies for CBS, CSE, CDO, CSAD, GOT1 and GOT2. Enzyme expression was quantified using infrared fluorescence imaging, and internally normalized to NP liver control. Normalized expression is presented relative to β-actin at each gestational age. Data are mean ± SEM, and analyzed by Kruskal-Wallis test followed by Mann-Whitney U test. RESULTS: A 1.7 fold increase in CBS expression was seen over late gestation (E18-19; n=3-5; p<0.05). CSE increased across gestation to 1.4 fold in labor (n=2-6). No change was observed in CDO expression throughout gestation. CSAD remained unchanged from E15-19 but increased 3 fold in labor (n=3-5). GOT1 increased 2.2 fold at late gestation (E18-19; n=2-6) whereas GOT2 decreased at late gestation and labor (n=1-3). CONCLUSIONS: CSE and CBS expression is increased in term and labor placenta, similar to our findings in the myometrium. Unlike myometrium, there is no decrease in CDO across gestation. This suggests a compartment-specific regulation of L-Cys availability and possibly H 2 S production. Increased CSAD and GOT1 in labor suggest that taurine and sulfites may increase at term. The regulation of maternal and fetal transsulfuration enzymes may indicate novel roles for H 2 S production and amino acid metabolism in the fetus.
