back_matter.text: not work, to elicit apoptosis. SDF2 exhibits similar structure to proteins known to be involved in ER stress and, it is expressed in human placenta. Herein, we investigated a possible role of SDF2 in ER stress pathway in trophoblast cells. METHODS: HTR8-Svneo trophoblastic cell lineage was maintained in culture and induced to ER stress with tunicamycin for 3h, 6h and 24h. ER stress markers were evaluated by q-RT-PCR (sXBP1, CHOP and SDF2) and Western Blot (GRP78/BiP and SDF2). Cells were also silenced for SDF2 with siRNA and superexpressed with plasmid; the same factors were evaluated in both conditions. Apoptosis and cell survival were evaluated by caspase-3 and ATP production luminescence assays. RESULTS: In HTR8/SVneo cells, SDF2 is downregulated after 6h of treatment and it is restored after 24h. The survival marker GRP78/BiP is upregulated after 24h of tunicamycin treatment and, in silenced cells it is upregulated after 6h only. sXBP1 is upregulated in SDF2 silenced cells after 24h of tunicamycin treatment, while CHOP expression is downregulated in silenced cells. Caspase 3/ATP production was lower in the group SDF2-/-treated for 3 and 6h with tunicamycin, but increased after 24h. In SDF2 superexpression, caspase 3/ATP production increased in tunicamycin treated cells. CONCLUSIONS: GRP78/BiP, CHOP and sXBP1 are classical ER stress markers involved in cells survival/apoptosis decision. Cells treated with tunicamycin and silenced for SDF2 showed a pro-survival fate (upregulation of GRP78/BiP and sXBP1, downregulation of CHOP and reduction in caspase 3/ATP production), while superexpression of SDF2 showed a pro-apoptosis fate (increase of caspase 3/ATP production). Our data support a role for SDF2 in trophoblast cell survival/apoptosis in ER stress response.

Chronic placental hypoxia is a main contributing factor of placental insufficiency causing disruption of normal trophoblast (TB) development, invasion into maternal decidua, and remodeling of maternal spiral arteries (SA). In this study, pregnant guinea pigs were used as a model to study the effects of intrauterine hypoxia. Guinea pig has a hemomonochorial placenta, a villous subplacenta analogous to human placenta cell columns, and deep TB invasion and remodeling of maternal SA, making it an excellent animal model for studying the mechanisms of human placental development. We tested the hypothesis that chronic intrauterine hypoxia of the pregnant guinea pig stimulates proliferation but inhibits TB invasion and SA remodeling. METHODS: Time-mated pregnant guinea pigs were exposed to either normoxic (NMX) or hypoxic (HPX;10.5%O 2 ) conditions at 20d gestation (implantation at 23d) until mid-term (40d) or near-term (65d). From euthanized animals placentas were excised, weighed, and frozen in liquid N 2 for RNA extraction and qRT-PCR, or perfusion-fixed with formalin for IHC for TB (KRT7), blood vessels (SMA-smooth muscle actin, vWF-endothelium), and proliferation (PCNA) in the placenta and associated uterine tissue. RESULTS: At term, hypoxia increased mean maternal arterial blood pressure (HPX 57.9±2.3 vs NMX 40.4±2.3, p<0.001), decreased fetal weight by 16.1% (p<0.05), and increased absolute and relative placenta to fetal weight by 10.1% and 31.8%, respectively (p<0.05). At mid-term, there was a significant increase in TB in HPX placentas as confirmed by elevated ESX1 gene expression (p<0.05), and staining for PCNA and KRT7. Image analysis of the decidua revealed that HPX placentas had a 39.2% decrease in the KRT7:vWF signal ratio, and evaluation of individual maternal vessels showed reduced occupation and remodeling by KRT7 positive TB in HPX placentas.

The HPX placenta compensates maladaptively by stimulating TB proliferation but inhibiting invasion into the SA. We conclude that oxygenation of the placenta regulates normal SA remodeling and that HPX conditions contribute to inadequate blood flow and placental insufficiency leading to maternal hypertension and fetal growth restriction. This is the first evidence of hypoxia-induced repression of SA remodeling in guinea pig placenta. (n=12) was chronically instrumented under anaesthesia at 119±2 d with a wireless data acquisition system to record maternal arterial pressure, uterine blood flow and vascular resistance. Five days later, half of these pregnancies were exposed to hypoxia (10% O 2 ) for 10 days in the isobaric chambers. RESULTS: Hypoxic pregnancy led to FGR (3.5±0.2 vs. 2.7±0.2 Kg; P<0.05) and increased the placental expression of protein disulphide isomerase (PDI), glucose related protein 78 (GRP78) and phosphorylated-p38 (P-p38) while reducing calreticulin; molecular changes associated with ER and oxidative stress ( Fig. 1 A-D) . Hypoxic pregnancy also prevented the fall in maternal arterial blood pressure and in uterine vascular resistance with advancing gestation (Fig. 1 E, F) . CONCLUSIONS: Chronic hypoxic pregnancy in sheep impairs uterine perfusion with advancing gestation, promoting relative maternal hypertension and placental ER stress which may lead to protein synthesis inhibition and FGR. These effects may link the low birth weight and increased prevalence of preeclampsia associated with hypoxic pregnancy. Support: British Heart Foundation *Figure(s) will be available online. RNA-Seq on all samples was used to identify genes possibly implicated in causing the DNA damage and pharmacologic and siRNA treatments were used to establish causation.

Trophoblast cells from patient M1 were highly positive for γH2AX immunostaining (39.5% vs 5.5-17.3% in controls). PolyA RNA-seq, qPCR and immunoblotting from the cultured cells revealed that L1 gene and protein expression was markedly elevated compared with controls.. To determine whether L1 caused the DNA damage or was just associated with the damage, L1 activity was blocked by treating the cultured cells with the reverse transcriptase inhibitor azidothimidine (AZT). AZT-treatment resulted in a >50% increase of γH2AX positivity in cells cultured from patient M1, but not in cells from other spontaneous and elective abortion samples. siRNA-targeted L1 knockdown in cells cultured from patient M1 resulted in a 50% decrease of γH2AX levels in cells collected from patient M1 but had no effect in controls or when scrambled siRNAs were used. Immunoblot analysis using an antibody against the apoptosis marker Caspase-3 revealed high level of Caspase-3 in the cultured cells from our patient, whereas no apoptosis in control cells was detected. Remarkably, AZT-treated and L1 knockdown cells from patient M1 demonstrated an increase and reduction in Caspase-3 , respectively. CONCLUSIONS: The L1 family of endogenous retrovirus, thought to be an ancient relic in our genome, caused DNA damage-induced apoptosis in a patient with unexplained RPL. In vitro, this damage is reversible under specific experimental conditions. Placentation is an intricate process that involves signaling not just from one individual but entails a finely orchestrated cellular and molecular interplay of 2 separate individuals, both mother and fetus, requiring a significant amount of crosstalk at the maternal fetal interface. However, in ongoing human pregnancies this crosstalk is poorly understood, as there is no means of assessing the underlying signaling between mother and fetus. To better understand the interactions at the maternal fetal interface, we conducted a 2 step approach to better define the crosstalk that takes place. First, we performed an in silico assessment of receptors/ligands in the uterus and placenta and then proceeded with RNA sequencing from matched maternal decidua and fetal chorionic villi from the same pregnancies to determine which receptor ligand pairs may be critical during this period of placentation. METHODS: In silico assessment was performed first by identifying all receptors in the uterus through Unigene (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ unigene/). Identification of potential ligands for all receptors identified from the uterus was performed using the Human Plasma Membrane Receptome (http://reprobio.stanford.edu/hsueh/). Further, identification of placental receptors and identification of potential ligands was performed in a similar fashion. RNA sequencing was performed from 8 matched maternal decidua/ fetal chorionic villus pairs of ongoing healthy pregnancies.

A total of 864 receptors were identified in the uterus. Of those identified receptors, 153 have at least 1 known ligand. In the placenta, we identified 882 receptors with 103 receptors having at least 1 known ligand. RNA sequencing was performed on the 8 matched maternal decidua/ fetal chorionic villus pairs which are currently being analyzed to look at transcript abundance of receptor ligand pairs identified by our in silico assessment. CONCLUSIONS: Our unique 2 step approach to identify signaling among mother and fetus has led to the identification of potentially unique receptor ligand pairs that may play a role in the crosstalk among the maternal fetal interface.

We found that expression levels of more than 1000 genes dramatically changed (> 10-fold increase or decrease) during differentiation of CTs to EVTs or STs. In STs, genes encoding hormones and other pregnancy-specific secretory proteins were strongly induced and genes regulating the cell cycle were downregulated, suggesting that STs are highly specialized cells for the production of secretory proteins. In EVTs, immune-related genes such as chemokines and the human leukocyte antigens were significantly induced, which might be

important for the migration of EVTs and their interaction with the maternal immune system. We also identified 100 genes specifically expressed in CTs, some of which are known to be essential for the maintenance of mouse trophoblast stem cells or labyrinth trophoblast progenitor cells. Furthermore, we found hundreds of exon-skipping events differentially regulated among trophoblast cells. CONCLUSIONS: These data will increase our understanding of normal placental development and the pathogenesis of pregnancy complications.

The Interplay Between Endothelin-1 (ET-1) Pre-eclampsia (PE) is a severe pregnancy complication associated with impaired trophoblast invasion in the first trimester of pregnancy. Endothelin-1 (ET-1) is up-regulated in PE and is also a regulator of cell migration and invasion. Since matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-15 plays a crucial role in these processes, we hypothesize that increased levels of ET-1 modify MMP-15 expression in human first trimester trophoblasts and that this effect is further modulated by PE characteristic stimuli such as TNF-α and hypoxia. METHODS: Primary human trophoblasts isolated from first trimester placenta (week 7 to 12 of gestation) were incubated in the absence or the presence of 100nM ET-1. MMP-15 mRNA and protein were quantified by RT-qPCR and Western blotting, respectively. ET-1 functional effects were analysed by MMP-2 zymography. ET-1 biological effects were tested as trophoblast outgrowth in first trimester chorionic villous explants. The role of TNF-α (25ng/ml) and hypoxia (1% O 2 ) on ET-1-mediated MMP-15 regulation was assessed by Western Blotting. RESULTS: ET-1 down-regulated MMP-15 mRNA and protein (by 27% and 26%, respectively, p≤0.05). This was paralleled by a down-regulation of MMP-2 protein (-17%, p≤0.05) and by an inhibition of trophoblast outgrowth in placental explants (-26%, p≤0.05). TNF-α did not directly affect MMP-15 expression, but enhanced ET-1 mediated MMP-15 downregulation by 12% (p≤0.05). Preliminary results showed that hypoxia down-regulated MMP-15 protein levels (by 44%) and even increased the effect of ET-1 on MMP-15 down-regulation by 8%. CONCLUSIONS: ET-1 down-regulates MMP-15 expression in human first trimester trophoblasts, leading to a decrease in MMP-2 activation and a reduction of trophoblast invasion. This effect is enhanced in the presence of a pro-inflammatory cytokine, or hypoxic environment, which are characteristic for PE. Thus, ET-1 might stimulate the impairment of trophoblast invasion observed in PE. Aged or damaged regions of the syncytiotrophoblast are shed into the maternal blood as syncytial nuclear aggregates (SNAs). These SNAs are cleared from the maternal body, at least in part, by pulmonary endothelial cells that phagocytose them. The effects of phagocytosing SNAs on endothelial cells is not fully established but we have shown that SNAs from normal pregnancies regulate the transcriptome of endothelial cells 1 and surprisingly up regulate the expression of "placenta-specific genes" such as human placental lactogen (hPL); chorionic gonadotropin alpha (CGA) and pregnancy specific beta-1-glycoprotein 3 (PSG3). Here we investigate the mechanism of this up regulation. METHODS: First trimester placentas (n=12) were obtained with informed consent following termination of pregnancies. SNAs were harvested from cultured placental explants as described before 2 . The endothelial cell line HMEC-1 was cultured with SNAs for 2, 24 or 48 hours in the presence or absence of 2 µM of 5-Ethynyl Uridine (5EU) to distinguish the newly transcribed RNA from the total RNA. At the end of each time point, total RNA or newly generated RNA was isolated from the SNAs-treated endothelial cells or the SNAs alone controls and reverse transcribed into cDNA for qRT-PCR. RESULTS: 1) qRT-PCR using total RNA demonstrated that control SNAs cultured in the absence of HMEC-1 for up to 24 hours contained extremely low levels of transcripts for hPL and by 48 hours these transcripts were undetectable. Whereas, HMEC-1 had expressed de novo transcripts for hPL at 2 hours after phagocytosing SNAs and continued to generate these transcripts for at least 48 hours, p<0.001. 2) qRT-PCR using newly transcribed RNA isolated from SNAs-treated HEMC-1 or SNAs alone confirmed that SNAs cultured in the absence of endothelial cells did not generate new transcripts for hPL but that endothelial cells did synthesise transcripts for hPL after phagocytosing SNAs, p<0.00001. CONCLUSIONS: After extrusion from the syncytium, most SNAs have little capacity to synthesise new mRNA. However, SNAs carry as yet unidentified regulators that can induce the de novo expression of placenta-specific genes in endothelial cells. Thus in effect SNAs expand production of pro-pregnancy factors to extra-placental sites. (ADM2), secreted by human blastocysts and expressed in placenta, promotes trophoblast invasion in the 1 st trimester of human pregnancy. Lower levels of ADM2 are associated with spontaneous abortion and inhibition of the endogenous ADM2 function in early rat pregnancy results in reduced implantation rate, restricted feto-placental growth and impaired placental vasculature. However, it is not known if ADM2 has a role in modulating the phenotypical changes in trophoblast stem cells. Current study was designed to assess the effect of ADM2 on the differentiation of trophoblast stem cells (Rcho-1) into giant trophoblasts. METHODS: RCHO-1 cells were seeded in 6-well plates in either stem cell medium (RPMI-1640 with 20% Fetal bovine serum, 50 µM 2-β-ME) for a 24hrs treatment with ADM2 (10 -8 M-10 -7 M) at 37 0 C, or in stem cell medium for 24hrs followed by differentiation medium (NCTC-135 medium with 1% horse serum, 50 µM 2-β-ME ) and culturing further at for 3 days in presence or absence of ADM2 (10 -8 M-10 -7 M). Rcho-1 cell spheroids were prepared by hanging drop method using 700 cells per drop. Spheroids were transferred onto a monolayer of smooth muscle cells and cultured for 72hrs in differentiation medium in presence or absence of ADM2 (10 -7 M). Morphological changes were assessed with Olympus U-TV1 microscope. Expression of mRNA were assessed by real time PCR. RESULTS: 1) ADM2 increases the formation of giant trophoblast cells in the stem cell population of Rcho-1 cells, 2) ADM2 increases the expression of both, stem cell markers Essrb1 and Id1, and differentiation markers prl3b1 and plf (P<0.05) in Rcho-1 cells, and these effects are inhibited by ADM2 antagonist, 3) ADM2 increases the expression of steroidogenic enzymes, STAR, sf1, 3bHSD1, 3bHSD2 and 17bHSD1 in differentiated Rcho-1 cells (P<0.05), and 4) compared to the control, ADM2 increases the differentiation of cells at the periphery of the Rcho-1 spheroids CONCLUSIONS: ADM2 induced increases in the expression of stem cell markers, differentiation markers and steroidogenic enzymes in Rcho-1 cells suggest an important role for ADM2 in regulating trophoblast stem cells phenotype to support placental formation. There are major sexually dimorphic differences in perinatal morbidity and mortality but the mechanisms that confer these differences are unclear. Our research and the work of others, suggest that glucocorticoids may play a role in regulating sex specific differences in placental function and fetal growth during pregnancy. We have recently identified there are twelve isoforms of the glucocorticoid receptor in the human placental trophoblast that vary with fetal sex, gestational age at delivery, maternal asthma and maternal betamethasone exposure. The current study was designed to determine if there are differences in placental glucocorticoid regulated pathways in association with the expression of different GR isoforms in term pregnancies complicated by asthma. METHODS: Placentae from pregnancies complicated maternal asthma (term deliveries, n=8) were analysed by Western blot to determine their GR protein profile. Placental RNA was extracted and GR regulated pathways were examined using a GR PCR array. Data was analysed based on fetal sex and presence and absence of maternal asthma.

In the presence of maternal asthma there was a predominance of GRβ and GRα-D1 in male placentae relative to male controls. In female placentae of pregnancies complicated by asthma there was a predominance of GRα A with GRα C and GRα-D3. In association with these differences in GR isoform expression, we observed no significant alterations in GR regulated genes in placentae of males regardless of the presence of maternal asthma. In females there was a significant decrease in the expression of AFF1, ANGPTL4, ATF4, CEBPB, CREB3, NFκB1A, PLEKHF1, POU2F1, SLC22A5, STAT5A (t test, P<0.05) in the presence of maternal asthma. CONCLUSIONS: This work suggests that glucocorticoid regulation of placental genes is dependent on the GR isoform pattern of expression. Understanding how changes in the GR proteomic profile between the sexes can drive differences in the regulation of the fetal-placental response to maternal inflammation will contribute significantly to determining the mechanisms that influence sex differences in perinatal outcome.

Changes Phloridzin, a standard CNT inhibitor, also exhibited marked inhibition of entecavir uptake. Tenofovir accumulation in the cell was 5 to 10 times lower than that of entecavir. Tenofovir accumulated intracellularly when ENT was inhibited by NBMPR, but was unchanged by CNT inhibition. Sofosbuvir uptake was not affected by inhibition of any transporter despite demonstrating saturable kinetics. CONCLUSIONS: Chronic HCV alters ENT1, ENT2, and CNT1 in human placenta which could affect maternal and/or fetal concentrations of antiviral agents. The results further indicate different interaction profiles of antiviral nucleoside drugs with human placental nucleoside transporter proteins.

We confirmed that maternal obesity was associated with significantly decreased (P<0.05) trophoblast mitochondrial respiration parameters. Addition of NaSe had a biphasic effect on respiratory parameters in trophoblast from both groups of women with stimulation from 50 to 800nM but subsequent inhibition at >800nM NaSe. Syncytiotrophoblasts from lean women appeared more sensitive than those of obese women with the greatest increase (p<0.05) in basal and maximal respiration, and spare capacity compared to control by 400nM. Addition of NaSe had no effect on basal respiration and required 800nM NaSe for a significant effect (p<0.05) on maximal respiration and spare capacity in cells from obese women. CONCLUSIONS: These data indicate that NaSe is able to increase mitochondrial respiration in primary syncytiotrophoblasts. Addition of NaSe to BeWo cells reportedly increases GPx activity, also in a biphasic manner with stimulation followed by inhibition at higher concentrations. Our data are consistent with NaSe induction of GPx activity reducing oxidative stress and increasing mitochondrial activity. The reduced sensitivity of trophoblast from obese women may be explained by their existing greater oxidative stress. Antioxidants such as NaSe may improve both mitochondrial and placental dysfunction in complicated pregnancies.

mTORC2 signaling and down-regulation of placental nutrient transporters. These changes are believed to directly contribute to the restricted fetal growth because mTOR signaling is a positive regulator of placental amino acid transport. We hypothesized that mTOR activation in primary trophoblast cells isolated from placentas of baboons subjected to MNR will improve placental insulin responsiveness, restore normal placental insulin-mTORC1/2 signaling and nutrient uptake capacity. METHODS: Pregnant baboons were fed either a control (n=8) or MNR diet (70% of control, n=8) from 30 days gestation (G) At 140 days G, placentas were collected. Primary Baboon Trophoblast (PBT) cells were isolated, cultured for 18 h and transfected with siRNA targeting DEPTOR (activation of mTORC1/2) or scrambled siRNA (control). PBT cells were allowed to syncytialize in culture and incubated in 5.8 ng ml -1 insulin and 300 ng ml -1 insulin-like growth factor 1 from 66 to 90 h in culture. System A and L amino acid transport activity was measured at 90 hours. RESULTS: Basal System A (-66%, p<0.01) and L (-70%, p<0.01) uptake was decreased and growth factors failed to stimulate System A/L uptake in MNR PBT cells as compared to control cells. Transfection with DEPTOR siRNA increased basal System A (+114%, p<0.001) and L uptake (+85%, p<0.01) and restored growth factor stimulation of amino acid uptake in MNR PBT cell. CONCLUSIONS: In a pregnant baboon nutrient restriction model with similarities to human IUGR, activation of mTORC1/2 signaling in MNR PBT restored insulin responsiveness and System A and L nutrient transport. Intervention strategies aiming at activating placental mTOR signaling may be effective to normalize placental nutrient transport and enhance fetal growth in IUGR. Grant support: NIH-HD 21350. is associated with preterm birth. IAI is also associated with an upregulation in neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL) expression in trophoblast tissues in vivo. NGAL is a lipocalin that plays a critical role in innate immunity. This study aims to investigate the effect of inflammatory cytokines and LPS on NGAL mRNA expression in a human cytotrophoblast cell line (HTR8/SVneo) and the mechanisms that regulate IAI.

The HTR8/SVneo cell lines were treated with/without IL-1β (0.1, 1 and 10ng/mL), TNFα (1, 10 and 100ng/ml) and LPS (0.1, 1 and 10 µg/ml) for 4 and 24 hours. Total RNA was harvested and RT-qPCR was used to quantify NGAL mRNA expression and normalized to GAPDH. Data was analyzed using one-way ANOVA with the posthoc Dunnett's test. RESULTS: IL-1β at all doses significantly upregulated NGAL mRNA expression at 4 hours (0.1 ng/ml p=0.007, at 1 and 10 ng/ml, p<0.001) when compared with the unstimulated control *Figure(s) will be available online. IL-1β at 1 and 10ng/ml significantly upregulated NGAL mRNA expression at 24 hours (p<0.001) when compared with the unstimulated control *Figure(s) will be available online. TNFα and LPS had no effect on NGAL mRNA expression. CONCLUSIONS: Our findings demonstrate that IL-1β but not TNFα or LPS stimulate NGAL mRNA expression in HTR8/SVneo cells in particularly at higher doses. These data provide important insights into the mechanism of upregulation of NGAL in IAI and may also be used to investigate NGAL function in vitro in future studies. property suggests that the placenta has innate defense mechanisms against microbial invasion and replication. Mammalian peptidoglycan recognition proteins are a family of innate immunity proteins that consists of four members: PGLYRP1-4. These proteins are present in intracellular vesicles and are secreted onto the skin and mucous membranes where they protect against infection by binding to and killing both gram-positive and gramnegative bacteria. We hypothesized that PGLYRPs are expressed in the placenta where they might also participate in protection from infection.

Real-time RT-qPCR, western blot, immunohistochemistry, and flow cytometry were used to analyze expression of PGLYRP1-4 in human term placental tissue or in trophoblast cell lines. Trophoblast cell lines were treated with different microbial associated molecular patterns (MAMPs) for 24 hr and changes in cellular PGLYRP expression were measured. RESULTS: Expression of PGLYRP1, 3, and 4, but not PGLYRP2, was observed in placental tissue by western blot and by RT-qPCR using two different primer sets for each gene. Immunohistochemical staining of term placenta revealed highest expression of PGLYRP1, 3, and 4 in the syncytiotrophoblast layer. Cellular levels of PGLYRP1 and PGLYRP3 were decreased by 50% in Swan.71 cells following exposure to MAMPs. Similarly, PGLYRP3 levels were decreased in 3aSubE cells, while PGLYRP1 levels were not altered. CONCLUSIONS: These results show that the human placenta expresses PGLYRPs in the syncytiotrophoblast. Exposure of trophoblast cells to bacterial cell wall components resulted in reduced intracellular levels of PGLYRP, which is consistent with stimulated protein secretion as an anti-bacterial defense mechanism. Thus, PGLYRPs may also contribute to the placental innate immunity to bacterial infection. RESULTS: : There were 71 and 257 subjects in the RPOCs and myomectomy groups respectively. There were no intraoperative complications. There were 28 pregnancies in the RPOC group and 39 pregnancies in the myomectomy group. There were no significant differences in birth weight or preterm delivery. Although a higher rate of abnormal placentation was observed in the RPOC group, this difference was not statistically significant (25% vs. 7.6%, p=0.107). Of the subjects in the RPOC group, 47 had an intrauterine catheter placed for 3-14 days post operatively. There were no differences in abnormal placentation (17.6% vs. 8.5%, p=0.370), birth weight (3.17Kg vs. 3.41Kg, p=0.220) or the presence of intrauterine adhesions on postoperative imaging (30% vs. 29%, p= 1.00) between the two groups. Placement of an intrauterine catheter was associated with a lower rate of preterm delivery (40% vs. 5%, p=0.031) (gestational age <37 weeks). CONCLUSIONS: This is the first study to examine pregnancy outcomes following hysteroscopic resection of RPOCs. Our data support that hysteroscopic resection of RPOCs is a safe procedure with no increase in adverse pregnancy outcomes compared to other hysteroscopic procedures. Our data suggest that placement of intrauterine catheter may play a beneficial role, however further studies are needed to elucidate its role in in hysteroscopic management of RPOC. Larger studies are also needed to evaluate the effect of hysteroscopic management of RPOC on placentation. that displays an uncovered SVVYGLR domain, which binds neutrophil specific integrin α9β1. Significantly increased OPN levels in human endometrium during the mid-secretory phase and in decidualized HESC cultures led us to posit that pLARCs induce OPN overexpression in human endometria, and that increased local nOPN levels resulting from excess thrombin cleaved intact OPN trigger endometrial neutrophil infiltration/ activation. METHODS: Paired endometrial sections (n=5) from women pre and 3 months post Depo-medroxyprogesterone acetate (DepoMPA) use were immunostained with OPN or nOPN and neutrophil elastase antibodies. Human leukocytes isolated from peripheral blood of healthy donors (n=2) by Ficoll gradient were seeded in upper insert wells then placed in 24-well plates containing control or 1U/ml Th or 10ng/ml recombinant (r)-OPN or Th+r-OPN for 12 h. Neutrophil elastase immunoassays compared migrated neutrophil numbers among the groups. RESULTS: Immunostained human endometria displayed increased total (Mean±SEM; 227.13±10.4 vs. 133.63±15.5; p<0.001) and N-half OPN (87.13±29.3 vs. 176.375±20.3; p<0.05) levels in post vs. pre-DepoMPA use, respectively. Stronger perivascular nOPN immunoreactivity was evident vs. other endometrial compartments from post vs pre-DepoMPA use. Moreover, a 3-fold increase in neutrophil numbers were found in post-DepoMPA exposed endometria (p<0.001), with intense nOPN immunoreactivity co-localized to perivascular areas displaying excess neutrophil infiltration. In culture, compared to controls (0.03±0.007) thrombin + r-OPN treatment (0.182±0.005) increased neutrophil migration by 6-fold (p<0.01); neither thrombin nor r-OPN alone exerted a significant effect. CONCLUSIONS: These in situ and in vitro findings reveal that thrombincleaved nOPN promotes pLARC-induced AUB by recruiting/activating neutrophils, a potent source of perivascular ECM degrading proteases.
Lower Specific Activity (%) of Myeloperoxidase (MPO) in Endometriosis.

Total and active MPO levels did not differ significantly among endometriosis cases and controls (p = 0.1113 and p = 0.5396, respectively). However, the specific MPO activity (%) was significantly lower in women with endometriosis than in controls (p = 0.0182). When assessing the different cycle phases, specific MPO activity (%) was significantly decreased in the luteal phase exclusively (p = 0.0330). CONCLUSIONS: Systemic MPO levels may not be suited as a single biomarker for endometriosis. We have reported an altered specific activity of MPO in endometriosis, indicating an altered inflammatory and immune response in these patients. Adenomyosis is an uterine disorder characterized by intense menstrual and non-menstrual-related painful symptoms, as well as abnormal uterine bleeding and infertility. The pathogenesis of adenomyosis indicates that endometrial cells invade and proliferate within myometrium, with mechanisms similar to those of endometriosis, in which inflammatory mediators and neurogenic factors participate to the intense painful symptoms. Given the similarity between adenomyosis and endometriosis, the present study aimed to evaluate the mRNA and protein expression of inflammatory and neurogenic factors in both adenomyotic nodules and eutopic endometrium of patients with adenomyosis. METHODS: Corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH)-family members (CRH, urocortin (Ucn), Ucn2), CRH-receptors (CRH-R1, CRH-R2) and nerve growth factor (NGF) mRNA expression and protein localization were analyzed by RT-PCR, IHC and IF. RESULTS: CRH, Ucn, Ucn2 and CRH receptors (CRH-R1 and CRH-R2) mRNAs expression was detected in both eutopic and ectopic endometrium from patients with adenomyosis. Moreover, adenomyotic nodules and eutopic endometrium of patients with adenomyosis expressed NGF mRNA. Protein expression of CRH and NGF was confirmed by immunohistochemical and immunofluorescence analysis in all the specimens analyzed. In particular, the presence of these peptides was observed in both glandular and stromal cells of eutopic endometrium and adenomyotic nodules. CONCLUSIONS: The present study, showing that adenomyotic nodules are novel site of expression of inflammatory mediators of the CRH-family and NGF, contribute to explain the mechanisms underlining inflammation and pain in adenomyosis. Endometriosis is a gynecological disorder which is a major cause of chronic pelvic pain and infertility. Though the prevalence of the disease has been known for more than a century the molecular mechanisms associated with the pathophysiology of the endometriosis related infertility are poorly understood. The Hippo signaling pathway is an evolutionary conserved pathway which regulates cellular events such as proliferation and apoptosis which are also know to be altered in women with endometriosis. In the present study we have tried to understand the role of Hippo signaling in the eutopic endometrium(EuE) of baboons and women with endometriosis. METHODS: Total RNA from the mid-secretory EuE extracted from the same group of baboons(n=4) before and 15 months after the induction of endometriosis were analyzed for molecules involved in Hippo signaling pathway. Immunohistochemical analysis was performed for YAP protein to validate the mRNA changes. Mid-secretory endometrial biopsies were obtained from control(n=6) and women with endometriosis(n=8) and proteins were isolated to perform western blot analysis for TAZ protein.

Induction of endometriosis leads to the altered expression of several genes(NF2, Mst1, Mst2, WW45, Lats1, Lats2, Mob1, YAP, TAZ) associated with Hippo signaling. The mRNA expression of WW45 and Lats1 was significantly(p<0.05) increased in EuE of baboon with endometriosis compared to controls. Although we did not observe significant increased in YAP mRNA levels in baboons with disease, we did observe a higher signal for YAP protein staining in glandular epithelium and stroma of EuE of baboons with endometriosis. Western blot analysis for TAZ protein revealed increased levels of TAZ in the EuE of women with endometriosis compared to women without disease.

Induction of endometriosis causes changes in the mRNA and protein expression of members of Hippo signaling pathway in EuE of baboons and women with endometriosis. YAP and TAZ proteins levels were increased in EuE of baboon and women respectively with the disease. This study reveals role for the Hippo signaling in regulating the cellular events, i.e. proliferation and apoptosis, which are associated with the pathophysiology of endometriosis.

Endometriosis Is Associated with Neurogenic Inflammation in a Rat Model of Dyspareunia. Anne-Marie Coelho, 1 Melanie Hermann, 1 Kerstin Kopp, 1 Michael Vos, 1 Mark Gemkow, 1 Markus Koch, 2 Jens Nagel, 2 Susan Boyce. 1 1 Evotec AG, Hamburg, Germany; 2 Bayer Pharma AG, Berlin, Germany. INTRODUCTION: Neurogenic inflammation (NI) is likely to be of relevance in endometriosis since, in human endometriotic tissues, neuropeptides like substance P (SP) and calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) were found expressed in sensory nerve fibers of peritoneal and deep infiltrating lesions. These neuropeptides contribute to NI by causing vasodilatation, plasma extravasation and cellular infiltration. In the context of the Bayer HealthCare-Evotec strategic alliance on endometriosis therapy initiated in 2012, the present study aimed to confirm the presence of CGRP, SP and its neurokinin 1 receptor (NK1R) in a recently established animal model of endometriosis-induced dyspareunia. METHODS: Endometriosis was induced in cycling rats by an autotransplantation of uterine biopsies onto abdominal arteries of the mesentery and the colon. Six (6) weeks after the surgery, biopsies were collected and analyzed by an immuno-histochemical (IHC) approach to identify the localization and expression pattern of CGRP, SP and NK1R, as well as PGP9.5, a marker of nerve fibers. All in vivo experiments were conducted in accordance with Evotec AG policies, AAALAC guidelines and the Directive 2010/63/EU as well as the German Animal Welfare Act. RESULTS: Compared to controls, animals implanted with uterine biopsies presented ectopic growths/lesions around blood vessels of the intestinal mesentery and on the colonic wall. These lesions developed rapidly in volume and weight during the first 6 weeks after autoimplantation. Using IHC techniques, SP and NK1R immunoreactivities (-ir) were detected in the lesions from both the mesentery and the colon. Staining analysis showed a co-localization of these markers with CGRPand PGP9.5-ir confirming presence on peptidergic positive sensory fibers in the lesions. In some of the lesions, SP-and NK1R-ir were also found to be present on purinergic nerve fibers or on infiltrating immune cells, which could possibly be mast cells. CONCLUSIONS: In the rat model of dyspareunia, IHC analysis of the implanted uterine biopsies revealed the presence of SP-and NK1Rimmunoreactivity on sensory nerve fibers innervating the lesions. These findings are consistent with observations in human endometriotic lesions and support a role of NI in the development of mechanical hyperalgesia observed in our animal model of endometriosis-induced dyspareunia. Endometriosis is a chronic, mainly estrogendependent disease characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus in the peritoneal cavity. Aldo-keto reductase 1C3 (AKR1C3/ 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 5) is an enzyme, combining 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase and prostaglandin (PG) F synthase activity. AKR1C3 has been described to play a crucial role in intra-tissue steroid and prostaglandin metabolism. Expression of the enzyme in lesions is expected to lead to increased local concentrations of steroid hormones (especially estradiol) and of PGF2α. This proestrogenic environment with increased PGF2α concentration is thought to stimulate proliferation and growth of estrogen-sensitive endometriotic lesions. To demonstrate the role of AKR1C3 in endometriosis, a novel

and selective AKR1C3 inhibitor was identified and tested in a marmoset monkey endometriosis model, as no AKR1C3 orthologues are present in rodent species. METHODS: AKR1C3 expression in human endometriotic and endometrial samples was studied by Affymetrix analysis. Localization of AKR1C3 in endometriotic lesions was performed by immunohistochemistry (IHC). BAY-688, a potent and selective AKR1C3 inhibitor was generated and tested in a marmoset endometriosis model for the effect on lesion size reduction. In this model endometriosis was induced as described by Einspanier et al. (2006) . RESULTS: AKR1C3 mRNA is strongly up-regulated in human endometriotic lesions compared to control endometrium, indicating a potentially important role in endometriosis. IHC confirmed strong expression of AKR1C3 in human lesions. A novel potent and selective AKR1C3 inhibitor (BAY-688) was generated. BAY-688 showed strong efficacy in a primate endometriosis model, in which total endometriotic lesion size was reduced by ~70% of baseline after 6 weeks treatment with BAY-688. CONCLUSIONS: In marmoset monkeys with established endometriosis, BAY-688 showed a significant effect on endometriotic lesion shrinkage. These results suggest that AKR1C3 plays a crucial role in endometriosis. Since AKR1C3 is not expressed in the ovary, effects on the ovarian cycle are not expected. BAY-688 is a promising new molecule for the treatment of endometriosis.

Impact Endometriosis results from the implantation and growth of endometrial tissue displaced into the pelvis via retrograde menstruation. This disease is a principle cause of pelvic pain and infertility. Severe endometriosis is strongly associated with junctional zone (endometrium and subendometrial myometrium interface) thickening. A growing body of evidence suggests that junctional zone hyperplasia may alter the peristaltic activity, reducing uterine transport capacity of the inner myometrium and leading to elevated retrograde flow. Using a high fidelity murine model of endometriosis, we examined whether pelvic endometriosis alters genetic and protein characteristics of the myometrium. METHODS: Donor mRFP1 transgenic female mice were induced to develop menstrual endometrium for intraperitoneal injection into menstrually synchronized wild-type C57BL/6J recipient females. Two weeks following the initial injection, recipient mice received a second inoculation of mRFP1 endometrial material. Uterine horns from age matched controls and recipients were removed two weeks after receiving the second injection and analyzed by immunohistochemistry and qRT-PCR. RESULTS: Recipient mice with induced endometriosis exhibited myometrial thickening with a significant increase of α-smooth muscle actin immunereactivity and expression [ Figure 1 ]. In addition, significant up-regulation of additional muscle genes where observed: myosin heavy chain 11 (Myh11), smooth muscle protein 22-alpha (SM22a), and calponin 1 (Cnn1). CONCLUSIONS: These findings suggest that endocrine signaling from ectopic endometrium can alter the molecular signature and induce thickening of the myometrium. The myometrial layer of the uterus is composed of an intricate network of smooth muscle fibers, and plays an important role in uterine tonicity. The evidence presented here supports endometriosis impacts the myometrium and may contribute to the pathophysiology of endometriosis. *Figure(s) will be available online. Resistance to conventional therapy critically raises the need for novel therapeutic options. Dopamine receptor 2 (DRD2) has been associated with endometriosis in genetic studies. KLF11 regulates DRD2 expression in neurons via an epigenetic heterochromatin protein 1/histone methyl transferase (HP1/HMT) mediated mechanism. We characterized the regulatory relationship of KLF11 and DRD2 in the context of endometriosis with potential translational implications.

In vitro experiments were performed in Ishikawa and human endometrial stromal (T-HESC) cells. Epigenetic cofactor binding mutants KLF11EAPP or KLF11del486 were generated by in vitro mutagenesis. To enable comparison of human and animal model data rat, mouse, and human DRD2 promoter activity was determined using luciferase assays. Promoter binding was determined by chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP). Gene expression was determined by qPCR, western blot and immunohistochemistry. In vivo disease relevance was evaluated in a surgically induced murine endometriosis model using KLF11-/-and wild-type mice; lesional Drd2 expression was evaluated by immunohistochemistry. RESULTS: DRD2 was expressed in human and mouse endometrial epithelial cells and in intact endometrium. KLF11 directly bound the DRD2 promoter in endometrial cells. DRD2 Promoter binding by KLF11 resulted in repression via the region encompassing the cognate binding element. Promoter repression resulted in diminished DRD2 transcript and protein expression levels. wt-KLF11 repression was reversed when cells were treated with KLF11EAPP and KLF11D486 mutants that do not bind and recruit the epigenetic histone deacetylase or heterochromatin protein 1/histone methyl transferase mechanisms. Consistent with loss of Klf11 repression, lesions in Klf11-/-animals had activated Drd2 expression which was diminished by targeted epigenetic inhibitor therapy. CONCLUSIONS: Contrary to activation in neurons, KLF11 is a DRD2 repressor in the endometrium, primarily via selective recruitment of epigenetic corepressors rather than activators. KLF11 is thus an epigenetic modulator via tissue-specific cofactor utilization. Characterization of such differential regulatory mechanisms have translational relevance in health and disease.
Whole Exome Sequencing of Endometriosis Patients Uncovers Mutations with Large Effects. Kenneth Ward, Rakesh Chettier, Hans Albertsen. Juneau Biosciences, LLC, Salt Lake City, UT, USA.

Family and twin studies have confirmed the heritability of endometriosis and genome wide association studies (GWAS) studies have implicated several chromosomal regions. By design, GWAS studies focus on common, ancestral mutations typically with smaller effects and with minor allele frequency >3%. In contrast, exome sequencing (ES) can detect private and rare gene variants with larger functional effects. In this study, we sequenced the exomes of 1,000 women with endometriosis to detect variants that predispose women to develop endometriosis. METHODS: ES was performed on 1,000 unrelated women with surgically-confirmed endometriosis using the Ion Proton platform (LifeScience Technologies). DNA variants were determined and confirmed using the Genome Analysis Toolkit (Broad). Prediction of protein function was evaluated using the Polyphen 2. Population allele frequencies were estimated using the Exome Aggregation Consortium (ExAC) data (n=33,500 individuals) which is expected to include the population rate of affected women and male "carriers". We examined damaging rare variants (ExAc MAF >0 but <0.01, and polyphen2 >0.447).

We found 15 rare variants in 6 genes with very large effects. 5.1% of endometriosis patients carry one of these variants, while the population data (with no selection for endometriosis) showed a 0.31% frequency. proposed to play a role in endometriotic lesion survival via its cell surface receptors CD74 and/or CXCR7. As expression of CD74 and CXCR7 is either incompletely understood or unknown, our objective was to define their expression in human eutopic endometrium and endometriotic lesions as well as in matched tissues from baboons with experimentally-induced disease. METHODS: Archival matched eutopic endometrial and endometriotic lesion tissues (N=10 proliferative stage; N=12 secretory stage) as well as control eutopic endometrial tissues from women without endometriosis (N=8 proliferative stage; N=11 secretory stage) were obtained. To determine the cause and effect relationship between eutopic and ectopic expression of these receptors, matched tissues were obtained (N=6) from baboons with experimentally-induced disease. For all studies, CD74 and CXCR7 expression was evaluated by immunohistochemistry. H-SCORE values were separately analyzed by one-way ANOVA or planned comparisons. RESULTS: Endometriotic eutopic endometrium, but not control, expressed significantly (P<0.05) greater CD74 staining in the glandular epithelium of the basalis layer and expression decreased in a graded fashion in glands of the functionalis layer. CD74 expression in lesion epithelial cells was significantly (P<0.01) greater compared to matched eutopic samples and this expression was independent of menstrual cycle stage. A similar pattern of expression was detected in both eutopic and ectopic endometrial tissue from baboons with experimentally induced disease. CXCR7 expression in control eutopic endometrium was minimal while epithelial cells of endometriotic eutopic endometrium expressed significantly (P<0.05) higher levels compared to stroma. Endometriotic epithelial CXCR7 expression was significantly (P<0.01) greater compared to both eutopic epithelial and endometriotic stroma expression. This pattern of expression in lesion, but not eutopic endometrium was recapitulated in baboons with experimentally-induced disease. CONCLUSIONS: These observations suggest that the ectopic lesion may influence eutopic CD74, but not CXCR7 expression and that endometriotic lesion CD74 and/or CXCR7 may contribute to MIF mediation of lesion survival. Endometriosis is a complex disease with an estimated heritable component of ~52%. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have so far identified nine genome-wide significant (P< 5 x 10 -8 ) common risk variants for endometriosis, which explain <4% of heritability; whereas half of heritability is estimated to comprise of such variants. Pathway analyses of GWAS data combine the evidence of single variants into gene-based measures, elucidating the evidence for certain pathways to be involved in disease pathogenesis and their contribution to heritability.

We used the International Endogene Consortium GWAS data, including 3,194 surgically confirmed endometriosis cases and 7,060 controls with genotype data imputed up to the 1000 Genomes reference panel-phase 3. Using two major pathway databases, MSigDB and PANTHER, we tested for enrichment of association signals in (1) all curated pathways (hypothesis-free), (2) pathways investigated previously in the literature, identified through systematic review of candidate genes and other targeted biological studies of endometriosis (hypothesis-driven). RESULTS: Hypothesis-free analysis showed 85 genetically enriched pathways with a nominal P<0.05, with the most significantly associated GRB2 SOS provides linkage to MAPK signaling for integrins pathway (nominal P=0.0001, FDR=0.0055) comprising 14 known genes and Wnt signaling pathway (nominal P=0.0259, FDR=0.0259) comprising 85 known genes. In the hypothesis-driven analysis the androgen estrogen progesterone biosynthesis -pathway showed significant genetic enrichment for stage III-IV endometriosis (FDR<0.05). Immunologyrelated pathways did not show significant genetic association enrichment, suggesting that differences in innate immune response do not play a major part in causality of endometriosis. CONCLUSIONS: With a recognized important role in endometrial biology, there should be an increased focus on the causal role of MAP kinase and Wnt signaling in endometriosis pathogenesis. The putative role of these pathways and contributing genes in relation to endometriosis as well as other diseases will be discussed. Elagolix is a novel oral gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist currently in development for the management of endometriosis pain and heavy menstrual bleeding associated with uterine fibroids. The objective of this study was to evaluate the effects of various doses of elagolix on gonadotropins and ovarian hormones in normal premenopausal women.

This was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multiple-ascending dose study conducted in 45 women. Treatment was initiated within 2 days following the start of the menstrual cycle. Each women received one of 6 elagolix regimens for 21 days: 150 mg once daily (QD), 100 mg, 200 mg, 300 mg, 400 mg twice daily (BID), or placebo. Intensive blood sampling was collected for the assay of estradiol (E2), progesterone (P), luteinizing hormone (LH), and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) through Day 21. Hormones were measured using chemiluminescent immunoassay methods. RESULTS: Elagolix administration resulted in dose-dependent suppression of FSH and LH, with maximal or near maximal suppression achieved at elagolix 300 mg BID. Dose-dependent E2 suppression was also observed, with maximum suppression reached at 200 mg BID (Figure 1 ). At doses of 100 mg BID or greater, P concentrations remained METHODS: The study included premenopausal women who were admitted to the hospital for myomectomy or hysterectomy. Using a morphological approach, we studied the presence of inflammatory cells inside leiomyomas, in the myometrium immediately surrounding and distant from leiomyomas. Next, we studied the localization of the ECM, the contractile proteins (a-sma and desmin) and the immunohistochemical profile of the mesenchymal cells with respect to CD34. Finally, we explored the effect of inflammatory mediators (TNF-α,IL-1β, IL-6, IL-15, GM-CSF and IFN-γ) on pro-fibrotic factor activin A mRNA expression in vitro. RESULTS: Higher numbers of macrophages were found inside and in the vicinity of leiomyoma as compared to the more distant surrounding myometrium. Cellular leiomyomas showed more macrophages and mast cells than the usual type. Inside the fibroid tissue, we found cells positive for a-smooth muscle actin, but negative for desmin and surrounded by a large amount of collagen, suggestive of myofibroblasts producing ECM. In myometrium and in leiomyoma usual type, we identified numerous CD34+ fibroblasts, which are known to give origin to myofibroblasts when loose CD34 expression. In the leiomyoma cellular type, stromal fibroblasts were CD34 negative. Finally, we found that TNF-a increased activin-A mRNA in myometrial and leiomyoma cells. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrated the presence of inflammation inside uterine leiomyomas, that may result in excessive ECM production, tissues remodeling and leiomyoma growth.

Characterization In Vitro in Animals and Humans. Andrea Wagenfeld, 1 Olaf Panknin, 2 Katrin Nowak-Reppel, 3 Stefan Klein, 4 Thomas Zollner, 1 Beate Rohde, 5 Christian Friedrich. 5 1 Bayer AG, Berlin, Germany; 2 Bayer AG, Berlin, Germany; 3 Bayer AG, Berlin, Germany; 4 Bayer AG, Berlin, Germany; 5 Bayer AG, Berlin, Germany. INTRODUCTION: Uterine fibroids are benign tumors of the uterus, characterized by their growth dependence on sex steroids. Non-invasive treatments are limited to a progesterone modulator (Ulipristal -not approved in the US) and GnRH agonists. However the use of the latter is limited to 6 months as they reduce sex steroids to post-menopausal levels and thus lead to hypoestrogenic side effects including bone loss. Aim of the project was to identify an orally available, potent and selective GnRH antagonist with low PK&PD variability allowing to titrate estradiol in a way that efficacy is maintained while avoiding hypoestrogenic side effects and thus being suitable for long term treatment. METHODS: 180 hits from a screening approach have been characterized on binding and in vitro activity towards the rat, monkey and human receptor. Selected compounds have then been tested on their LH reducing ability in rats and cynomolgus monkeys. Finally a cpd (BAY-784) with the most favorable profile has been administered to post-menopausal women in single escalating doses and characterized with regard to its PK &PD properties. RESULTS: BAY-784 is a potent (human IC 50. 21 nM) and selective GnRH antagonist without agonistic activity in vitro. It displays comparable functional activity at the GnRH receptor of rats and cynomolgus monkeys (rIC 50 24 nM, cynIC 50 35 nM). In ovariectomized rats a dose-dependent reduction of the plasma LH levels could be demonstrated (ED 50 4.5 mg/ kg). In the orchidectomized monkey LH suppression of up to ca. 60% from baseline was achieved with 20 mg/kg. Administration of BAY-784 to postmenopausal women was safe and well tolerated. PK variability in terms of AUC and Cmax was generally low across doses (gCV:14.9 to 36.4%). The maximum LH reduction was about 45% and showed a low variability of 27.6% (CV). CONCLUSIONS: BAY-784 revealed a favourable PK & safety profile and lead to LH with low variability of up to 45%. Whether this reduction will lead to a reduction in estradiol levels sufficient to reach the desired treatment effects in patients with uterine fibroids remains to be shown. In this work, we wanted to investigate if human fibroid stem cells do indeed produce exosomes, and evaluate factors that regulate this process (such as hypoxia) as well as possible effect on surrounding differentiated fibroid cells. METHODS: For exosome isolation, hFSCs were cultured in media with exosome-free FBS at normoxic or hypoxic conditions. Exoquick TC reagent was added to isolate exosomes. Electron microscopy and ZetaView were used to characterized hFSC derived hypoxic and normoxic exosomes. For proliferation and apoptosis studies, primary human (differentiated) fibroid cells were cultured for 48 hrs. MTT assay and Western blot were carried out to measure the level of proliferation and apoptosis. We also used MiScript PCR array human fibrosis kit to run RT-PCR for miRNA expression profiling in (hFSC) derived hypoxic vs normoxic exosomes. RESULTS: Hypoxia induced dramatic increase in exosomes production by hFSC (up to 16 fold increase) compared to normoxic-grown hFSC (P = 0.005). The hypoxic and normoxic exosomes were similar in size about 200 nm. The hypoxic exosomes induced significantly higher rate of proliferation and lower rates of apoptosis in primary fibroid cell proliferation compared to normoxic exosomes after 48 hours of treatment. PCR array revealed 3 folds or more up-regulation of 11 miRNA and 3 of these miRNAs are intricately involved in regulation the estrogen receptor. CONCLUSIONS: Hypoxic human fibroid stem cells produce dramatically more exosomes that possess robust pro-oncogenic properties. This pro-proliferative paracrine stimulation of primary fibroid cells by hFSCs derived exosomes is likely mediated through miRNA. Further understanding of the cross-talk between human fibroid tumor-forming stem cells and surrounding differentiated tumor cells can provide novel therapeutic targets for treatment of symptomatic uterine fibroids.
