back_matter.text: Investigate the Inhibitory Effect of SS5020-A Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator on Uterine Leiomyomas. Bin Li, 1 Takashi Takeda, 2 Kenji Tsuiji, 1 Nobuo Yaegashi. 1 1 Tohoku University Graduate School of Medicine, Sendai, Japan; 2 Kinki University School of Medicine, Osaka, Japan. INTRODUCTION: Uterine leiomyomas are the most common gynecological benign tumors and greatly affect reproductive health and wellbeing. Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) are estrogen receptor (ER) ligands that act as estrogens in some tissues while blocking estrogen activity in others. SS5020, a new benzopyran antiestrogen, has anti-breast cancer potential in rats and mice model. In this study, we investigated the inhibitory effect of SS5020 on uterine leiomyomas in vitro and in vivo. METHODS: In vitro study, ELT-3 cells were treated with various concentrations of Tamoxifen (TAM), SS1020 and SS5020. Cell proliferation was evaluated by MTS assay. In vivo study, human leiomyoma tumor tissues were collected from female Japanese patients at the time of hysterectomy and implanted into immunodeficient mouse. Mice were administered orally with SS5020. Then tumors were evaluated by tissue morphology, steroid receptors, apoptosis and collagen components. RESULTS: SS5020 inhibited ELT-3 cells proliferation. Xenograft model study showed that SS5020 administration inhibited the enlargement of the tumor, caused the inhibitory effect of cellular proliferation and ER, PR expression levels. Furthermore, SS5020 increased TUNEL positive cells. However, the expression levels of smooth muscle actin (SMA) and collagen components exhibited no significant changed. CONCLUSIONS: These experimental findings showed that SS5020 inhibited uterine leiomyoma cells proliferation both in vitro and in vivo. However, the inhibitory effect was not as strong as to affect the expression levels of SMA and collagen components. Vanderbilt, Nashville, TN, USA; 3 Marshfield Clinic, Marshfield, WI, USA; 4 Geisinger Health Service, Danville, PA, USA; 5 Norhtwestern, Chicago, IL, USA; 6 Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, New York, NY, USA; 7 The Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA. INTRODUCTION: Up to 77% of women have a uterine fibroid (UF) by menopause. UF are the leading indication for hysterectomy and account for up to $39B in annual healthcare costs. Risk of UFs is heritable with disparities in UF risk, symptoms, and severity among ancestral groups. African ancestry (AA) populations have 2-3 fold higher prevalence, more severe symptoms, and earlier onset than Europeans (EA). Because up to 51% of UF cases are unaware of fibroid status and are misclassified as controls in surveys, association studies of UF risk without UF status confirmed by imaging suffer from information bias. METHODS: We conducted an association study of rare and common genetic determinants of UF risk confirmed by pelvic imaging from electronic medical records (EMR) from 6 eMERGE Network sites (N=10,227). All subjects were classified using a validated EMR algorithm (PPV 98%, NPV 96%). All samples were genotyped by GWAS arrays and a subset was also genotyped by exome arrays. RESULTS: The most statistically significant associations from transethnic meta-analysis were the intergenic SNPs rs2983218 at chr6q27 (OR=1.23, p=8x10 -10 ) and rs13103279 at chr4q34.3 (OR=0.81, p=2x10 -9 ) near genes involved in angiogenic pathways. Statistically significant associations were observed in the subset of AA cohorts for the rare (MAF<0.01) variants rs190615976 at chr17 near IGF2BP1 (OR=3.82, p=2x10 -10 ), chr2 at rs77950674 near RUFY4 (OR=4.15, p=7x10 -10 ) and rs116003406 in the 3'UTR of SLC9A4 (OR=3.57, p=3x10 -9 ), and chr4 at rs115077882 in ARFIP1 (OR=1.98, p=5x10 -9 ). In EAs the rare variant rs148308239 near NEBL on chr10 was significantly associated with UF risk (OR=0.44, p=5x10 -8 ). CONCLUSIONS: These results suggest UF risk is influenced by common and rare variants, and ancestral genetic heterogeneity in UF risk is likely.

Local Estrogen Therapy Modulates Immune Response in Vaginal Tissue of Postmenopausal Women. Oksana Shynlova, 1 Yvonne Leong, 2 Harold Drutz, 2 May Alarab. 2 1 MSH, Toronto, ON, Canada; 2 MSH, Toronto, ON, Canada. INTRODUCTION: Currently pelvic organ prolapse (POP) affects almost half of postmenopausal women. Menopause has also been associated with lower urinary tract symptoms and urogenital atrophy. Local low-dose vaginal estrogen therapy (creams or tablets) can treat urinary symptoms related to atrophy, but its effect on POP is less clear. Ovarian hormones are known to influence the immune system that plays a major role in uterine tissue repair/regeneration. We investigated whether local estrogen therapy affects immune responses (cytokine expression and the presence of leukocytes) in vaginal tissue of postmenopausal patients with severe POP. METHODS: Postmenopausal women undergoing vaginal hysterectomy and anterior vaginal wall repair for POP (POPQ=3-4) were recruited. Vaginal biopsies were collected from POP patients not treated with hormone (Controls, N=14) and patients using local vaginal estrogen cream (conjugated equine estrogen) or tablets (estradiol) (N=13). One half of each sample was frozen in liquid nitrogen for biochemical study, the second half was fixed in formalin. Total protein and RNA was extracted. The expression of multiple cytokines was analyzed using 17-plex Cytokine assay and RT-PCR (N=6-13/group). Leukocyte infiltration was examined by immunohistochemistry (N=10/group). RESULTS: Protein expression of cytokines (IL1b, IL6) and chemokines (IL8, MCP1, MIP1β) as well as their transcript levels were significantly (p<0.05) up-regulated by local estrogen therapy in vaginal tissue of postmenopausal POP patients as compared to untreated Controls. IFNɤ protein was not detected in Controls, however was upregulated in all samples from Estrogen group. Hormone-induced chemokines play important roles in leukocyte infiltration, thus we examined vaginal tissues using pan-leukocyte marker CD45 and CD68 (expressed by tissue macrophages). We detected a significant increase in the number of CD68+ cells in the sub-epithelium/lamina propria (140±57 vs 32±5 cells/mm2) and muscularis (66±10 vs 30±7 cells/mm2) layers of estrogen-treated vaginal tissues compared to Controls. CONCLUSIONS: An activated local immune response was detected in the vaginal tissue of postmenopausal POP patients after estrogen treatment. The immune alterations included significant increase in pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines, which coincided with infiltration of immune cells . We speculate that the infiltrated leukocytes may play a role in the vaginal tissue repair and remodeling .

Menstrual Concerns in Young Women: The Father's Perspective. Jane E Girling, 1 Samuel CJ Hawthorne, 1,2 Jennifer L Marino, 1 Abdul Ghani Nur Azurah, 3 Sonia R Grover, 2 Yasmin L Jayasinghe. 1,2 1 The University of Melbourne, Royal Women's Hospital, Parkville, Australia; 2 Royal Children's Hospital, Parkville, Australia; 3 UKM Medical Centre, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. INTRODUCTION: A father's knowledge of menstrual symptoms is usually considered limited, yet there have been no studies on paternal understanding of menstruation. As not every family has a mother, a well-informed father can be essential for ongoing health of adolescent daughters. This study aimed to establish the degree of understanding and concern of fathers of adolescent girls with menstrual symptoms. METHODS: Adolescent patients attending the Royal Children's Hospital outpatient gynaecology clinic for dysmenorrhoea and/or heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) and their parents were surveyed about the father's understanding of menstrual symptoms and potential medications, as well as involvement/concerns with his daughter's health care.

RESULTS: 23 surveys were returned by daughters, 19 by mothers, and 15 by fathers. The fathers' knowledge of menstrual symptoms was poorer than mothers, although most knew of HMB (93%) and mood swings (87%). A large percentage of both fathers and mothers answered 'don't know' or didn't answer questions about potential long-term health impacts and side-effects of medications, although parents were clearly concerned about side-effects. Of fathers, 80% felt sympathetic/concerned, 53% helpless and 13% frustrated when daughters were in pain. Parental perception of their daughter's pain was comparable within families, with mothers more likely to overestimate and fathers underestimate. When asked about impacts on the family, 93% of fathers (79% of mothers) worried about their daughter's welfare and 60% (21%) about schooling; 54% (69%) noted impacts on family activities and 33% (53%) took leave from work to care for daughters. CONCLUSIONS: We present the first insight into father's knowledge of their daughter's menstrual health. Overall, fathers have an incomplete picture of menstrual symptoms or side effects of common medications. Even in this cohort, which could be expected to be well informed due to their daughter's attendance at a tertiary hospital, it is clear that both mothers and fathers lack sufficient knowledge to make fully informed decisions for daughters. This highlights the need for carefully tailored education material that addresses knowledge gaps and parental concerns. HIV-treatment has evolved rapidly with most HIV positive people in Western world being on continuous suppressive combination Antiretroviral Treatment (cART) with restored immunity and life expectancy approaching that of general population. METHODS: A retrospective study of all 369 women attending HIV care at our hospital at least twice during 2002-2013. Their mean (SD) age was 35y (±9) at the beginning of the follow-up. All women were invited to annual PAP-smear follow-up. Altogether 2056 PAP-smears were collected and analyzed using the Bethesda system. Risk factors for SIL (combined LSIL, ASC-H and HSIL) were analyzed using logistic regression models. RESULTS: The distribution of PAP-smears findings at the beginning of follow-up was 60% normal, 25% ASC-US, 10% LSIL, 0,3% ASC-H, 2,7% HSIL and 1.6 AGC-NOS, whereas the last PAP-smear findings were 90% normal, 7 % ASC-US, 3% LSIL, 0,3% ASC-H and 0,3% HSIL. Altogether 53% of the women were on HAART and 86% on cART at the beginning and end of the follow-up, respectively. The corresponding mean CD4 lymphocyte counts (/µL) were 465 (range 6-1577) and 615 (range 51-2138). Significant risk factors for SIL are shown in Table. Mode of transmission, country of origin, smoking, hepatitis C serostatus or age were not risk factors for SIL. Maternal obesity is associated with poor reproductive outcomes and their offspring have greater risk of adverse metabolic sequelae and fetal anomalies. The precise mechanisms behind these associations are undetermined. We hypothesized that obese women have an altered follicular fluid (FF) metabolite profile compared to nonobese women.

We performed a prospective cohort study of women aged 21-39 undergoing transvaginal oocyte retrieval (TVOR) at an academic medical center. Women were excluded for history of endometriosis. FF was obtained at time of TVOR. Nano-LCMS analysis was performed.Metaboanalyst was used to compare FF between obese (BMI >=30 kg/m2) and non-obese (BMI<25 kg/m2) women. Demographics were compared using t-tests or Chi-squared when appropriate. PCA was used to assess differences in the metabolome. RESULTS: FF was analyzed from 15 obese and 16 non-obese women. There were no differences between group in age or race. PCA demonstrated significant differences in FF metabolites between obese versus non-obese women. * Figure( s) will be available online. Folate metabolism and fatty acid (FA) activation pathways were most different between groups. ( p <0.05) CONCLUSIONS: Differences exist in the FF metabolome of obese versus non-obese women. Altered folate metabolism in FF could explain the increased incidence of neural tube defects in offspring of obese women. Altered FA activation may lead to increased ROS and altered oocyte competence which could explain some of the poor reproductive outcomes in obese women.

Infertility. Hans M Albertsen, Rakesh Chettier, Kenneth Ward. Juneau Biosciences, LLC, Salt Lake City, UT, USA. INTRODUCTION: Exome sequencing (ES) provides a means to detect private and rare variants in candidate disease genes, and genes with elevated mutation-rates often indicate disease genes. In contrast, genes with low mutation-rates often indicate developmentally essential genes that do not tolerate mutations. In this study we find that four key endometriosis genes (WNT4, CDC42, ID4 and VEZT) have very low mutation rates suggesting that they play critical roles in development.
back_matter.section: S-211 Key Endometriosis Genes Show Very Low Mutations Rates Indicating These Genes Have Essential Functions During Embryonic Development and Suggests a Role in Endometriosis-Related

back_matter.text: ES was performed on 859 women with endometriosis using the Ion Proton platform. DNA variants were determined and confirmed using the Genome Analysis Toolkit and mutation rates were compared Frequently Mutated Genes (FLAGS) gene rankings. Embryonic gene expression status was determined using published global expression levels in pre-and peri-implantation embryos. RESULTS: As shown in Table 1 , we found very low mutation-rates in each of the four confirmed endometriosis genes in concordance with their FLAGS rank. The Table also show that each of the genes, except WNT4, are expressed at the earliest stages of embryonic development prior to implantation. Low FLAGS-ranking number correlate with high mutation rates.

We find evidence that the endometriosis genes WNT4, CDC42, ID4 and VEZT, display very low mutation-rates in affected women, in a manner consistent with genes that play essential roles during development. We further determined that CDC42, ID4 and VEZT are expressed during the earliest stages of development prior to implantation. This is in concordance with the literature where is has been reported that CDC42 and VEZT null mutants in mice are embryonic lethals before or at implantation. This evidence supports a model for endometriosisrelated infertility that involve impaired epithelial development at the morula and blastocyst stage of development. The infertility seen in some endometriosis patients might be a pleiotropic effect of the genes which act on a different adult tissue to cause endometriosis. If this model is correct then endometriosis-related mutations from either parent might contribute to infertility.

Decidualization Is Not Impaired in Endometrial Stromal Fibroblasts from Women with Fibroids. Lusine Aghajanova, Sahar Houshdaran, Juan C Irwin, Linda C Giudice. University of California San Francisco, San Francisco, CA, USA. INTRODUCTION: Uterine fibroids are a common finding in infertility patients. Impaired implantation has been proposed to contribute to compromised fertility. While the most recent findings suggest no difference in the endometrial receptivity signature in women with intramural fibroids, there are no data on the decidualization potential of endometrial stromal fibroblasts from women with fibroids. METHODS: Endometrial stromal fibroblasts (eSF) were isolated from 5 women with intramural fibroids (F) and 5 women with no uterine pathology (NUP) and treated with 1mM progesterone (P 4 ) (with 10nM estradiol (E 2 )) for 14 days, and 0.5mM of 8-bromo-cAMP for 96 hours. IGFBP1 and prolactin secretion was measured by ELISA. Expression of P 4 -and cAMP-regulated genes and decidualization markers (IGFBP1, prolactin, HOXA10, EBAF, SST, FOXO1A, GPX3), steroidogenic enzymes HSD17B1, HSD17B2, aromatase, and estrogen (ESR1, ESR2) and progesterone receptor (PRA, PRB) mRNAs were determined by realtime qRT-PCR. Cell morphology was analyzed under light microscopy. In addition, mid-secretory endometrium (MSE) was obtained from 8 women with F and 4 with NUP, and subjected to microarray analysis on the HU133 Affymetrix platform with subsequent bioinformatics analysis; validation was performed with Fluidigm array. Menstrual cycle phase was assigned by histology, hormone levels and bioinformatics methods. RESULTS: Large number of transcripts was significantly dysregulated throughout the menstrual cycle in F vs NUP. Upon validation, there was an increased expression of IGFBP1 mRNA, but not prolactin, in F vs NUP tissue, but no significant difference was found in cultured cells on mRNA or protein level. No difference was seen in SST, GPX3, EBAF, FOXO1A or HSD17B1, HSD17B2 and aromatase mRNA between F and NUP on tissue levels or in eSF decidualized with either E 2 +P 4 or cAMP. HOXA10 mRNA was significantly upregulated in F vs. NUP upon decidualization with cAMP. PRB mRNA, but not ESR1, ESR2 or PRA,

was significantly downregulated in F vs NUP when decidualized with E 2 +P 4 . No significant difference in cell morphology upon decidualization was seen between the two groups. CONCLUSIONS: Normal expression of decidualization markers in MSE and cultured eSF from women with intramural fibroids indicate preserved decidualization potential despite observed gene expression changes in F vs. NUP tissue.

The Blastocyst implantation is a critical step in the establishment of pregnancy and is strictly regulated by a plethora of endometrial molecules including inflammatory cytokines. Glucocorticoids (GC) are crucial in the inflammatory response that accompanies tissue remodeling and influence several aspects of early pregnancy. Local tissue concentrations of GC are modulated by the enzyme 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (11β-HSD), which interconverts cortisol and cortisone. Although the type 1 isoform (11β-HSD1) is present in term decidua, its expression and regulatory mechanisms have not been characterized in first trimester maternal tissues. The present study aimed to evaluate the role of inflammatory mediators as regulators of GC balance, by assessing the effect of IL1β, TNFα and IFNg on 11β-HSD1 expression in cultured first trimester decidual cells (FT-DCs). METHODS: Isolated, purified FT-DCs were cultured for 8 days in 10-8M estradiol (E2)+10-7M medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA) to mimic the steroidal milieu of pregnancy. Cells were treated with 1ng/ml of IL1β, INFγ, 5ng/ml of TNFα alone or in combination for 5 or 24 hours. RNA was extracted and relative levels of mRNA for 11β-HSD1 assessed by quantitative RT-PCR, while enzymatic activity was evaluated in cell homogenate using cortisone and NADPH as cofactor and measuring cortisol concentration by ELISA.

In cultured FT-DC, the addition of IL1β significantly upregulated 11β-HSD1 mRNA levels (15-fold over basal levels) while TNFα and IFNγ had not a statistical significant effect when used alone. The combination of IL1β or TNFα with IFNγ resulted in a slightly increase in 11β-HSD1 mRNA. Mimicking mRNA changes, IL1β induced a statistical significant increase in 11β-HSD1 activity (2-fold over basal activity) while TNFα and IFNg had no effect. However, when IFNg was used in combination with IL1β a synergistic augmentation of enzymatic activity was observed (3-fold increase over basal activity; p<0.001). CONCLUSIONS: The present study, demonstrating an inflammatory cytokines-dependent control of11β-HSD1 expression and activity in FT-DCs, supports a link between implantation-related inflammation and GC metabolism in early pregnancy.

There is a significant positive correlation between AMH level and random AFC in women with cancer. These findings support the use of these measures in this patient population, where urgency and time constraints often preclude testing for ovarian reserve on cycle day 3. Ovarian tissue cryopreservation is a promising option for fertility preservation for reproductive age cancer patients. During cryopreservation, cells or tissues are exposed to harmful environment such as cold stress, crystallization, which leads to a decline of cellular functionality. In this study, we attempted to demonstrate the effects of anti-apoptotic agents on the microRNA (miR) expression of pre-cryopreservation and post-thaw murine ovaries. METHODS: Six-week-old, C57/BL6 mice ovaries were isolated and treated with 10 µM of ROCK inhibitor (Y-27632) before freezing or after thawing. Total RNAs were extracted from ovaries of each group and the expression of ovary-specific microRNAs were analyzed. The expression of FSH-and LH receptor genes was assessed in both groups.

The expression of miRs, let-7b, let-7c, miR-16 was downregulated on cryopreserved ovaries compared to non-cryopreserved ovaries. Post-thaw treatment of ROCK inhibitor significantly up-regulated the expression of microRNAs, let-7b and let-7c compared to non-treated control. The gonadotropin receptor gene expression was not significantly affected.

We demonstrated that the miR expression profile on mice ovaries can be altered by cryopreservation and be affected by ROCK inhibitor treatment (HI14C2289 and HI14C2259). Although the presence of FXR and bile acid has been shown in the human ovary, its function in reproduction and folliculogenesis and luteinization has not been determined. The present study aimed to investigate FXR expression in human luteinized granulosa cells (GCs) and the role of FXR in steroidogenesis.

Immunofluorescence and RT-PCR were used to show the presence of FXR in the human GCs. To reveal the roles of FXR in steroid production, a synthetic FXR agonist, GW4064, was used. We analyzed mRNA levels of steroidogenesis-related genes quantitative RT-PCR. Progesterone and estradiol concentrations in cultured media were then analyzed. Total bile acid level in cultured media was examined to explore a possible interaction between bile acid and steroid hormone production.

We confirmed in human GCs the presence of FXR protein and mRNA expression of FXR and cytochrome P450 7A1, the ratelimiting enzyme of bile acid synthesis. The addition of GW4064 in GCs statistically but minimally reduced the bile acid concentration, implying a small scale of local bile acid production. While GW4064 addition downregulated modest P450 aromatase mRNA expression and estradiol secretion (around 20% changes), it significantly increased the mRNA expression of progesterone-related genes, steroidogenic acute regulatory protein and cholesterol side-chain cleavage enzyme, ultimately raising significant progesterone secretion. CONCLUSIONS: These results suggest that FXR and bile acids are involved in the process of steroidogenesis and maintenance of steroid levels in the ovary.

Advanced Recently, special emphasis was put on the role of Follicular T helper Cells (TfH) in the process of immune cells' maturation. TfH are essential for B-cell maturation and immunoglobuline production after immunization with thymus-development antigens. As such, our understanding of the TfH role in pregnancy remains incomplete. Aim of this study was to characterize the contribution of TfH-cells towards a negative pregnancy outcome.

A well-established mouse model for pregnancy disturbances have been applied in our study. CBA/J females were either paired with DBA/2J males to obtain immune-induced pathological pregnancies (P), or with BALB/c males, generating normal pregnancies (N). Non-pregnant mice were used as controls. Mice were sacrificed and lymphocytes were isolated from the spleen (day 14) and analyzed by flow cytometry. The T-cell's expression of Il-21 was also examined in vitro and analyzed their phenotype by flow cytometry. Moreover, naive T cells were cultivated in vitro for 7 days to explore their capacity to generate TfH. IL-21 actions on B cells were also studied.

Our experiments revealed that the number of TfH decreases during normal pregnancies in mice. *Figure(s) will be available online. Additionally, we observed the expression of IL-21 receptors on B cells was increased in pathological as compared to normal pregnancies. We were able to shown that there was also a shift in B cell subtypes, predominantly confined to the population of Marginal Zone B cells (MZ). CONCLUSIONS: Our data suggest that TfH and IL-21 are relevant factors within disturbed pregnancies. Our data contributes to a better understanding of autoimmune-related pregnancy disorders. IL-33 is a cytokine produced by fibroblasts, endothelial and epithelial cells and capable of promoting inflammation via activation immune cells and upregulation of inflammatory cytokines such as IFN-γ, IL-17, and TNF-α. This aberrant immune response has been well documented in endometriosis, but only one study has examined and reported the presence of IL-33 in endometriosis patients. We hypothesize that IL-33 plays a role in the inflammatory microenvironment of endometriotic lesions.

Our goal was to investigate levels of IL-33 in endometriosis patients before and after surgical removal of lesions, and the role of IL-33 in the pathogenesis of the condition. METHODS: From endometriosis patients undergoing lesion removal surgery (n=24), we obtained matched eutopic and ectopic endometrium, as well as plasma samples pre-surgery, 2-weeks post-, and 3 months post-surgery (Greenville Hospital, USA). As control (n=7), we obtained endometrium and plasma samples from healthy, cycle stage-matched women (University of North Carolina, USA). An ELISA (R&D systems) was performed on plasma samples from normal and endometriosis patients. RESULTS: Based on samples analyzed so far, endometriosis patients showed no significant changes in pooled analyses of IL-33 levels across time. When stratified by disease stage, IL-33 levels were higher at 3 months vs. 2 weeks post-surgery in early stage (stages I-II), but not in advanced stage patients (stages III-IV). When compared to normal patients, levels of IL-33 were lower only in 2 week post-surgery vs. normal samples. After stratification, early stage patients had lower levels of IL-33 at both pre-and 2 week post-surgery, but the differences disappeared at 3 months. No differences were found in normal vs. advanced stage patients. Tissue analysis and mechanistic studies are in progress. CONCLUSIONS: Our preliminary analysis indicates that serum IL-33 levels are influenced by lesion removal and seem to achieve closer to normal levels at 3 months. Further studies are in progress.

In summary, the effect of LPS on intracellular HO-1 expression in inflammatory immune cells appears to be tissue specific.In addition, the LPS-induced phenotypic maturation of DCs appears to coincide with an increased expression of HO-1 in blood DCs. We conclude that since mature DCs activate effector adaptive responses, they may disrupt immune homeostasis and then lead to adverse changes as a result of inflammation during pregnancy. Vaginal mucosae are often exposed to chemicals, irritants, microorganisms and viruses that induce inflammation and enhance women' susceptibility to infections. Most studies on female genital mucosae responses were performed on available animal models or ex vivo models. Alternatively, 3D organotypic cultures were generated using an exogenous extracellular matrix to provide spacing and to create the in vivo-like morphology and ultrastructure characteristics of a vaginal tissue. Using a unique self-assembly technique, we report here the production of a fully autologous Three-dimensional (3D) model that is very specific for studying vaginal mucosae responses. Objectives: 1-To validate that our human 3D model mimics female genital mucosae, 2-To study mucosal immunity to various infections.

Vaginal stromal and epithelial cells were isolated from vaginal biopsies of the same HIV-1-negative female donor. Stromal cells were cultured and allowed to form their own extracellular matrix, and vaginal epithelium was seeded on top of the stromal layer and differentiated in vitro using growth factors and various estrogen concentrations. Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells (PBMC) were isolated from healthy donors and immune cells extracted and incorporated into the vaginal equivalents. RESULTS: Immunofluorescence using antibodies against cytokeratin, Lamin and collagen identified the three key structures of the equivalent (epithelium, basement membrane and stromal component). Primary human monocyte-derived macrophages (MDM) infected with HIV-1 or free HIV-1 viral load were co-cultured on the apical surface of our equivalents to measure virus transcytosis 24, 48, 72h post-infection in the multilayer vaginal model. CONCLUSIONS: Our experimental model indicates that the 3D vaginal equivalent engineered in our laboratory is similar to native vaginal tissue, and can be used to study intravaginal delivery of microbicides, contraceptives and/or anti-HIV agents. Melatonin is an indoleamine involved in the regulation of circadian rhythms, sleep and food-intake. Apart from the pineal gland, many peripheral tissues express both melatonin and its receptors. This ubiquitous distribution suggests that, in addition to endocrine actions of pineal derived indoleamine, locally produced melatonin might exert autocrine/paracrine effects in different tissues. This should be the case in ovary, where the expression of both melatonin and its receptors has been demonstrated in human granulosa-luteal cells.

We previously demonstrated that increasing concentrations of melatonin influence human corpus luteum function. In particular, melatonin was able to increase P4 and PGE 2 release and to reduce PGF 2a and VEGF release, suggesting the ability of melatonin to positively affect luteal steroidogenesis and to influence the balance between luteotropic and luteolytic factors.To further extend our observations about the role of melatonin as intraovarian regulator factor we wanted to evaluate the possible presence of melatonin receptors-MTRN1B/MT2 and GPR50-in human corpus luteum.

To this aim corpora lutea were obtained from normally menstruating patients (aged 25-38 years) at the time of surgery for nonendocrine gynecological diseases. Immunoistochemistry was performed in 7 corpora lutea. RESULTS: A strong to moderate immunohistochemical staining of both proteins in the luteal cells was observed. CONCLUSIONS: This study support our previous hypothesis of melatonin action in regulating luteal function and suggests a direct regulatory role in corpus luteum integrity. Melatonin could become an important medication for improving ovarian and luteal function and open new opportunities for the management of several ovarian-luteal diseases.

Feasibility of TopFluor™ Cholesterol to Study Cholesterol Trafficking in Steroidogenic Cells. George Patounakis, Alan H DeCherney, Jennifer Lippincott-Schwartz. National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA. INTRODUCTION: Cholesterol trafficking in steroidogenic cells has been studied primarily using biochemical methods and thus can only provide insight into the average behavior of cells ignoring any spatial specialization of organelles in cells. TopFluor™ Cholesterol (TFCh) is a cholesterol with a fluorescent molecule on the side-chain. TFCh may allow live-cell imaging of cholesterol up through the side-chain cleavage step since the fluorescent molecule will be cleaved with the side-chain. Given the selective nature of the P450 side-chain cleavage (P450scc), the structure of TFCh may not be recognized by the mitochondrial transporters or P450scc. Since the fluorescent molecule is on the side-chain, successful import and cleavage of the side-chain should result in 2 fluorescent byproducts (an aldehyde and subsequent conversion to alcohol by aldolases). The objective of this study was to determine if TFCh can be used to study mitochondrial cholesterol trafficking in steroidogenic cells. METHODS: Mouse Leydig tumor cells (mLTC-1), which retain their response to hCG stimulation, were cultured and exposed to TFCh in methyl-β-cyclodextrin overnight to exchange unlabeled cholesterol in the plasma membrane for TFCh. Experimental conditions were control, hCG 100mIU/mL, aminoglutetimide (AG) 172µM, and hCG+AG (same as other concentrations). After 6 hours, cells were trypsinized, pelleted, and resuspended in methanol:chloroform:water to extract polar and nonpolar molecules. Thin layer chromatography was performed on silica gel with a solvent system of cyclohexane:ethyl acetate. The plates were fluorescently imaged and the peaks quantified. RESULTS: All conditions showed 4 dominant peaks in addition to the source spot from most to least polar as follows: by-product peak #1, free TFCh, by-product peak #2, and esterified TFCh. The free TFCh peak was approximately 400x larger than the two by-product peaks and approximately 75x larger than the esterified TFCh peak. The hCG condition showed the by-product peaks 50% greater than the other 3 conditions as expected since AG inhibits P450scc and thus cleavage of the fluorescent side-chain even in the presence of hCG. CONCLUSIONS: TFCh is a novel probe for studying mitochondrial cholesterol trafficking in steroidogenic cells. A potential difficulty with imaging TFCh in mitochondria is the large difference in intensity of the free cholesterol versus the by-product peaks, which will ultimately require a sensitive high dynamic range camera. syndrome, also known as Mullerian aplasia, is a congenital anomaly characterized by the absence of the uterus and vagina. MRKH affects 1/5000 females and is the second most common cause of primary amenorrhea in adolescent girls. Although WNT4, LHX1, and HNF1B gene mutations and copy number variants have been identified in some patients, the genetic basis for most cases of MRKH is unknown. MRKH often occurs without a family history, which has led us to hypothesize that affected patients have heterozygous de novo mutations. The purpose of this study was to identify candidate genes in MRKH patients.

We studied DNA of 16 trios (affected daughter and unaffected parents) with whole exome sequencing (WES). Variants were filtered using the Exome Aggregation Consortium (ExAC), and filtered according to phenotype using PhenoDB. Selected sequence variants present in the affected patient, but absent in both parents, were confirmed by Sanger sequencing.

In the 16 affected females, a total of 1822 de novo variants were detected, including 208 frameshift, 31 stop-gain, 60 splice site, and 1523 missense. WES identified six genes to contain frameshift or splice site variants in more than one patient, with variant frequency in ExAC <0.01. These include TNKS2, MYO6, IK, KIAA0040, ASPN, and FYB.We have confirmed putative deletions in two of the genes by Sanger sequencing, and are currently evaluating the other genes. CONCLUSIONS: In addition to important population frequency information provided by ExAC, the incorporation of PhenoDB allows more detailed phenotypic analysis. This should improve the detection of meaningful genetic variants. If additional variants in these six genes are identified in our cohort of 127 MRKH patients, this will provide strong evidence for involvement of the candidate genes in the development of the female reproductive tract.

Blunted INTRODUCTION: Diet intake in pregnant rats fed a low protein (LP) diet was significantly reduced during late pregnancy despite elevated plasma levels of ghrelin. We hypothesized that ghrelin signaling in the hypothalamus is blunted under a low protein diet condition and therefore, it does not stimulate diet intake during late pregnancy. To test this hypothesis, diet and water intake, expression of genes related to appetite regulation and hypothalamic ghrelin signaling in response to intraventricular (ICV) injection of ghrelin in pregnant rats fed LP diet were investigated. METHODS: Female SD rats were fed a normal (CT) or LP diet from Day 1 of pregnancy. On Day 21, 0.5 µg ghrelin was given into the third ventricle. Diet and water intake at 30, 60 and 120 min after ICV injection CONCLUSIONS: LH surge predicts CRL on first trimester ultrasound significantly better than LMP. Therefore, these preliminary results suggest that LH surge could be preferentially used for gestational age calculations, when available. Further investigation in a larger cohort is ongoing. *Figure(s) will be available online.

What Is Implantation Failure? Chelsi Goodman, Carli Chapman, John S Rinehart, Carolyn B Coulam. Reproductive Medicinie Institute, Chicago, IL, USA. INTRODUCTION: Recurrent implantation failure (RIF) is a major cause of failure to achieve pregnancy after in vitro fertilization (IVF) and embryo transfer treatment cycles. However, no formal criteria defining the number of failed cycles or the total number of embryos transferred in these IVF attempts exist. Considering the current success rate of IVF treatments, outcomes of IVF procedures performed between January 1, 2014 and June 30, 2015 were analyzed to determine the cumulative number of embryos needed to achieve 80% probability of pregnancy with demonstrated fetal cardiac activity. METHODS: From January 1, 2014, and June 30, 2015, 644 patients underwent IVF or embryo transfer procedures involving 2093 embryos. 427 women had positive HCG tests 7 days after transfer of 1364 embryos, resulting in 381 FHT demonstrated by 6 weeks gestation. Of the 381 positive FHT, 55 had preimplantation genetic screening (PGS) and 326 had no PGS. The percentage of pregnancies with demonstrable FHT was determined for each number of embryos transferred, and cumulative pregnancy rates were computed. RESULTS: Cumulative rates to achieve fetal cardiac activity compared with total number of embryos transfer are shown in the following graph (Fig 1) . The rate of FHT after 1 embryo transferred double from 13% to 29% with PGS. Whereas, after a cumulative of 4 embryos transferred the rate of FHT was 75% amongst PGS and 82% with no PGS. CONCLUSIONS: The total number of embryos transferred to achieve 80% of pregnancies with FHT is 4. After a cumulative of 4 embryos transferred, PGS does not increase probability of successful pregnancy. PGS should be used to make the diagnosis rather than evaluation of implantation failure. Individuals who have not achieved successful pregnancy after transferring 4 embryos should be evaluated for implantation failure. *Figure(s) will be available online. Elevated progesterone (P) in a fresh ART transfer cycle results in decreased implantation and live birth. Recent evidence has shown elevated P likely advances the endometrium creating asynchrony with the embryo and thus implantation failure. If the window of implantation is closing as the embryo attempts to implant, there may be difficulty with trophoblastic invasion, leading to failure of early pregnancies. Our objective was to evaluate if P on the day of trigger was associated with spontaneous abortion (SAB) rates in fresh transfers. The secondary objective was to determine if P interacted with SAB risk differently in fresh versus FET cycles.

This was a retrospective cohort study. Autologous ART cycles with fresh transfers or FET from 2011-2013 were included if P was measured on the day of trigger in the initial fresh cycle. The primary outcome was spontaneous abortion. GEE modeling was performed to control for age, embryo quality, embryo stage, and repeated cycles. Interaction testing was performed to determine if the effect of P on SAB was similar in fresh and FET cycles. P was treated as a continuous variable except in additional analyses comparing P threshold of 2ng/mL. RESULTS: 4,123 fresh and FET transfer cycles were included, resulting in 1,547 fresh and 491 FET pregnancies. The overall SAB rate was 19.9% among fresh cycles and 18.9% in FET cycles. P as a continuous variable was not associated with SAB in fresh cycles (OR 0.93, 95%CI 0.68-1.29). P >2 ng/ml was not associated with SAB in fresh cycles (OR 0.96, 95%CI 0.24-3.05). Interaction testing of P and cycle type indicated P had similar associations with SAB in FET and fresh cycle (P=0.95). Similar results were found in both groups after adjusting for age, embryo quality, and embryo stage. CONCLUSIONS: Elevated P on the day of trigger during the initial fresh cycle was not associated with increased SAB in fresh transfer cycles or in FET cycles. Despite elevated P likely advancing the window of implantation, once implantation occurs, pregnancies are no longer negatively impacted by progesterone. INTRODUCTION: PCOS has been associated with numerous metabolic abnormalities including the Metabolic Syndrome (MetS) However, the underlying mechanism(s) have not been clearly elucidated. Previously we demonstrated alterations in skeletal muscle fiber type and decreased estrogen (ER), insulin (IR), and androgen (AR) receptor gene expression with PCOS. Since skeletal muscle represents the major site for insulin mediated glucose disposal, we sought to determine alterations in skeletal muscle glucose metabolism that could explain this relationship.

In patients with PCOS (NIH criteria), baseline labs, anthropomorphic measurements and vastus lateralis muscle biopsies were obtained (n=10) and compared to age and race matched controls (n=10). Protein levels of the ER alpha, AR-A, and AR-B were evaluated using routine western blot techniques. Phosphorylation levels of second messengers involved in glucose homeostasis were also examined. . Levels of phospho-MAPK, phospho-IRS-1, and phospho-JNK were similar in both groups. CONCLUSIONS: Skeletal muscle in patients with PCOS demonstrates changes associated with decreased glucose metabolism and a relative hyperinsulinemia. Our findings support a PCOS phenotype with a decreased oxidative capacity secondary to changes in fiber type, along with alterations at numerous points in insulin signaling pathways that affect the ability of skeletal muscle to increase uptake of glucose. Oral supplementation with myo-inositol, a new insulin sensitizer agent was demonstrated to enhance insulin sensitivity and improve the clinical and hormonal characteristics of patients in PCOS. Moreover Alpha-lipoic acid (ALA), a biological antioxidant, has been reported to improve glucose control in patients with type 2 diabetes, presumably by improving insulin sensitivity and reduction of oxidative stress. This study investigates the potential role of these two molecules in improving PCOS characteristics METHODS: Forty overweight PCOS women (BMI>25; age range 18-35 years) were enrolled. Anthropometric characteristics, hirsutism score, ovarian ultrasound, an oral glucose tolerance test and hormonal parameters, including AMH were evaluated before and after combined treatment of alpha-lipoic acid (800 mg), myoinositol (2000 mg) and folic acid (400 mcg) daily for six months. RESULTS: All patients completed the study therapy. A significant improvement in mean F-G score and BMI was obtained after six months of treatment, while WHR values did not significantly changed. All studied patients experienced a significant increase of number of cycles in six months. A significant ireduction of androgen levels (in terms of free androgen index, androstenedione, DHEAS) was observed. At baseline, AMH serum levels were above the normal range and after six months of treatment we observed a significant decrease. At baseline, participants presented a mean insulinemic response to OGTT and a normal peripheral insulin sensitivity expressed as HOMA-IR. After therapy, we did not observe a significant modification in peripheral insulin sensitivity and in insulin secretion during the OGTT CONCLUSIONS: This combined therapy was shown to restore the menstrual pattern and to improve the hormonal milieu in PCOS women, with a mechanism that, albeit not fully clarified, seems to be insulin independent and instead targeted to the ovary itself. Further investigations on a larger population are needed to confirm these results and to elucidate the specific mechanism of action of this therapy.

Effect of a Levonorgestrel Intrauterine System with or without Estradiol Supplementation on Reproductive Hormones and Ovulation in Late Reproductive Aged Women. Nanette F Santoro, Justin Chosich, Jeanelle Sheeder, Christina Gavito, Stephanie Teal. University of Colorado School of Medicine, Aurora, CO, USA.

The effect of the low circulating levels of levonorgestrel (LNG) that result from the use of an LNG intrauterine system (IUS) has been rarely studied in women of late reproductive/ perimenopausal age. Yet a combination of estradiol plus an LNG IUS may provide excellent symptom control with concurrent contraception for women in this age group.

We performed a double-blind, randomized, controlled pilot trial of regularly cycling women aged 40-52 with perimenopausal symptoms. Women were allocated to either LNG-IUS + low-dose TDE gel (intervention) or LNG-IUS alone (control). TDE was administered once daily as a 0.06% gel containing 0.75mg of TDE for 50 days. LNG-IUSs were placed at least 90 days before TDE or placebo gel treatment to assure stable circulating LNG. Participants collected daily first morning voided urine for 50 days; samples were analyzed for urinary estrogen and progesterone metabolites (E1c and Pdg). Ovulatory status of each cycle was determined using a Pdg algorithm that detects a significant rise in Pdg. Data were compared using rank sum tests or t tests as appropriate. Data re expressed as mean +/-SD unless otherwise specified. RESULTS: Thirty-eight women aged 42.9 ± 2.7 years with a mean BMI of 24.7 ± 3.3 kg/m 2 were enrolled; 20 were randomized to TDE. Twenty four women had sufficient urinary data for analysis; 11 of these women received active TDE and 13 received placebo. Of 46 possible ovulatory This fact, together with the lack of a proven molecular mechanism of action for ovarian protection with GnRHa places this approach under scrutiny as a fertility preservation strategy. We therefore aimed in this study to provide evidence for-or-against the role of GnRHa in the prevention of ovarian damage induced by chemotherapy and radiation in human.

Ovarian cortical pieces (n=15, age 14-37) and mitotic non-luteinized (COV434 and HGrC1) and non-mitotic luteinized human granulosa cells (HLGC) expressing GnRH receptor were used for the experiments. The samples were treated with cyclophosphamide, cisplatin, paclitaxel, 5-FU; or radiation (2Gy) with and without GnRHa leuprolide acetate for 24 hrs. DNA damage, apoptosis, follicle reserve, hormone markers of ovarian function and reserve (estradiol (E 2 ), progesterone (P) and anti-mullerian hormone (AMH)), and the expression of anti-apoptotic genes were compared.

The greatest magnitude of cytotoxicity was observed in the samples treated with cyclophosphamide, cisplatin and radiation. Exposure to these drugs resulted in DNA damage, apoptosis and massive follicle loss along with a concurrent decline in the steroidogenic activity of the samples. GnRHa co-administered with chemotherapy agents stimulated its receptors and raised intracellular cAMP level. But it neither activated anti-apoptotic pathways; nor prevented follicle loss, DNA damage and apoptosis induced by chemotherapy drugs and radiation *Figure(s) will be available online. CONCLUSIONS: GnRH agonist treatment with chemotherapy does not prevent or ameliorates ovarian damage and follicle loss in vitro.
